verses.latin: Vir erat in terra Hus, nomine Job, et erat vir ille simplex, et rectus, ac timens Deum, et recedens a malo.
verses.english: There was a man in the land of Uz named Job. That man was innocent in his heart, righteous in his deeds, reverent toward God, and always turned away from evil.

verses.latin: Natique sunt ei septem filii, et tres filiae.
verses.english: To him were born seven sons and three daughters.

verses.latin: Et fuit possessio ejus septem millia ovium, et tria millia camelorum, quingenta quoque juga boum, et quingentae asinae, ac familia multa nimis: fuitque vir ille magnus inter omnes orientales.
verses.english: His possessions included seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yokes of oxen, and five hundred female donkeys. He also had a very numerous household of servants. That man was the greatest of all the people of the East.

verses.latin: Ibantque filii ejus, et faciebant convivium per domos, unusquisque in die suo: et mittentes vocabant tres sorores suas, ut comederent, et biberent cum eis.
verses.english: His sons would go and hold feasts in their own houses, each on his designated day. They would send for their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

verses.latin: Cumque pertransissent dierum circuli convivii, mittebat Job, et sanctificabat eos: surgensque diluculo offerebat holocausta per singulos. Dicebat enim: Ne forte peccaverint filii mei, et blasphemaverint Deum in cordibus suis. Sic facit Job cunctis diebus.
verses.english: When the cycle of feasting days had passed, Job would send for his children and purify them. Rising early in the morning, he would offer a burnt offering for each of them. He would say to himself, "Perhaps my sons have sinned and inwardly renounced God in their hearts." Job did this continually.

verses.latin: Quadam autem die, cum venissent filii Dei ut assisterent coram Domino, affuit inter eos etiam Satan.
verses.english: Now on a certain day, when the sons of God — the angelic beings — came to present themselves before the Lord, Satan also came among them.

verses.latin: Cui dixit Dominus: Unde venis? Qui respondens ait: Circuivi terram, et perambulavi eam.
verses.english: The Lord said to him, "Where have you come from?" And Satan answered, "I have traveled throughout the earth, walking to and fro across it."

verses.latin: Dixitque Dominus ad eum: Numquid considerasti servum meum Job, quod non sit similis illi in terra, vir simplex, et rectus, ac timens Deum, et recedens a malo?
verses.english: The Lord then said to him, "Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one like him on earth, a man innocent in his heart and righteous in his deeds, reverent toward God, and always turning away from evil."

verses.latin: Cui respondens Satan, ait: Numquid Job frustra timet Deum?
verses.english: Satan answered the Lord, "Does Job fear God for nothing? Is there no gain for him in it?"

verses.latin: Nonne tu vallasti eum, ac domum ejus, universamque substantiam illius per circuitum? Operibus manuum ejus benedixisti, et possessio ejus crevit in terra.
verses.english: "Have You not hedged him in —protected him — and his house, and all his possessions on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his wealth has increased on the earth.

verses.latin: Sed extende paululum manum tuam, et tange cuncta quæ possidet, nisi in faciem benedixerit tibi.
verses.english: But stretch out Your hand a little and touch all that he possesses, and see if he will not curse You to Your face."

verses.latin: Dixit autem Dominus ad Satan: Ecce universa quæ habet in manu tua sunt: tantum in eum ne extendas manum tuam. Egressusque est Satan a facie Domini.
verses.english: Then the Lord said to Satan, "Behold, all that he has is in your power. Only do not lay a hand on him personally." So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord.

verses.latin: Quadam autem die cum filii et filiæ ejus comederent et biberent vinum in domo fratris sui primogeniti,
verses.english: Now on a certain day, when Job's sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in the house of their firstborn brother,

verses.latin: nuntius venit ad Job, qui diceret: Boves arabant, et asinæ pascebantur juxta eos,
verses.english: a messenger came to Job and said, "The oxen were plowing, and the donkeys were grazing beside them,

verses.latin: et irruerunt Sabei, tuleruntque omnia, et pueros interfecerunt gladio: et evasi ego solus, ut nuntiarem tibi.
verses.english: when the Sabeans raided, took them all, and killed the servants with the sword. I alone have escaped to tell you."

verses.latin: Adhuc loquebatur, et ecce alter veniens, dixit: Ignis Dei cecidit e cælo, et combussit oves, puerosque consumpsit: et evasi ego solus, ut nuntiarem tibi.
verses.english: While he was still speaking, behold, another messenger came and said, "Fire from the sky —sent by God— fell and burned up the sheep, and consumed the servants. I alone have escaped to tell you."

verses.latin: Sed et illo adhuc loquente, alius intravit, et dixit: Chaldæi fecerunt tres turmas, et invaserunt camelos, et tulerunt eos, necnon et pueros interfecerunt gladio: et ego solus evasi, ut nuntiarem tibi.
verses.english: While he was still speaking, another entered and said, "The Chaldeans formed three raiding parties, attacked the camels, and took them. They also killed the servants with the sword. I alone have escaped to tell you."

verses.latin: Adhuc loquebatur, et ecce alius introit, et dicit: Filii tui et filiæ tuæ comedebant, et bibebant vinum in domo fratris sui primogeniti:
verses.english: While he was still speaking, behold, another messenger came in and said, "Your sons and your daughters were eating and drinking wine in the house of their firstborn brother.

verses.latin: et subito ventus vehemens irruit a regione deserti, et concussit quatuor angulos domus, quæ corruens oppressit liberos tuos, et mortui sunt: et ego solus evasi, ut nuntiarem tibi.
verses.english: Then suddenly a violent wind burst in from the desert, struck the four corners of the house, and it collapsed, crushing your children, and they are dead. I alone have escaped to tell you."

verses.latin: Surrexit itaque Job, et scidit vestimenta sua: et tonso capite corruens in terram adoravit,
verses.english: Then Job arose, tore his clothes as a sign of mourning, shaved his head, and falling to the ground, he worshipped.

verses.latin: et dixit: Nudus egressus sum de utero matris meæ, et nudus revertar illuc. Dominus dedit, Dominus abstulit: sicut Domino placuit, ita factum est. Sit nomen Domini benedictum.
verses.english: He said, "I came out naked from my mother's womb, and naked I shall return there, to the earth. The Lord gave, and the Lord has taken away. As it pleased the Lord, so it has happened. May the name of the Lord be blessed."

verses.latin: In omnibus his non peccavit Job labiis suis, neque stultum quid contra Deum locutus est.
verses.english: In all these things, Job did not sin with his lips, nor did he speak anything foolish against God.

verses.latin: Rursum autem, quadam die, cum venissent filii Dei, ut assisterent coram Domino, adfuit inter eos etiam Satan, assistens in conspectu ejus.
verses.english: Again, on a certain day, when God's holy angels came to serve before the Lord in His heavenly court, Satan also came among them, standing in the Lord's presence.

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus ad Satan: Unde venis? Qui respondens ait: Circuivi terram, et perambulavi eam.
verses.english: And the Lord said to Satan, "Where do you come from?" Satan answered, "I have been circling the earth, and I have walked throughout it."

verses.latin: Et ait Dominus ad Satan: Numquid considerasti servum meum Job, quod non sit ei similis in terra, homo simplex et rectus, et timens Deum, et recedens a malo, et adhuc retinens innocentiam? Tu autem commovisti me adversus eum, ut affligerem illum frustra.
verses.english: And the Lord said to Satan, "Have you truly considered My servant Job, that there is no one like him on earth—a simple and upright man, who fears God and turns away from evil? He still holds onto his integrity, even though you provoked Me against him to afflict him without cause."

verses.latin: Cui respondens Satan, ait: Pellem pro pelle, et cuncta quæ habet homo, dabit pro anima sua:
verses.english: Satan answered Him, saying, "Skin for skin! A man will give everything he owns to save his own life."

verses.latin: sed extende paululum manum tuam, et tange os ejus et carnem: et tunc videbis quod benedicat tibi in faciem tuam.
verses.english: "But stretch out Your hand a little bit and strike his bone and his flesh, and then You will see if he curses You to Your face."

verses.latin: Dixit ergo Dominus ad Satan: Ecce in manu tua est, verumtamen animam illius serva.
verses.english: So the Lord said to Satan, "Behold, he is in your power. However, you must spare his life."

verses.latin: Egressus itaque Satan a facie Domini, percussit Job ulcere pessimo, a planta pedis usque ad verticem ejus.
verses.english: So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord and struck Job with painful boils and festering sores, from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.

verses.latin: Qui sedens in sterquilinio, radebat scabra calcarea:
verses.english: Job sat among the ashes and used a broken piece of pottery to scrape his sores.

verses.latin: Dixitque illi uxor sua: Adhuc tu permanes in simplicitate tua? Benedic Deo, et morere.
verses.english: And his wife said to him, "Are you still clinging to your integrity? Bless God and die!"

verses.latin: Qui ait ad illam: Quasi una de stultis mulieribus locuta es: si bona suscepimus de manu Dei, mala quare non suscipiamus? In omnibus his non peccavit Job labiis suis.
verses.english: But Job said to her, "You are speaking like one of the foolish women. If we accept good things from the hand of God, why should we not also accept difficult things?" In all these trials, Job did not sin with his lips.

verses.latin: Igitur audientes tres amici Job omne malum, quod accidisset ei, venerunt singuli de loco suo, Eliphaz Themanites, et Baldad Suhites, et Sophar Naamathites. Condixerant enim ut pariter venientes visitarent eum, et consolarentur.
verses.english: Now, when Job's three friends heard about all the evil that had come upon him, they came, each from his own place: Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite. They had agreed to come together to visit him and to console him.

verses.latin: Et cum elevassent procul oculos suos, non cognoverunt eum: et exclamantes ploraverunt, scissisque vestibus sparserunt pulverem super caput suum in cælum.
verses.english: And when they lifted their eyes from a distance, they did not recognize him because of his disfigurement. They cried out and wept, tearing their garments, and they sprinkled dust over their heads toward the sky as a sign of their deep grief.

verses.latin: Et sederunt cum eo in terra septem diebus et septem noctibus, et nemo loquebatur ei verbum: videbant enim dolorem ejus vehementem esse.
verses.english: And they sat with him on the ground for seven days and seven nights, and no one spoke a word to him, for they saw that his suffering was very intense.

verses.latin: Post hæc aperuit Job os suum, et maledixit diei suæ,
verses.english: After all this, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day he was born.

verses.latin: et locutus est:
verses.english: And he spoke these words:

verses.latin: Pereat dies in qua natus sum, et nox in qua dictum est: Conceptus est homo.
verses.english: "Let the day perish on which I was born, and the night in which it was announced: 'A man has been conceived!'"

verses.latin: Dies illa vertatur in tenebras, non requirat eam Deus desuper, et non illustretur lumine.
verses.english: "Let that day turn into darkness. Let God above not seek it out, and let no light illuminate it."

verses.latin: Obscurent eum tenebræ et umbra mortis, occupet eum caligo, et involvatur amaritudine.
verses.english: "Let deep darkness and the shadow of death obscure that day. Let a thick cloud settle upon it, and let it be enveloped in bitterness."

verses.latin: Noctem illam tenebrosus turbo possideat, non commisceatur diebus anni, nec numeretur in mensibus.
verses.english: "Let a dark storm seize that night. Let it not be counted among the days of the year, nor included in the number of the months."

verses.latin: Sit nox illa solitaria, nec laudabilis in numero mensium.
verses.english: "Let that night be solitary and not worthy of praise among the number of the months."

verses.latin: Maledicant ei qui maledicunt diei, qui parati sunt suscitare leviathan.
verses.english: "Let those who curse the day curse it—those sorcerers who are ready to rouse Leviathan."

verses.latin: Obtenebrentur stellæ caligine ejus: expectet lucem, et non videat, nec ortum surgentis aurorae.
verses.english: "Let its stars be darkened by its gloom. Let it wait for light but not see it, nor the rising of the dawn."

verses.latin: Quia non conclusit ostia ventris, unde exivi, nec abstulit mala ab oculis meis.
verses.english: "Because it did not close the doors of the womb from which I came, nor did it hide trouble from my eyes."

verses.latin: Quare non in vulva mortuus sum? egressus de utero non statim perii?
verses.english: "Why did I not die in the womb? Why did I not perish as soon as I came out of the belly?"

verses.latin: Quare exceptus genibus? cur lactatus uberibus?
verses.english: "Why was I received upon knees? Why was I nursed at breasts?"

verses.latin: Nunc enim dormiens silerem, et somno reparato quiescerem:
verses.english: "For now, I would lie down and be silent. I would sleep and be at peace, restored by rest."

verses.latin: Cum regibus et consulibus terræ, qui ædificant sibi solitudines:
verses.english: "With kings and counselors of the earth, who built desolate places and monuments for themselves."

verses.latin: Aut cum principibus qui possident aurum, et replent domos suas argento:
verses.english: "Or with princes who possessed gold and filled their houses with silver."

verses.latin: Aut sicut abortivum absconditum non subsisterem, vel qui concepti non viderunt lucem.
verses.english: "Or like a hidden, stillborn child, I would not exist; or like those who were conceived but never saw the light of day."

verses.latin: Ibi impii cessaverunt a tumultu, et requieverunt fessi robore.
verses.english: "There, in that place of rest, the wicked cease from their raging, and those who were exhausted in strength find peace."

verses.latin: Et quondam vincti pariter, absque ulla molestia, non audierunt vocem exactoris.
verses.english: "And those who were once bound together, without any trouble, no longer hear the voice of the oppressor."

verses.latin: Parvus et magnus ibi sunt, et servus a domino liber.
verses.english: "The small and the great are there alike, and the slave is free from his master."

verses.latin: Quare datum est misero lumen, et vita his qui in amaritudine animæ sunt?
verses.english: "Why is light given to the miserable, and life to those who are bitter in spirit?"

verses.latin: Qui expectant mortem, et non venit, et effodiunt quasi thesauros;
verses.english: "Who long for death, but it does not come, and they search for it more eagerly than for hidden treasures."

verses.latin: gaudentque vehementer cum invenerint sepulchrum.
verses.english: "They rejoice greatly when they find the grave."

verses.latin: Homo cujus via est abscondita, et circumdedit eum Deus tenebris.
verses.english: "Why is life given to a man whose path is hidden, and whom God has surrounded with darkness?"

verses.latin: Antequam comedam, suspiro, et velut inundantes aquæ sic rugitus meus.
verses.english: "Before I eat, I sigh, and my groans pour out like flowing waters."

verses.latin: Quia timor quem timebam, evenit mihi: et quod verebar, accidit.
verses.english: "For the very fear that I feared has come upon me, and what I dreaded has happened."

verses.latin: Nonne dissimulavi? nec tacui? nec quievi? et venit super me ira.
verses.english: "I did not pretend to be calm, nor was I silent, nor did I find rest; yet, anger and suffering still came upon me."

verses.latin: Respondens autem Eliphaz Themanites, dixit:
verses.english: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:

verses.latin: Post haec aperuit Job os suum, et maledixit diei suo.
verses.english: After everything that had happened, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.

verses.latin: Et locutus est Job, et dixit:
verses.english: Then Job spoke, and said:

verses.latin: Pereat dies in qua natus sum, et nox in qua dictum est: Conceptus est homo.
verses.english: Let the day I was born completely vanish. And let the night also vanish when it was announced: 'A man has been conceived!'

verses.latin: Dies ille vertatur in tenebras, non requirat eum Deus desuper, et non illustretur lumine.
verses.english: May that day turn into total darkness. May God above not look upon it or care about it, and may it never be brightened by any light.

verses.latin: Obscurent illum tenebrae, et umbra mortis; occupet eum caligo, et involvatur amaritudine.
verses.english: Let shadows and the deepest gloom of death obscure it. Let thick fog and bitterness completely overwhelm it.

verses.latin: Noctem illam tenebrosus turbo possideat, non computetur in diebus anni, nec numeretur in mensibus.
verses.english: Let a dark storm claim that night as its own. May it not be counted among the days of the year, nor included in the months.

verses.latin: Sit nox illa solitaria, nec laudabilis in laudibus.
verses.english: May that night be utterly desolate and solitary. May it never be a night for rejoicing or praise.

verses.latin: Maledicant ei qui maledicunt diei, qui parati sunt suscitare Leviathan.
verses.english: Let those who curse days, those who are ready to rouse the great sea monster Leviathan, curse that night.

verses.latin: Obscurentur stellae caligine ejus; expectet lucem, et non videat, nec ortum surgentis aurorae.
verses.english: Let its morning stars be obscured by its gloom. May it long for light but never see it, nor the dawning of the rising sun.

verses.latin: Quia non conclusit ostia ventris qui portavit me, nec abstulit mala ab oculis meis.
verses.english: Because that night did not seal the doors of the womb that carried me, nor did it keep sorrow and misfortune from my eyes.

verses.latin: Quare non in vulva mortuus sum? egressus de ventre non statim perii?
verses.english: Why was I not stillborn in the womb? Why did I not perish immediately upon leaving my mother's body?

verses.latin: Quare exceptus genibus? cur lactatus uberibus?
verses.english: Why was I received upon knees? Why was I nursed at the breast?

verses.latin: Nunc enim dormiens silerem, et somno reparatus, quietus essem:
verses.english: For now, I would be lying in silent sleep. I would be refreshed by slumber, and I would be at peace.

verses.latin: cum regibus et consulibus terrae, qui aedificant sibi solitudines:
verses.english: I would be at rest with kings and the great leaders of the earth, who built desolate ruins for themselves as tombs.

verses.latin: aut cum principibus, qui possident aurum, et replent domos suas argento:
verses.english: Or with princes who possessed gold and filled their houses with silver, all now in their tombs.

verses.latin: aut sicut abortivum absconditum, non subsisterem, vel qui concepti non viderunt lucem.
verses.english: Or, like a hidden miscarriage, I would not even exist. I would be like infants who were conceived but never saw the light of day.

verses.latin: Ibi impii cessaverunt a tumultu, et requieverunt fessi robore.
verses.english: In the grave, the wicked cease from their raging tumult, and those who are exhausted from their strength finally rest.

verses.latin: Et quondam vincti pariter absque molestia, non audierunt vocem exactoris.
verses.english: There, even prisoners who were once bound lie together without any trouble. They do not hear the voice of their taskmaster anymore.

verses.latin: Parvus et magnus ibi sunt, et servus liber a domino suo.
verses.english: Both the insignificant and the powerful are there, and the servant is finally free from his master.

verses.latin: Quare datum est misero lumen, et vita his qui in amaritudine animae sunt?
verses.english: Why is light given to the miserable? And why is life given to those who live in such bitterness of soul?

verses.latin: Qui expectant mortem, et non venit, et effodiunt quasi thesauros;
verses.english: They long for death, but it does not come. They search for it more eagerly than for hidden treasures.

verses.latin: gaudentque vehementer cum invenerint sepulchrum.
verses.english: They rejoice exceedingly when they finally find the grave.

verses.latin: Homo cujus via est abscondita, et circumdedit eum Deus tenebris?
verses.english: Why is life given to a man whose path is hidden, a man whom God has surrounded with darkness and despair?

verses.latin: Antequam comedam, suspiro; et quasi inundantes aquae, sic rugitus meus.
verses.english: Before I eat, I sigh; and my groans pour out like overflowing waters.

verses.latin: Quia timor quem timebam evenit mihi, et quod verebar accidit.
verses.english: For the very terror I feared has come upon me, and what I dreaded has happened.

verses.latin: Non sum perturbatus, nec quievi, neque acquievi, et venit super me iracundia.
verses.english: I have not found peace, nor quiet, nor rest. Instead, only torment and anger have come upon me.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Eliphaz Themanites, dixit:
verses.english: But Eliphaz, the man from Teman, spoke, responding to what Job had said:

verses.latin: Si coeperimus loqui tibi, forsan moleste feres: sed conceptum sermonem tenere quis poterit?
verses.english: If we were to begin speaking to you, perhaps you would take it badly. But who can possibly hold back the words that have formed in his mind?

verses.latin: Ecce tu erudisti plurimos, et manus lassas roborasti.
verses.english: Look, you yourself have instructed many people, and you have given strength to those whose hands were weak.

verses.latin: Vacillantes confirmaverunt sermones tui, et genua trementia confortasti.
verses.english: Your words have stabilized those who were wavering, and you have strengthened trembling knees.

verses.latin: Nunc autem venit super te plaga, et defecisti: tetigit te, et conturbatus es.
verses.english: But now a calamity has come upon you, and you have become weak. It has touched you, and you are deeply troubled.

verses.latin: Nonne timor tuus, providentia tua est: et spes tua, perfectio viarum tuarum?
verses.english: Was not your reverence for God your confidence? And your hope, the blamelessness of your ways?

verses.latin: Recole, obsecro te, quis innocens periit? aut quando recti subversi sunt?
verses.english: Please remember this: Has any innocent person ever perished? Or when have the upright ever been destroyed?

verses.latin: Quin potius vidi eos qui operantur iniquitatem, et seminant dolores, et metunt eos.
verses.english: On the contrary, I have seen that those who practice wickedness, and sow seeds of trouble, eventually reap those same troubles.

verses.latin: Flante Deo perisse, et spiritu iræ ejus consumptos.
verses.english: They perish by the very breath of God, and they are consumed by the spirit of His anger.

verses.latin: Rugitus leonis, et vox leaenae, et dentium catulorum leonum contrita sunt.
verses.english: The roaring of the lion, and the cry of the lioness, and the teeth of the young lions, are all broken.

verses.latin: Tigris periit eo quod non haberet praedam, et catuli leonis dissipati sunt.
verses.english: The tiger perishes because it has no prey, and the young lions are scattered.

verses.latin: Porro ad me furtim verbum factum est, et quasi furta suscepit auris mea susurrum ejus.
verses.english: Moreover, a word was secretly revealed to me, and my ear caught its whisper as if by stealth.

verses.latin: In horrore visionis nocturnæ, quando solet sopor occupare homines,
verses.english: In the terror of a vision by night, when deep sleep usually overtakes people,

verses.latin: pavor tenuit me, et tremor, et omnia ossa mea perterrita sunt.
verses.english: fear and trembling seized me, and all my bones were terrified.

verses.latin: Et cum spiritus, me præsente, transiret, inhorruerunt pili carnis meæ.
verses.english: And when a spirit passed right before me, the hairs of my body stood on end.

verses.latin: Stetit quidam, cujus faciem ignorabam: imago tantum ante oculos meos, et vocem quasi auræ lenis audivi.
verses.english: Someone stood there, whose face I could not recognize; only an outline was before my eyes, and then I heard a voice like a soft whisper.

verses.latin: Numquid homo, Dei comparatione, justificabitur? aut super factorem suum mundus erit vir?
verses.english: Can a mortal man be considered righteous in comparison with God? Or can a man be pure before his Maker?

verses.latin: Ecce qui serviunt ei, non sunt stabiles: et in Angelis suis reperit pravitatem.
verses.english: Look, those who serve Him are not steadfast, and He finds fault even in His Angels.

verses.latin: Quanto magis hi qui habitant domos luteas, terrenam habentes fundamentum, consumentur velut a tinea?
verses.english: How much more, then, will those who live in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the earth, be consumed like a moth?

verses.latin: De mane usque ad vesperam succiduntur: et quia nemo intelligit, in æternum pereunt.
verses.english: From morning until evening, they are cut down. And because no one understands their plight, they perish forever.

verses.latin: Usque ad semetipsos recident eos qui simul habitabant in eis: moriuntur, et non in sapientia.
verses.english: Those who lived with them are utterly cut off from their very being; they die, and not in wisdom.

verses.latin: Clama, si est qui tibi respondeat, et ad aliquem sanctorum convertere.
verses.english: Cry out, if there is anyone who will answer you! And turn to any of the holy ones for help.

verses.latin: Vere iram interficit parvulum, et invidia occidit hominem.
verses.english: Truly, wrath slays the foolish, and resentment kills a man.

verses.latin: Ego vidi insipientem radices ponentem, et statim maledixi pulchritudini ejus.
verses.english: I myself have seen a foolish man taking root, but immediately I cursed his prosperity.

verses.latin: Fiat habitaculum ejus sine liberis, et exspolientur filii ejus.
verses.english: May his home be without children, and may his children be plundered.

verses.latin: Lactent filii ejus egestatem, et expellantur de domibus suis.
verses.english: May his children suckle on poverty, and may they be driven out of their homes.

verses.latin: Irrideat fames divitias ejus, et detrahat ei armatum.
verses.english: May hunger mock his riches, and may an armed man drag him away.

verses.latin: Auferat areola ejus fructum ejus, et comedat sitiens facultates ejus.
verses.english: May his own small field not yield its fruit, and may the thirsty consume his possessions.

verses.latin: Non egreditur de terra iniquitas, et de humo non oritur dolor.
verses.english: Indeed, wickedness does not spring up from the earth, and sorrow does not grow out of the ground.

verses.latin: Homo ad laborem nascitur, et avis ad volatum.
verses.english: Man is born for labor, just as a bird is born for flight.

verses.latin: Quam ob rem ego deprecabor Dominum, et ad Deum ponam sermonem meum.
verses.english: For this reason, I will call upon the Lord, and I will present my case to God.

verses.latin: Qui facit magna et inscrutabilia, et mirabilia absque numero:
verses.english: He is the One who does great and unsearchable things, and wonders beyond counting.

verses.latin: Qui dat pluviam super faciem terræ, et irrigat aquis universa.
verses.english: He is the One who sends rain upon the face of the earth, and waters all living things with moisture.

verses.latin: Qui ponit humiles in sublime, et mœrentes erigit sospitate.
verses.english: He is the One who sets the humble on high, and lifts up those who mourn into security and wellbeing.

verses.latin: Qui dissipat cogitationes malignorum, ne possint implere os eorum.
verses.english: He is the One who thwarts the schemes of the malicious, so that they cannot achieve their full intent.

verses.latin: Qui apprehendit sapientes in astutia eorum, et consilium perversorum dissipat.
verses.english: He is the One who catches the cunning in their own craftiness, and scatters the plans of the perverse.

verses.latin: Confitentur die, et non est lux, et quasi in nocte palpant in meridie.
verses.english: They grope about in daylight, yet there is no light for them; they stumble at noon as if in the deepest night.

verses.latin: Et salvat a gladio oris eorum, et de manu violenti pauperem.
verses.english: He saves the poor from the sharp words of their mouths, and from the hand of the violent man.

verses.latin: Et erit pauperi spes, et iniquitas contrahet os suum.
verses.english: And so there will be hope for the poor, and wickedness will be silenced.

verses.latin: Beatus homo quem corripit Deus: increpationem ergo Altissimi ne reprobes.
verses.english: Blessed is the man whom God corrects. Therefore, do not reject the rebuke of the Most High.

verses.latin: Voca ergo si est qui tibi respondeat, et ad aliquem sanctorum convertere.
verses.english: Go ahead and call out, if there is anyone at all who will answer your pleas, or if any of the holy ones—be they angels or righteous men—will agree with you.

verses.latin: Vere iram occidit stultum, et invidia interficit parvulum.
verses.english: Truly, uncontrolled anger destroys the foolish man, and envy is deadly to the simple-minded.

verses.latin: Ego vidi stultum firma radice, et maledixi statim habitationi ejus.
verses.english: I have seen a foolish man firmly established, and I immediately pronounced a curse upon his home.

verses.latin: Erunt procul a salute filii ejus, et conterentur in porta, nec erit qui eruat.
verses.english: His children will be far from any help or safety, and they will be crushed in the city gate—the place of judgment—with no one to rescue them.

verses.latin: Cujus messem famelicus comedet, et ipse eam de spinis rapiet, et sitiens hauriet divitias ejus.
verses.english: The hungry will eat his harvest, even snatching it from among thorns, and the thirsty will consume all his wealth.

verses.latin: Nihil in terra sine causa fit, et de humo non oritur dolor.
verses.english: Nothing happens on earth without a reason, and pain does not simply arise from the ground without a cause, as if it were a plant.

verses.latin: Homo ad laborem nascitur, et avis ad volatum.
verses.english: For man is born to toil, just as a bird is born to fly.

verses.latin: Quam ob rem ego deprecabor Dominum, et ad Deum ponam sermonem meum:
verses.english: Because of this truth, I will appeal to the Lord, and I will present my case before God.

verses.latin: Qui facit magna et inscrutabilia, et mirabilia absque numero:
verses.english: He is the One who does great and unsearchable things, wonders beyond all counting.

verses.latin: Qui dat pluviam super faciem terrae, et rigat aquis universa.
verses.english: He is the One who sends rain upon the face of the land and waters all things with refreshing water.

verses.latin: Qui ponit humiles in sublime, et mærentes erigit sospitate.
verses.english: He is the One who sets the humble in high places, and raises those who mourn to a state of security and well-being.

verses.latin: Qui dissipat cogitationes malignorum, ne possint implere os suum.
verses.english: He is the One who frustrates the plans of malicious men, so that they cannot achieve their desires or speak boastfully of their success.

verses.latin: Qui apprehendit sapientes in astutia eorum, et consilium perversorum dissipat.
verses.english: He is the One who traps the cunning in their own craftiness, and He brings to nothing the plans of the twisted-minded.

verses.latin: Per diem incurrent tenebras, et quasi in nocte sic palpabunt in meridie.
verses.english: During the day, they will encounter darkness, and even at high noon, they will grope about as if it were the dead of night.

verses.latin: Sed salvabit in manu mortis pauperem, et de manu violenti liberabit inopem.
verses.english: But He will save the poor from the grasp of death, and He will deliver the needy from the hand of the violent oppressor.

verses.latin: Et erit pauperi spes, iniquitas vero operiet os suum.
verses.english: And so there will be hope for the poor, while injustice will be silenced.

verses.latin: Beatus homo qui corripitur a Deo: increpationes ergo Altissimi ne reprobes.
verses.english: Blessed is the man whom God corrects; therefore, do not despise the discipline of the Most High God.

verses.latin: Quia ipse vulnerat, et medetur: percutit, et manus ejus sanabunt.
verses.english: For He Himself inflicts the wound, and then He heals it; He strikes, and His hands alone bring restoration.

verses.latin: In sex tribulationibus liberabit te, et in septima non tanget te malum.
verses.english: Through six troubles, He will deliver you, and in the seventh, no evil will even touch you.

verses.latin: In fame liberabit te de morte, et in bello de manu gladii.
verses.english: In times of famine, He will deliver you from death itself, and in war, He will save you from the power of the sword.

verses.latin: Ab flagello linguae absconderis, et non timebis vastitatem cum venerit.
verses.english: You will be hidden from the scourge of slanderous tongues, and you will not fear devastation when it arrives.

verses.latin: In vastitate et fame ridebis: et bestias terrae non formidabis.
verses.english: You will laugh at devastation and famine, and you will not dread the wild beasts of the land.

verses.latin: Sed cum lapidibus regionum pactum tuum, et bestiae terrae pacificae erunt tibi.
verses.english: For you will have a covenant relationship even with the stones of the field, and the wild animals of the earth will be at peace with you.

verses.latin: Et scies quod pax sit tabernaculo tuo: et visitans speciem tuam non peccabis.
verses.english: And you will know that peace resides in your dwelling place, and when you inspect your flock, you will find nothing missing or amiss.

verses.latin: Et scies quoniam multiplex erit semen tuum, et progenies tua quasi herba terrae.
verses.english: And you will know that your descendants will be numerous, and your offspring like the abundant grass of the earth.

verses.latin: Ingredieris in tumulum in maturitate, sicut reponitur acervus fœni in tempore suo.
verses.english: You will come to your grave in ripe old age, just as a shock of grain is gathered in its proper season.

verses.latin: Ecce hoc ut investigavimus, ita est: quod auditum est, scribe tibi.
verses.english: Behold, this is what we have diligently researched, and it is truly so: what you have heard, write it down and keep it for yourself.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Job, dixit :
verses.english: But Job responded and said:

verses.latin: Utinam appenderentur peccata mea, quibus iram merui, et calamitas quam patio in statera simul!
verses.english: Oh, if only my wrongdoing could be weighed on a scale, that wrongdoing for which I have deserved God’s wrath, and if only the suffering I am enduring could be weighed alongside it!

verses.latin: Quasi arena maris haec gravior appareret : unde et verba mea dolore sunt plena.
verses.english: My suffering would appear heavier than the sand of the sea: that is why my words are full of pain.

verses.latin: Quia sagittae Domini in me sunt, quarum indignatio ebibit spiritum meum, et terrores Domini militant contra me.
verses.english: For the arrows of the Lord are within me, and His indignation has consumed my spirit, and the terrors sent by the Lord wage war against me.

verses.latin: Numquid rugiet onager cum habuerit herbam? aut mugiet bos cum ante praesepe plenum steterit?
verses.english: Does the wild donkey bray when it has grass? Or does the ox bellow when it stands before a full manger?

verses.latin: Aut poterit comedi insulsum, quod sale non fuerit conditum? aut potest amara res, cum gustata fuerit, absque fastidio devorari?
verses.english: Can something tasteless be eaten, something not seasoned with salt? Can a bitter thing be swallowed without disgust, once it has been tasted?

verses.latin: Quae prius tangere nolebat anima mea, nunc propter angustiam comedere cogitur.
verses.english: Things which my soul previously refused to touch, now I am forced to eat because of my distress.

verses.latin: Quis det ut veniat ad me petitio mea, et quod expecto, tribuat mihi Deus?
verses.english: Who will grant that my request might come to me, and that God might grant me what I await?

verses.latin: Et ut incipiat Deus conterere me, ut relaxet manum suam, et secet me?
verses.english: And that God might begin to crush me, that He might release His hand and cut me off?

verses.latin: Et haec mihi sit consolatio, ut affligens me dolore, non parcat, nec contradicam sermonibus Sancti.
verses.english: And let this be my consolation: that in afflicting me with pain, He may not spare me, nor will I contradict the words of the Holy One.

verses.latin: Quae est enim fortitudo mea ut sustineam? aut quis finis meus ut patienter agam?
verses.english: For what strength do I have to endure this? Or what end do I have to act with patience?

verses.latin: Numquid fortitudo lapidum fortitudo mea? aut caro mea aenea est?
verses.english: Is my strength the strength of stones? Or is my flesh made of bronze?

verses.latin: Nec, re vera, auxilium mihi est in me, et facultas quoque mea recessit a me.
verses.english: Truly, there is no help for me within myself, and even my capability has departed from me.

verses.latin: Qui aufert ab amico suo misericordiam, timorem Domini derelinquit.
verses.english: He who withholds mercy from his friend abandons the fear of the Lord.

verses.latin: Fratres mei transierunt me sicut torrens, qui currit in vallibus.
verses.english: My brothers have deceived me like a wadi, a seasonal stream that flows through valleys.

verses.latin: Qui tument caligine, et nives occultantur in eis.
verses.english: They swell with dark waters from the melting snow, where snow is hidden within them.

verses.latin: In tempore quo fuerint dissipati, arescunt, et cum incaluerit, evanuerunt de loco suo.
verses.english: In the time when they disperse their waters, they dry up, and when the heat comes, they vanish from their place.

verses.latin: Invioverunt semitae gressus eorum, divertunt ad nihilum, et pereunt.
verses.english: Their paths twist into crooked ways, they turn off into nothingness, and they perish.

verses.latin: Considerate semitas Theman, et itinera Saba, et expectate.
verses.english: The caravans from Tema looked for their paths, and the travelers from Sheba waited expectantly for water.

verses.latin: Confusi sunt, quia speraverunt : venerunt illuc, et pudore cooperti sunt.
verses.english: They were confused and ashamed because they had hoped; they came to the wadi’s location and were covered with disappointment.

verses.latin: Nunc vos ad nihilum redacti estis : videntes plagam meam, pertimescitis.
verses.english: Now you have become nothing to me; seeing my affliction, you are terrified.

verses.latin: Numquid dixi : Afferte mihi, et de substantia vestra dotate me?
verses.english: Have I ever said: 'Bring something to me, and endow me from your possessions?'

verses.latin: Aut liberate me de manu inimici, et de manu fortium redimite me?
verses.english: Or: 'Deliver me from the hand of my enemy, and redeem me from the hand of the powerful?'

verses.latin: Docete me, et ego tacebo : et si quid forte ignoravi, instruite me.
verses.english: Teach me, and I will be silent; and if by chance I have been ignorant of anything, instruct me.

verses.latin: Quare detraxistis sermonibus veritatis, cum e vobis nullus sit qui possit arguere?
verses.english: Why have you undermined the words of truth, when among you there is no one who can argue a point effectively?

verses.latin: Ad increpandum tantum eloquia concinnatis, et in ventum verba profertis.
verses.english: Do you only prepare speeches for rebuking, and do you utter words into the wind?

verses.latin: Super pupillum irruitis, et amicum vestrum subvertitis.
verses.english: You even attack an orphan, and you overthrow your friend.

verses.latin: Revertimini, et estote : videbo an mentiar.
verses.english: Turn back, and consider; I will see if I lie.

verses.latin: Respondete saltem, ne iniquitas sit : et loquentes justum recognoscite.
verses.english: At least respond, lest there be iniquity; and acknowledge what is just when you speak.

verses.latin: Estne in lingua mea iniquitas? an in sensu meo non potest judicari aspera?
verses.english: Is there iniquity on my tongue? Or can it not be discerned if there is harshness in my understanding?

verses.latin: Militiam hominis super terram, et sicut dies mercenarii dies ejus.
verses.english: Is not the life of man on earth a perpetual struggle, like a soldier's deployment? And are not his days exactly like the days of a hired worker, who anxiously waits for the end of his shift and his payment?

verses.latin: Sicut servus desiderat umbram, et sicut mercenarius præstolatur finem operis sui:
verses.english: Just as a slave desires the shade from the scorching sun, and just as a hired hand longs for the completion of his work,

verses.latin: Sic et ego habui menses vacuos, et noctes laboriosas enumeravi mihi.
verses.english: So too have I endured empty months without relief, and I have counted for myself many nights of painful labor and suffering.

verses.latin: Si dormiero, dicam: Quando consurgam? et rursum exspectabo vesperam, et replebor doloribus.
verses.english: If I try to sleep, I ask myself, 'When will I rise again?' And then I anxiously await the evening, only to be filled with even more sorrows.

verses.latin: Induta est caro mea putredine, et sordibus pulveris, pellis mea arescit et tabescit.
verses.english: My flesh is covered with putrefaction and with filthy dust, as my skin becomes dry and wastes away.

verses.latin: Dies mei velocius transierunt quam a texente tela succiditur, et consumpti sunt absque ulla spe.
verses.english: My days have passed more swiftly than a weaver’s shuttle is cut from the loom, and they are consumed without any hope for betterment.

verses.latin: Memento quia ventus est vita mea, et non revertetur oculus meus ut videat bona.
verses.english: Remember, O God, that my life is but a fleeting breath of wind, and my eyes will never return to see any good thing.

verses.latin: Nec aspiciet me visus hominis, oculi tui quærent me, et non subsistam.
verses.english: Nor will the gaze of any human see me again. Your eyes will search for me, but I will no longer exist.

verses.latin: Sicut nubes consumitur et pertransit, sic qui descenderit ad inferos non ascendet.
verses.english: Just as a cloud is consumed and passes away, so too will he who descends to the underworld never ascend back to this life.

verses.latin: Nec revertetur ultra in domum suam, nec cognoscet eum amplius locus ejus.
verses.english: He will not return again to his own house, nor will his place on earth know him any longer.

verses.latin: Quapropter et ego non parcam ori meo, loquar in tribulatione spiritus mei, confabulabor cum amaritudine animæ meæ.
verses.english: Therefore, I will not hold back my words. I will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I will pour out my bitterness of soul.

verses.latin: Numquid mare ego sum, aut cetus, ut circumdes me carcere?
verses.english: Am I the tumultuous sea, or a monstrous sea creature, that You should confine me with such a barrier and restrain me?

verses.latin: Si dixero: Consolabitur me lectus meus, relevabor loquens mecum in stratu meo:
verses.english: If I say, 'My bed will comfort me, I will find relief speaking to myself on my couch and finding peace there,'

verses.latin: Terrificabis me per somnia, et per visiones horrore concuties.
verses.english: You, O God, terrorize me through dreams, and You shake me with horror through terrifying visions.

verses.latin: Unde elegit anima mea suspendium, et mortem magis quam vivere.
verses.english: Because of this, my soul has chosen strangulation, and death rather than to continue living in such torment.

verses.latin: Desperavi, nec ultra vivere volo: parce mihi, nihil enim sunt dies mei.
verses.english: I have despaired, and I no longer wish to live. Leave me alone, for my days are nothing of value.

verses.latin: Quid est homo, quia magnificas eum? aut quid apponis erga eum cor tuum?
verses.english: What is man, that You should magnify him with such attention? Or why do You set Your heart upon him with such scrutiny?

verses.latin: Visitas eum diluculo, et subito probas illum?
verses.english: You visit him every morning, and You test him suddenly, without warning?

verses.latin: Usquequo non parcis mihi, nec dimittis me ut glutiam salivam meam?
verses.english: How long will You not spare me, nor leave me alone long enough to even swallow my saliva and catch my breath?

verses.latin: Peccavi, quid faciam tibi, o custos hominum? quare posuisti me contrarium tibi, et factus sum mihimetipsi gravis?
verses.english: I have sinned; what can I do to You, O Guardian of men? Why have You made me Your target, and why have I become a burden to myself?

verses.latin: Cur non tollis peccatum meum, et quare non auferas iniquitatem meam? ecce nunc in pulvere dormiam, et si mane me quæsieris, non subsistam.
verses.english: Why do You not take away my sin? And why do You not remove my iniquity? For behold, now I will sleep in the dust, and if You search for me in the morning, I will no longer be there.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Baldad Suhites, dixit:
verses.english: And then Bildad the Shuhite replied and said:

verses.latin: Usquequo loqueris talia, et spiritus oris tui quasi turbo, et procellis similis?
verses.english: How long will you speak such things? The words coming from your mouth are like a strong, destructive whirlwind, like a storm!

verses.latin: Numquid Deus supplantat judicium? aut Omnipotens subvertit justitiam?
verses.english: Does God pervert justice? Or does the Almighty ever twist what is right?

verses.latin: Si filii tui peccaverunt ei, et dimisit eos in manu iniquitatis suae:
verses.english: If your sons sinned against Him, then He surely delivered them over to the consequences of their sin.

verses.latin: Tu autem si diluculo consurrexeris ad Deum, et Omnipotentem fueris deprecatus:
verses.english: But if you would sincerely seek God early in the morning, and implore the Almighty for mercy:

verses.latin: si mundus et rectus fueris, statim evigilabit ad te, et pacabiles reddet sedes justitiae tuae:
verses.english: if you are pure and upright, then He would immediately awaken to your plight, and restore the peaceful dwelling of your righteousness.

verses.latin: et licet parvus fueris principio, in novissimis multiplicabitur vehementer.
verses.english: And even if your beginnings were humble, in the end, your prosperity will be greatly multiplied.

verses.latin: Interroga enim generationem pristinam, et diligenter investiga patrum memoriam:
verses.english: For inquire of the generations of old, and diligently examine the wisdom passed down by the fathers:

verses.latin: hesterni quippe sumus, et nescimus, quoniam sicut umbra dies nostri sunt super terram.
verses.english: For we are only of yesterday, and know nothing, because our days on earth are like a passing shadow.

verses.latin: Nonne ipsi docebunt te, et loquentur tibi, et de corde suo proferent eloquia?
verses.english: Will they not themselves teach you, and speak to you their wisdom? And from their hearts bring forth wise sayings?

verses.latin: Numquid vivere potest papyrus absque humiditate? aut inlaqueata germinare?
verses.english: Can papyrus grow tall without water? Or can reeds flourish without marshy ground?

verses.latin: Adhuc in flore est, nec siccatur, nec herba succiditur, et arescit ante omnes herbas.
verses.english: Even while still in its bloom, before it can dry out—before any plant can be cut—it withers away sooner than all other plants.

verses.latin: Sic viae sunt omnium qui obliviscuntur Dei, et spes hypocritae peribit:
verses.english: Such is the fate of all who forget God, and the hope of the godless will perish.

verses.latin: cui frustrata est quasi rete spes ejus, et sicut tela aranearum fiducia ejus.
verses.english: Whose confidence is like a fragile net, and whose trust is like a spider's web.

verses.latin: Innitetur domui suae, et non stabit: fulciet illam, et non surget.
verses.english: He leans on his house, but it will not stand; he props it up, but it will not hold firm.

verses.latin: Humidus videtur ante quam veniat sol, et in horto ejus rami ejus pullulant:
verses.english: He seems fresh and green before the sun comes, and his branches sprout vigorously in his garden;

verses.latin: super acervum lapidum radices ejus dilatantur, et inter lapides morantur.
verses.english: his roots spread out over a heap of stones, and entwine themselves among the rocks.

verses.latin: Si comederit eum de loco suo, et negaverit eum: Non novi te.
verses.english: If he is uprooted from his place, then the place itself will deny him, saying, 'I do not know you!'

verses.latin: Haec est laetitia viae ejus: et de terra ejus alter orietur.
verses.english: Behold, such is the fleeting joy of his existence; and from his very ground, another will arise.

verses.latin: Non enim projiciet Deus perfectum, nec manum adjuvabit malorum.
verses.english: For God will not reject a blameless person, nor will He uphold the hand of evildoers.

verses.latin: Usque dum impleat risu os tuum, et labia tua jubilo.
verses.english: Until He fills your mouth with laughter, and your lips with shouts of joy.

verses.latin: Qui oderunt te, induentur confusione: et tabernaculum impiorum non subsistet.
verses.english: Those who hate you will be clothed with shame, and the dwelling of the impious will cease to exist.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Job, ait:
verses.english: Job then answered and said:

verses.latin: Vere scio quod ita sit, et quod non justificetur homo comparatus Deo.
verses.english: Truly, I know that this is the truth—no mortal man can be justified when compared to God.

verses.latin: Si voluerit contendere cum eo, non poterit ei respondere unum pro mille.
verses.english: If God wishes to argue against a man, the man will not be able to answer even one in a thousand points God raises.

verses.latin: Sapiens corde est, et fortis robore: quis restitit ei, et pacem habuit?
verses.english: God is wise in heart, and mighty in strength. Who has ever resisted Him and found peace afterward?

verses.latin: Qui transtulit montes, et nescierunt hi quos subvertit in furore suo.
verses.english: He is the One who moves mountains, and those whom He overturns in His fury do not even perceive it happening.

verses.latin: Qui commovet terram de loco suo, et columnæ ejus contremiscunt.
verses.english: He is the One who shakes the earth from its foundations, and its very pillars tremble.

verses.latin: Qui præcipit soli, et non oritur: et signat stellas quasi sub manu sua.
verses.english: He commands the sun, and it does not rise. He seals up the stars as if they are under His control.

verses.latin: Qui extendit cælos solus, et graditur super fluctus maris.
verses.english: He alone spreads out the universe, and He walks upon the waves of the sea.

verses.latin: Qui facit Arcturum, et Orionem, et Hyadas, et interiora austri.
verses.english: He made the constellations Arcturus, Orion, and the Hyades, and also the hidden southern constellations.

verses.latin: Qui facit magna et incomprehensibilia, et mirabilia quorum non est numerus.
verses.english: He performs great deeds that cannot be understood, and wonders that are beyond counting.

verses.latin: Si superveniat ad me, non videbo: si prætereat, non intelligam.
verses.english: If He comes to me, I will not see Him. If He passes by, I will not comprehend it.

verses.latin: Si repente auferat, quis impediet? aut quis dicere potest: Quare facis?
verses.english: If He suddenly snatches something away, who can stop Him? Or who can say to Him: 'Why do You do this?'

verses.latin: Deus, cujus iræ nemo resistere potest, et sub quo curvantur hi qui portant orbem.
verses.english: God, whose wrath no one can resist, is the One before whom even the cosmic powers that hold up the world bend.

verses.latin: Quantus ergo ego sum, ut respondeam ei, et loquar verbis meis cum illo?
verses.english: How then can I be great enough to answer Him, or to speak my own words in debate with Him?

verses.latin: Qui etiam si habuero aliquid justi, non respondebo: sed meum judicem deprecabor.
verses.english: Even if I possessed some righteousness, I would not answer Him. Instead, I would implore my Judge for mercy.

verses.latin: Et cum invocavimus, et non audierit, nec credam quod loquatur mihi.
verses.english: And even if I were to call upon Him and He heard me, I would not believe that He was actually speaking to me.

verses.latin: In turbine enim conteret me, et multiplicabit vulnera mea sine causa.
verses.english: For He would crush me with a storm, and multiply my wounds without any discernible cause.

verses.latin: Non concedit requiescere spiritum meum, et satiat me amaritudinibus.
verses.english: He does not allow my spirit to rest, but fills me with bitter experiences.

verses.latin: Si fortitudo quæritur, robustissimus est: si judicium, nemo audet respondere pro me.
verses.english: If strength is sought, He is the mightiest. If justice is sought, no one dares to speak on my behalf.

verses.latin: Si justificare me voluero, os meum condemnabit me: si innocentem ostendero, pravum me comprobabit.
verses.english: If I wanted to justify myself, my own mouth would condemn me. If I showed myself innocent, it would prove me perverse.

verses.latin: Si simplex fuero, hoc ipsum ignorabit anima mea, et onerabor mœrore.
verses.english: Even if I were perfectly blameless, my soul would not recognize this, and I would be overwhelmed with sorrow.

verses.latin: Unum est, quod locutus sum: et innocentem et impium ipse consumit.
verses.english: There is one truth that I have spoken: God consumes both the innocent and the wicked.

verses.latin: Si flagellum occidat protinus, irridet pœnas innocentium.
verses.english: If a sudden scourge brings death, He mocks the suffering of the innocent.

verses.latin: Terra data est in manus impii: vultum judicum ejus velat. Quod si non ille est, quis igitur?
verses.english: The earth is given into the hands of the wicked. God conceals the faces of its judges. If it is not God who does this, then who is it?

verses.latin: Dies mei velociores fuerunt cursu nuntii: fugerunt, et non viderunt bonum.
verses.english: My days have been swifter than a swift messenger; they have fled away without seeing any good.

verses.latin: Perierunt quasi naves oneratæ pomis, et sicut aquila volans ad escam.
verses.english: They have passed away like swiftly loaded ships with goods, and like an eagle flying towards its prey.

verses.latin: Si dixero: Obliviscar, et ignorabo rugitum meum, et assumam faciem hilarem:
verses.english: If I say: 'I will forget my complaint, I will ignore my roaring, and I will put on a cheerful expression,'

verses.latin: Vereor omnes dolores meos, sciens quod non parcas delinquenti.
verses.english: I still fear all my sorrows, knowing that You will not spare the guilty.

verses.latin: Si autem et sic impius sum: quare frustra laboravi?
verses.english: But if I am, even so, deemed wicked, why then have I labored in vain?

verses.latin: Si lotus fuero quasi aquis nivis, et mundavero quasi mundissimis manibus:
verses.english: If I were to wash myself with snow water, and cleanse my hands until they were as pure as possible,

verses.latin: Tamen sordibus intingeris me, et abominabuntur me vestimenta mea.
verses.english: even then, You would plunge me into filth, and my own clothes would detest me.

verses.latin: Neque enim cum homine ego judicio contendo, sicut ego sum: neque enim homo est mecum, quo possim ex æquo contendere.
verses.english: For I do not contend with God in a trial, as I would with a mere man who is like me; for He is not a man like me, that I could equally argue with Him.

verses.latin: Non est qui utrumque valeat arguere, et inter utrumque ponere manum suam.
verses.english: There is no arbiter who can reprove both of us, and lay his hand between us to mediate.

verses.latin: Auferat a me virgam suam, et terror ejus non me formidet.
verses.english: Let Him remove His rod of chastisement from me, and let His terror not frighten me.

verses.latin: Loquar, et non timebo eum: nec enim possum metu vacuus.
verses.english: Then I would speak and not be afraid of Him, for in my current state, I cannot be free from fear.

verses.latin: Anima mea fastidit vitam meam: dimittam adversum me eloquium meum: loquar in amaritudine animae meae.
verses.english: My very being finds my life unbearable. I will unleash my complaint, even if it sounds like it’s against myself. I will speak from the deepest bitterness within my spirit.

verses.latin: Dicam Deo: Ne me condemnes: indica mihi cur me ita judices.
verses.english: I will say to God: 'Please, do not condemn me. Show me the reason why You judge me in this way.'

verses.latin: Numquid bonum tibi videtur, si calumnieris, et opprimas me opus manuum tuarum, et consilium impiorum adjuves?
verses.english: Does it seem right to You that You should oppress me, Your own creation, and then seem to favor the schemes of the wicked?

verses.latin: Numquid oculi carnei tibi sunt? aut sicut videt homo, et tu videbis?
verses.english: Do You have the limited vision of mortal eyes? Do You see things the way a mere human sees them?

verses.latin: Numquid sicut dies hominis dies tui sunt, et anni tui sicut humana sunt tempora:
verses.english: Are Your days as fleeting as the days of a man? Are Your years as limited as human life spans?

verses.latin: ut quæras iniquitatem meam, et peccatum meum scrutaris:
verses.english: Why do You meticulously search for my guilt and scrutinize my every sin, as if You didn't already know everything?

verses.latin: et scias quia nihil impium fecerim, cum sit nemo qui de manu tua possit eruere?
verses.english: Even though You know I haven't committed any grave sin against You, there is no one who can rescue me from Your mighty hand.

verses.latin: Manus tuæ fecerunt me, et plasmaverunt me totum in circuitu: et sic repente præcipitas me?
verses.english: Your hands created me and fashioned every part of me. How can You so suddenly decide to destroy me?

verses.latin: Memento, quæso, quod sicut lutum feceris me, et in pulverem reduces me.
verses.english: Please remember that You molded me from clay, and it is to dust that You will return me.

verses.latin: Nonne sicut lac mulsisti me, et sicut caseum me coagulasti?
verses.english: Did You not pour me out like milk and then solidify me like cheese, forming my body?

verses.latin: Pelle et carnibus vestisti me, ossibus et nervis compegisti me.
verses.english: You clothed me with skin and flesh, and You knit me together with bones and sinews.

verses.latin: Vitam et misericordiam tribuisti mihi, et visitatio tua custodivit spiritum meum.
verses.english: You granted me life and Your lovingkindness, and Your watchful care preserved my very breath.

verses.latin: Licet hæc habeas in corde tuo, tamen scio quoniam omnium recordaris.
verses.english: Even if You have hidden purposes in Your heart regarding these matters, I still know that You remember all things—including my actions.

verses.latin: Si peccavi, et tu statim scis, et a scelere meo mundum me esse non pateris.
verses.english: If I have sinned, You know it instantly, and You do not allow me to be declared innocent of my wrongdoing.

verses.latin: Et si impius fuero, væ mihi est: et si justus, non levabo caput, saturatus afflictione et miseria.
verses.english: If I were truly wicked, then woe to me! But even if I am innocent, I cannot hold my head high, for I am utterly saturated with suffering and misery.

verses.latin: Et propter superbiam quasi leonem capies me, et revertens miro dolore me crucias.
verses.english: If I show any pride, You hunt me down like a fierce lion, and again and again, You return to inflict extraordinary pain upon me.

verses.latin: Instauras testes tuos contra me, et multiplicas iram tuam adversum me, et pœnis vicissim me atteris.
verses.english: You bring fresh evidence against me, and You intensify Your anger towards me, crushing me with wave after wave of pain.

verses.latin: Quare de vulva eduxisti me? Qui utinam consumptus essem ne oculus me videret.
verses.english: Why did You bring me forth from my mother’s womb? If only I had died at birth, so that no one would have ever seen me.

verses.latin: Fuissem quasi non essem, de utero translatus ad tumulum.
verses.english: Then I would have been as if I had never existed, carried directly from the womb to the grave.

verses.latin: Numquid non paucitas dierum meorum finietur brevi? dimitte ergo me, ut plangam paululum dolorem meum,
verses.english: Since my few remaining days will soon be over, please leave me alone for a little while, so I can lament my pain.

verses.latin: antequam vadam, et non revertar, ad terram tenebrosam, et opertam mortis caligine:
verses.english: Grant me this before I journey to the place of no return—the dark land, shrouded in the deepest gloom of death.

verses.latin: terram miseriæ et tenebrarum, ubi umbra mortis, et nullus ordo, sed sempiternus horror inhabitat.
verses.english: It is a land of utter misery and darkness, where the shadow of death is present everywhere, and there is no order, but only an everlasting terror.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Sophar Naamathites dixit:
verses.english: Then Zophar, who was from Naamah and was one of Job's friends, replied to him, saying:

verses.latin: Numquid qui multiplicat verba, non audietur? aut vir loquax justificabitur?
verses.english: Will a man who multiplies words not be heard? Or will a talkative man be justified simply by speaking much?

verses.latin: Taceant tibi homines, et cum cachinno rideant? et cum irriserit te alius, et nemo confundat?
verses.english: Should men be silent before you and laugh with scorn? And when another mocks you, should no one correct him or put him to shame?

verses.latin: Dixisti enim: Munda est loquela mea, et mundus sum in conspectu tuo.
verses.english: For you have said, 'My doctrine and my speech are pure, and I am clean in your sight.'

verses.latin: Atque utinam Deus loqueretur tecum, et aperiret labia sua tibi,
verses.english: Oh, if only God would speak to you Himself and open His divine lips to address you directly,

verses.latin: ut ostenderet tibi arcana sapientiae suae, et quid multiplex esset lex ejus: et intelligeres quod multo minora de tuis meritis exigat Deus.
verses.english: so that He might show you the hidden secrets of His divine wisdom and make known to you how manifold His divine law is. Then you would understand that God demands less punishment from you than your sins actually deserve.

verses.latin: Forsitan et vestigia Dei comprehendes, et usque ad perfectum omnipotentem reperies?
verses.english: Can you possibly comprehend the deep and hidden ways of God? Or can you perfectly understand the Almighty and His infinite wisdom?

verses.latin: Excelsior caelo est, et quid facies? profundior inferno, et unde cognosces?
verses.english: God is higher than the created universe itself—what can you possibly do to reach Him? He is deeper than the underworld, the realm of the dead—how can you truly know Him?

verses.latin: Longior terra mensura ejus, et latior mari.
verses.english: His wisdom and reach are longer than the entire earth in its measure, and wider than the vast sea.

verses.latin: Si subverterit, vel concluserit, vel coarctaverit, quis contradicere ei poterit?
verses.english: If He should overthrow things, or confine them, or restrict them—who then could possibly contradict Him or stand against His will?

verses.latin: Ipse enim novit hominum vanitatem, et videns iniquitatem, non attendit.
verses.english: For He Himself knows the vanity and emptiness of human beings, and when He sees their iniquity, He does not fail to notice it.

verses.latin: Vanus homo in superbiam erigitur, et sicut pullum onagri se liberum natum putat.
verses.english: An empty and vain person proudly exalts himself, and like an untamed wild donkey, he thinks he was born free from all accountability.

verses.latin: Tu autem firmasti cor tuum, et expandisti ad eum manus tuas.
verses.english: But you, Job, should set your heart aright and truly stretch out your hands in supplication toward Him.

verses.latin: Si iniquitatem, quae est in manu tua, abstuleris a te, et non manserit in tabernaculo tuo injustitia:
verses.english: If you remove the iniquity that is actively in your hands—meaning your sinful deeds—and if injustice no longer dwells in your tent, your home and your life:

verses.latin: tunc caput tuum absque macula eriges, et eris stabilis, et non timebis.
verses.english: then you will lift up your head, free from the blemish of sin, and you will be firm and steady, and you will no longer fear.

verses.latin: Miseriae quoque oblita eris, et quasi aquarum incurrentium recordaberis.
verses.english: You will also entirely forget your past miseries, and you will remember them only as rushing waters that have flowed away and are gone.

verses.latin: Et quasi meridianus fulgor, consurget tibi ad meridiem: et cum te deficere putaveris, orieris ut lucifer.
verses.english: And your light will shine forth like the brilliance of noonday, and even when you think you are failing or have come to an end, you will rise again like the morning star.

verses.latin: Et habebis fiduciam, proposita tibi spe: et defossus securus dormies.
verses.english: And you will have confidence because hope has been set before you, and you will rest securely, deeply rooted and safe.

verses.latin: Et requiesces, et non erit qui te exterreat: et deprecabuntur faciem tuam plurimi.
verses.english: And you will rest peacefully, and there will be no one to frighten you. Many will come to entreat your favor and seek your guidance.

verses.latin: Oculi autem impiorum deficient, et effugium peribit ab eis: et spes illorum, quasi halitus animae.
verses.english: But the eyes of the wicked will fail and lose their sight, and all possibility of escape will perish from them. Their hope will be like the fleeting breath of life, utterly insubstantial and gone in an instant.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Job dixit:
verses.english: But Job replied to them and said:

verses.latin: Putatisne vos esse solos homines, et vobiscum morietur sapientia?
verses.english: Do you really think that you are the only human beings who possess wisdom? Do you think wisdom will die when you die?

verses.latin: Et mihi est cor sicut et vobis, nec inferior sum vobis: quis ignorat ista quæ scitis?
verses.english: However, I also have understanding, just like you all do. I am not inferior to you. For who among us is ignorant of these things that you know?

verses.latin: Qui deridetur ab amico suo quasi ego, invocabit Deum et exaudiet eum: deridetur enim justi simplicitas.
verses.english: A man like me, who is ridiculed by his friend, will call upon God, and God will hear him. For even the straightforward righteousness of a just man is ridiculed by others.

verses.latin: Lampas contempta apud cogitationes divitum, parata ad irrisum pedibus labentium.
verses.english: A lamp, despised in the thoughts of the wealthy, is ready to be scorned by the feet of those who stumble — meaning a man in misfortune is easily kicked aside.

verses.latin: Tabernacula prædonum abundant, et audacter provocant Deum, cum ipse dederit omnia in manibus eorum:
verses.english: The tents of robbers are full of prosperity, and they boldly challenge God Himself, even though God is the one who has given everything into their hands.

verses.latin: Qui interrogat jumenta, et docebunt te: et volatilia cæli, et indicabunt tibi.
verses.english: Indeed, if you ask the beasts of burden, they will teach you. And the birds of the sky will show you the truth.

verses.latin: Loquere terræ, et docebit te: et narrabunt pisces maris.
verses.english: Speak to the earth, and it will teach you. And the fish of the sea will tell you.

verses.latin: Quis ignorat in his omnibus, quod manus Domini fecerit ista?
verses.english: Who among all these living things does not know that the hand of the Lord has made these things?

verses.latin: In cujus manu anima omnis viventis, et spiritus universæ carnis hominis.
verses.english: In the Lord's hand is the soul of every living creature, and the breath of all human flesh.

verses.latin: Nonne auris verba dijudicat, et fauces cibum sibi palato probant?
verses.english: Does not the ear discern words? And do not the mouth and palate taste and approve food for themselves?

verses.latin: In antiquis est sapientia, et in longa rerum experientia prudentia.
verses.english: Wisdom is found among the aged, and prudence comes from long experience with many things.

verses.latin: Apud ipsum est sapientia et fortitudo, ipse habet consilium et intelligentiam.
verses.english: With God alone is true wisdom and strength. He alone has counsel and understanding.

verses.latin: Si destruxerit, nemo est qui ædificet: si incluserit hominem, nemo est qui aperiat.
verses.english: If He destroys, no one can rebuild. If He shuts a man in, no one can open his prison.

verses.latin: Si continuerit aquas, omnia siccabuntur: et si emiserit illas, subvertent terram.
verses.english: If He holds back the waters, everything will dry up. And if He releases them, they will overturn the earth.

verses.latin: Apud ipsum est fortitudo et sapientia: ipse novit et decipientem, et eum qui decipitur.
verses.english: With Him is strength and wisdom. He knows both the deceiver and the one who is deceived.

verses.latin: Inducit consiliarios in stultum finem, et judices in stuporem.
verses.english: He leads counselors to a foolish end, and He brings judges into a state of bewilderment.

verses.latin: Baltheum regum laxat, et præcingit fune renes eorum.
verses.english: He loosens the belt of kings — stripping them of their authority — and binds their loins with a rope — making them prisoners.

verses.latin: Sacerdotes ducit captivos, et optimates supplantat.
verses.english: He leads priests away as captives, and He overthrows the powerful nobles.

verses.latin: Commutat labium veracium, et doctrinam seniorum aufert.
verses.english: He changes the speech of those who speak truthfully, making them unable to speak, and He takes away the wisdom of the elders.

verses.latin: Effundit despectionem super principes, et eos qui oppressi fuerant relevat.
verses.english: He pours contempt upon princes, and He raises up those who had been oppressed.

verses.latin: Revelat profunda de tenebris, et producit in lucem umbram mortis.
verses.english: He reveals deep things from the darkness, and He brings the shadow of death into the light.

verses.latin: Multiplicat gentes, et perdit eas: et subversas denuo restituit.
verses.english: He makes nations grow in number, and then He destroys them. And those that were overthrown, He restores again.

verses.latin: Immutat cor principum populi terræ, et decipit eos ut frustra incedant per invium.
verses.english: He changes the heart of the leaders of the people of the earth, and He deceives them, so that they wander in vain through an untraveled wilderness.

verses.latin: Palpabunt quasi in tenebris, et non in luce: et errare facit eos quasi ebrios.
verses.english: They will grope about as if in darkness, and not in the light. And He makes them stumble and wander as if they were drunk.

verses.latin: Juxta scientiam vestram, et ego novi: nec inferior vestri sum.
verses.english: I know these things just as well as you do. I am not inferior to any of you.

verses.latin: Sed ad Omnipotentem loquar, et accusare illum volo.
verses.english: But I will speak directly to the Almighty One. I intend to bring a charge against Him.

verses.latin: Vos autem fabri mendacii, et curatores perversi dogmatis.
verses.english: But you are merely forgers of lies. You are ministers of perverse doctrines.

verses.latin: Utinam taceretis, ut putaremini esse sapientes!
verses.english: I wish you would just keep silent, so that you might be considered wise!

verses.latin: Audite ergo correptionem meam, et attendite judicium labiorum meorum.
verses.english: Therefore, hear my rebuke. Pay attention to the judgment coming from my lips.

verses.latin: Numquid Deus indiget vestro mendacio, ut pro illo loquamini dolosa?
verses.english: Does God truly need your lies, so that you may speak deceitfully on His behalf?

verses.latin: An magis illi placet, ut fallaciter pro eo loquamini?
verses.english: Or is it more pleasing to Him that you speak falsely for Him?

verses.latin: Aut numquid adducet vos, ut scrutetur? an sicut illuditur homo, sic illudi potest Deus?
verses.english: Or will He bring you forward to examine you? Can God be mocked, just as a human can be mocked?

verses.latin: Ipse vos arguet, quoniam in abscondito facitis judicium.
verses.english: He Himself will rebuke you, because you render judgment in secret.

verses.latin: Statim ut vobis se ostenderit, concutiet vos ejus terror.
verses.english: As soon as He reveals Himself to you, His terror will shake you.

verses.latin: Memoria vestra comparabitur cinem, et defensio vestra, ad luti similitudinem.
verses.english: Your memory will be compared to ashes, and your defense will be like a heap of mud.

verses.latin: Tacete paulisper ut loquar quidquid mihi mens suggesserit.
verses.english: Be silent for a little while, so that I may speak whatever my mind suggests to me.

verses.latin: Quare lacero carnes meas dentibus meis, et animam meam porto in manibus meis?
verses.english: Why do I tear my flesh with my teeth? Why do I carry my life in my hands, risking it all?

verses.latin: Etiam si occiderit me, in ipso sperabo: verumtamen vias meas in conspectu ejus arguam.
verses.english: Even if He kills me, I will still hope in Him. Nevertheless, I will argue my case and my ways in His presence.

verses.latin: Et ipse erit salvator meus: non enim veniet in conspectu ejus omnis hypocrita.
verses.english: And He Himself will be my Savior, my deliverer. For indeed, no hypocrite will come into His presence.

verses.latin: Audite diligenter sermonem meum, et aures vestrae percipiant sensum meum.
verses.english: Listen carefully to my discourse, and let your ears perceive my true meaning.

verses.latin: Ecce judicium meum paratum est: scio quoniam justus inveniar.
verses.english: Look! My judgment, my defense, is prepared. I know that I will be found just.

verses.latin: Quis est qui judicetur mecum? Veniant: quid est quod taceo?
verses.english: Who is it that will contend with me in judgment? Let them come forward. What reason do I have to remain silent?

verses.latin: Duo tantum ne facias mihi, et tunc a facie tua non abscondar.
verses.english: Only two things, please do not do to me, and then I will not hide from your presence.

verses.latin: Manum tuam longe fac a me, et formido tua non me terreat.
verses.english: Keep Your hand far from me, and let Your terrifying majesty not frighten me.

verses.latin: Proponas quid velis, et ego respondebo: aut certe loquar, et tu responde mihi.
verses.english: Propose what You wish, and I will answer. Or indeed, let me speak, and You respond to me.

verses.latin: Quantas habeo iniquitates et peccata? scelera et delicta mea ostende mihi.
verses.english: How many iniquities and sins do I have? Show me my crimes and my offenses.

verses.latin: Cur faciem tuam abscondis, et arbitraris me inimicum tuum?
verses.english: Why do You hide Your face? Why do You consider me to be Your enemy?

verses.latin: Contra folium quod vento rapitur, ostendis potentiam tuam, et stipulam siccam persequeris?
verses.english: Against a leaf that is snatched away by the wind, do You display Your power? Do You pursue a dry stubble of straw?

verses.latin: Scribis enim contra me amaritudines, et consu mis me peccatis adolescentiae meae.
verses.english: For You write bitter accusations against me, and You consume me with the sins of my youth.

verses.latin: Posuisti in nervo pedem meum, et observasti omnes semitas meas, et vestigia pedum meorum considerasti.
verses.english: You have put my foot in stocks. You have watched all my paths, and You have considered the very tracks of my feet.

verses.latin: Qui quasi de putredine consumendus sum, et quasi vestimentum quod comeditur a tinea.
verses.english: I, who am to be consumed as if by rot, and like a garment that is eaten by a moth.

verses.latin: Homo natus de muliere, brevi vivens tempore, repletur multis miseriis.
verses.english: Every man born from a woman lives for only a brief time. His life is filled with many troubles and sufferings.

verses.latin: Qui quasi flos egreditur, et conteritur, et fugit velut umbra, et nunquam in eodem statu permanet.
verses.english: He comes forth like a flower, blooming only to be crushed and wither away. His life flees like a quickly passing shadow, and he never remains in the same state—constantly changing, constantly moving towards death.

verses.latin: Et dignum ducis super hujuscemodi aperire oculos tuos, et adducere eum tecum in judicium?
verses.english: Do You, O God, consider it worthy to even look upon such a fleeting creature? Do You bring such a one into Your judgment with You?

verses.latin: Quis potest facere mundum de immundo conceptum semine? Nonne tu solus?
verses.english: Who can make a clean thing out of something conceived from unclean seed, from a fallen human lineage? Only You, O God, can do that.

verses.latin: Breves dies hominis sunt: numerus mensium ejus apud te est: constituisti terminos ejus, qui præteriri non poterunt.
verses.english: The days of man are short. The number of his months are determined by You, O God. You have set his boundaries, and these cannot be surpassed or extended.

verses.latin: Recede paulisper ab eo, ut quiescat, donec optata veniat sicut mercenarii dies ejus.
verses.english: Turn away from him for a little while, so that he may find some rest, until his appointed day of death comes—a day he looks forward to, just as a hired laborer longs for the end of his day to receive his wages.

verses.latin: Lignum habet spem: si præcisum fuerit, rursum frondescit, et rami ejus pullulant.
verses.english: Even a tree has hope: if it is cut down, it will sprout again, and its new branches will bud and grow.

verses.latin: Si inveteraverit in terra radix ejus, et in pulvere emortuus fuerit truncus illius:
verses.english: Even if its root grows old in the earth, and its stump appears to die away into the dust,

verses.latin: Ad odorem aquæ germinabit, et faciet comam quasi cum primum plantabatur.
verses.english: Yet, at the mere scent of water, it will bud and spring to life again, producing new foliage as if it were a young sapling freshly planted.

verses.latin: Homo vero cum mortuus fuerit, et nudatus, et consumptus, ubi, quæso, est?
verses.english: But when a man dies, when his body is stripped of life and consumed, where, I ask, is he? There is no hope of his return to earthly life.
