verses.latin: Quomodo si recedant aquæ de mari, et fluvius vacuefactus arescat:
verses.english: Just as the waters of the sea may recede, and a river, once full, becomes empty and dries up completely,

verses.latin: Sic homo cum dormierit, non surget donec atteratur cælum: non evigilabit, nec consurget de somno suo.
verses.english: So it is with man: once he dies, he will not rise again from that sleep, not until the very universe itself is worn away. He will not awaken, nor will he rise from his slumber in this earthly existence.

verses.latin: Quis mihi hoc tribuat, ut in inferno, vel in secreto abscondas me, donec pertranseat furor tuus, et constituas mihi tempus in quo recorderis mei?
verses.english: Oh, that someone would grant me this: that You would hide me in Sheol, or keep me in some secret place until Your divine wrath has passed over. And that You would then appoint a time when You would remember me.

verses.latin: Si mortuus fuerit homo, vivet iterum? Cunctis diebus quibus nunc milito, expecto donec veniat immutatio mea.
verses.english: If a man dies, will he live again? All the days of my current struggle and service, I wait and hope until my change comes—the end of this suffering.

verses.latin: Vocabis me, et ego respondebo tibi: operæ manuum tuarum porriges dexteram.
verses.english: Then You will call to me, and I will answer You. You will extend Your right hand to the work of Your own hands, to me, Your creation.

verses.latin: Tu quidem grederis vestigia mea: sed parcis peccatis meis.
verses.english: Indeed, You closely observe my every step. But in that time, You will be merciful to my sins.

verses.latin: Signasti quasi in sacculo iniquitates meas: sed curasti delicta mea.
verses.english: You have sealed up my iniquities as if in a bag for safekeeping, yet You have also covered over and healed my offenses.

verses.latin: Mons cadens deficit: et saxum transfertur de loco suo.
verses.english: But as a mountain crumbling eventually vanishes, and a rock is dislodged and moved from its place,

verses.latin: Lapides extenuant aquæ, et alluvione paulatim terra consumitur: et hominem similiter perdis.
verses.english: Just as water wears down stones, and an overwhelming flood gradually consumes the land, in the same way, You destroy the hope of man.

verses.latin: Irruit in eum, et pertransiit: immutans vultum ejus, et emittens eum.
verses.english: You overcome him, and he passes away. You change his countenance in death, and You send him away from life.

verses.latin: Sive nobiles fuerint filii ejus, sive ignobiles, non intelligit.
verses.english: Whether his sons become honored or remain unknown, he does not know it. He is unaware of the fate of his descendants.

verses.latin: Attamen caro ejus, dum vivit, dolebit, et anima illius super semetipsam lugebit.
verses.english: However, his own flesh, while he lives, will feel pain, and his soul within him will mourn over its own suffering.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Eliphaz Themanites, dixit:
verses.english: Eliphaz the Themanite then responded and said:

verses.latin: Numquid sapiens respondebit quasi in ventum verba, et implebit ardore stomachum suum?
verses.english: Can any wise man truly respond with words that are as empty as wind, and then fill his stomach with such emptiness?

verses.latin: Arguis eum verbo, qui non est aequalis tui, et non proficies quidquam eloquio?
verses.english: Do you argue against him with empty words? You are not his equal, and you gain nothing with such speech.

verses.latin: Tu quidem dissolvisti timorem, et attenuasti orationem apud Deum.
verses.english: Indeed, you have dissolved all reverence for God, and you have diminished the importance of prayer before God.

verses.latin: Implevit enim iniquitas os tuum, et meditaris linguam blasphemiarum.
verses.english: For your iniquity has filled your mouth, and your tongue plans out blasphemies.

verses.latin: Te condemnat propria lingua, et non ego: et labia tua respondent tibi.
verses.english: Your own tongue condemns you, not I; your own lips speak against you.

verses.latin: Numquid primus homo tu natus es, et ante colles formatus?
verses.english: Were you the first man ever born, and formed before the hills?

verses.latin: Audistin’ consilium Dei, et in te retines sapientiam?
verses.english: Have you heard the counsel of God, and do you keep all wisdom to yourself?

verses.latin: Quid nosti quod ignoremus? quid intelligis quod nos nesciamus?
verses.english: What do you know that we do not know? What do you understand that we are unaware of?

verses.latin: Et senes et antiqui sunt in nobis, multo vetustiores quam pater tuus.
verses.english: Both old men and those with ancient wisdom are among us, many much older than your father.

verses.latin: Numquid grande est ut te consoletur Deus? et sermones occultos a te, leniter audit auris tua?
verses.english: Is it such a great thing that God would console you? And does your ear gently hear the secret words from you?

verses.latin: Quid elevatum est cor tuum, et cur attonitos habes oculos, quasi ad iram provoces Deum?
verses.english: Why is your heart so lifted up with pride, and why do you have such astonished eyes, as if you are provoking God to anger?

verses.latin: Quid tumet spiritus tuus contra Deum, ut proferas de ore tuo sermones hujuscemodi?
verses.english: Why does your spirit swell against God, so that you utter such words from your mouth?

verses.latin: Quid est homo ut immaculatus sit, aut ut justificetur natus de muliere?
verses.english: What is man, that he should be without sin, or that one born of a woman should be justified?

verses.latin: Ecce, sancti non sunt stabiles apud eum, et caeli non sunt mundi in conspectu ejus.
verses.english: Behold, even the holy ones are not steadfast in His sight, and even the heavens are not pure in His presence.

verses.latin: Quanto magis abominabilis et inutilis homo, qui bibit quasi aquam iniquitatem?
verses.english: How much more abominable and useless is man, who drinks iniquity as if it were water?

verses.latin: Ostendam tibi, audi me: et quid experiri inveni, narrabo tibi.
verses.english: I will show you, listen to me: and what I have found through experience, I will tell you.

verses.latin: Quam sapientes nuntiant, et non abscondunt patres eorum:
verses.english: What wise men declare, and what their fathers have not hidden from them:

verses.latin: quibus solis data est terra, et non transivit alienus per eos.
verses.english: To whom alone the land was given, and no foreigner passed among them.

verses.latin: Cunctis diebus suis impius superbit, et numerus annorum incertus est tyrannidis ejus.
verses.english: The wicked man is arrogant all his days, and the number of years of his tyranny is uncertain.

verses.latin: Sonitus terroris semper in auribus illius, et cum pax fuerit, insidiae semper timidae.
verses.english: The sound of terror is always in his ears, and even when there is peace, his snares are always timid.

verses.latin: Non credit quod revertatur de tenebris, et alium exspectat gladium undique.
verses.english: He does not believe that he will return from the darkness, and he always expects another sword from every side.

verses.latin: Cum fugerit ad panem, ubi illi praeparatus est? scit tenebras sibi praesto esse in die.
verses.english: When he flees for bread, where is it prepared for him? He knows that darkness is ready for him in the day.

verses.latin: Tribulatio, et angustia terrebit eum, et praevalebit contra illum, quasi rex qui praeparatur ad praelium.
verses.english: Trouble and anguish will terrify him, and will prevail against him, like a king preparing for battle.

verses.latin: Direxit enim adversum Deum manum suam, et contra Omnipotentem roboratus est.
verses.english: For he has stretched out his hand against God, and has strengthened himself against the Almighty.

verses.latin: Cucurrit adversus eum cervice tensa, sub clypeo colli ejus.
verses.english: He ran against Him with a stiff neck, under the boss of his own neck's shield.

verses.latin: Comedisti enim pinguedinem ejus, et medullam illius:
verses.english: For you have indeed consumed his abundance, and his very substance.

verses.latin: Operuisti faciem tuam adipe tuo, et collum tuum infers pinguedine.
verses.english: You have covered your own face with your own fat, and you make your neck heavy with your own indulgence.

verses.latin: Non ditabitur, nec perseverabit substantia ejus, nec mittet in terra radicem suam.
verses.english: He will not become rich, nor will his substance endure, nor will he send forth his root into the earth.

verses.latin: Non recedet de tenebris, ramos ejus arefaciet flamma: et auferetur spiritus ejus ore Dei.
verses.english: He will not escape the darkness; the flame will wither his branches; and his spirit will be taken away by the breath of God.

verses.latin: Non credat frustra errore seductus, ut redimatur quolibet pretio.
verses.english: Let him not trust in vain, having been led astray by error, believing that he might be redeemed by any price.

verses.latin: Ante dies suos peribit, et rami ejus non frondescent.
verses.english: He will perish before his appointed days, and his branches will not flourish.

verses.latin: Decerpet quasi vinea intemperiem uvam suam, et quasi oliva projiciet florem suum.
verses.english: He will pluck off his unripe grape like a vine, and cast off his blossom like an olive tree.

verses.latin: Congregatio enim hypocritae sterilis, et ignis devorabit tabernacula munerum.
verses.english: For the assembly of the hypocrite is barren, and fire will devour the tents of those who take bribes.

verses.latin: Concipit dolorem, et parit iniquitatem, et uterus ejus praeparat dolos.
verses.english: He conceives sorrow, and gives birth to iniquity, and his womb prepares deceits.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Iob ait:
verses.english: Job, however, responded and said:

verses.latin: Audivi frequenter talia: consolatores onerosi omnes vos estis.
verses.english: I have often heard such words as these. All of you are burdensome comforters.

verses.latin: Numquid habebunt finem verba ventosa? aut quid te permovit ut sic loquaris?
verses.english: Will these empty words never end? Or what has provoked you to speak like this?

verses.latin: Potui et ego similibus verbis loqui, atque utinam esset anima vestra pro anima mea!
verses.english: I also could speak similar words, and if only your souls were in place of my soul!

verses.latin: Confortarem et ego vos sermone, et moverem caput meum super vos.
verses.english: I could also strengthen you with my words and shake my head at you in mock sympathy.

verses.latin: Loquente me, non quiescit dolor meus: et tacente me, non recedit a me.
verses.english: If I speak, my pain does not cease. And if I am silent, it does not leave me.

verses.latin: Nunc autem afflictione mea contristavit me: et devastavit omnem domum meam.
verses.english: But now, my affliction has saddened me, and it has devastated my entire household.

verses.latin: Rugæ meæ testimonium sunt, et falsum testimonium: et elevans mendacium adversum me, aretit faciem meam.
verses.english: My wrinkles are a witness, even a false witness, that accuses me. My adversary, standing up against me with lies, makes my face gaunt.

verses.latin: Iratus squarravit me, et adversatus est mihi, infremuit super me dentibus suis: hostis meus terribilibus oculis me intuitus est.
verses.english: In His wrath, He has torn me apart and opposed me. He has gnashed His teeth at me. My enemy has looked upon me with terrible eyes.

verses.latin: Aperuerunt super me os suum, exprobrantes percusserunt maxillam meam, simul et convenerunt adversum me.
verses.english: They have opened their mouths wide against me. They have struck my cheek with reproaches. They have gathered together against me.

verses.latin: Conclusit me Deus apud iniquos, et inter manus impiorum me tradidit.
verses.english: God has shut me up among the wicked and has handed me over into the hands of the impious.

verses.latin: Ego ille quondam opulentus, repente contritus sum: arripuit comam meam, et scidit me: et posuit me quasi signum ad sagittam.
verses.english: I, who was once prosperous, have suddenly been crushed. He has seized my hair and torn me apart. He has set me up as a target for arrows.

verses.latin: Circumdederunt me lanceæ ejus, perfodere renes meos, nec pepercerunt: effudit in terra intestina mea.
verses.english: His spears have surrounded me. They pierce my kidneys without mercy. He has spilled my entrails upon the earth.

verses.latin: Concisisset me vulnere super vulnus: irruit in me quasi gigas.
verses.english: He cuts me with wound upon wound. He rushes upon me like a mighty warrior.

verses.latin: Saccum consui super cutem meam, et operui cinere carnem meam.
verses.english: I have sewn sackcloth over my skin, and I have covered my flesh with ashes.

verses.latin: Facies mea intumuit a fletu, et palpebræ meæ caligaverunt.
verses.english: My face has become swollen from weeping, and my eyelids have grown dark.

verses.latin: Absque ulla iniquitate manus meæ: et cum munda oratione mea.
verses.english: Though there is no iniquity in my hands, and my prayer is pure.

verses.latin: Terra, ne operias sanguinem meum, neque inveniat in te locum latendi clamor meus!
verses.english: O Earth, do not cover my blood, and let my cry find no hiding place within you!

verses.latin: Ecce enim in cælo testis meus, et conscius meus in excelsis.
verses.english: For behold, my Witness is in the universe, and my Advocate is in the highest realms.

verses.latin: Interpretator meus est amicus meus, ad Deum stillat oculus meus.
verses.english: My interpreter, my friend, is for me. My eye weeps tears to God.

verses.latin: Utinam judicium sit viri cum Deo, sicut et filii hominis cum socio suo!
verses.english: Oh, that there might be a judgment between a man and God, just as there is between a man and his neighbor!

verses.latin: Breves enim anni transeunt, et semitam per quam non revertar, ambulo.
verses.english: For a few years are passing quickly, and I walk a path from which I will not return.

verses.latin: Spiritus meus attenuatus est, dies mei breviati sunt, et solum mihi superest sepulchrum.
verses.english: My spirit is broken, my days are few, and the grave is all that is left for me.

verses.latin: Nonne irrisiones eorum undique sunt, et in amaritudinibus moratur oculus meus?
verses.english: All around me, I hear nothing but their taunts. My eyes are consumed with bitterness and grief.

verses.latin: Pone me juxta te, et ponatur manus tua contra me. Quis est enim iste, qui spondeat mihi?
verses.english: Grant me a hearing directly before You! Let Your hand be a witness against me. For who else is there who can stand as my guarantor and defend my cause?

verses.latin: Cor eorum longe fecisti a disciplina: propterea non exaltabuntur.
verses.english: You have removed wisdom from their hearts, from my friends. That is why they will never be raised up in honor.

verses.latin: Spolia loquitur promittens amicis, et oculi filiorum ejus deficient.
verses.english: He who betrays his companions for profit, making empty promises of gain, will find that his own children’s eyes fail and become blind.

verses.latin: Me vero quasi in proverbium posuit populis, et exemplum eorum qui obmutuissent.
verses.english: But He has made me a byword to the peoples, an example for those who have been utterly silenced by suffering.

verses.latin: Caligavit ab iracundia oculus meus, et membra mea quasi in nihili redacta sunt.
verses.english: My eyes have grown dim from all my grief, and my limbs have wasted away to nothing.

verses.latin: Stupebunt justi super hoc, et innocens contra hypocritam excitabitur.
verses.english: The righteous will be astonished by what has happened to me, and the innocent will rise up against the hypocrite.

verses.latin: Et tenebit justus viam suam, et mundis manibus addet fortitudinem.
verses.english: Yet the righteous will hold firm to his path, and those with clean hands will grow stronger.

verses.latin: Igitur convertimini omnes, et venite: et non inveniam in vobis quemquam sapientem.
verses.english: So then, turn back, all of you, and come to me! Yet I still will not find a single wise person among you.

verses.latin: Dies mei transierunt, cogitationes meae dissipatae sunt, et tormenta cordis mei.
verses.english: My days are over. My plans are shattered, and with them, the very torments of my heart have been laid bare.

verses.latin: Noctem verterunt in diem, et rursum post tenebras spero lucem.
verses.english: They claim to turn night into day, yet I still foolishly hope for light after such darkness.

verses.latin: Si sustinuero, infernus domus mea est, et in tenebris stravi lectulum meum.
verses.english: If I must only wait, then the grave is my home, and in its darkness I have already made my bed.

verses.latin: Putredini dixi: Pater meus es: Mater mea et soror mea, vermibus.
verses.english: I have said to corruption: “You are my father!” To worms, I have said: “You are my mother and my sister!”

verses.latin: Ubi est ergo nunc praestolatio mea? et patientia mea? Tu es, Domine, Deus meus.
verses.english: Where then is my hope now? And where is my patience? Truly, You are my Lord, my God!

verses.latin: In profundissimam terram descendet totum quod habeo: et simul in pulvere requiescemus.
verses.english: All that I have will descend with me into the deepest earth, and together, we will rest in the dust.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Bildad Suhites, dixit:
verses.english: Bildad from Shuah then responded and spoke:

verses.latin: Usquequo non ponitis finem sermonum? Intelligite prius, et sic loquamur.
verses.english: “How long will you never stop talking? First, understand what we are saying, and then let us speak clearly.”

verses.latin: Quare reputati sumus ut jumenta, et sorduimus coram vobis?
verses.english: “Why are we regarded as mere animals, and considered vile in your presence?”

verses.latin: Qui perdis animam tuam in furore tuo, numquid propter te derelinquetur terra, et transferentur rupes de loco suo?
verses.english: “You are destroying yourself in your fury. But will the created universe then be abandoned because of you, and rocks be moved from their appointed places?”

verses.latin: Nonne lux impii extinguetur, et non splendebit flamma ignis ejus?
verses.english: “Truly, the light of the ungodly person will be extinguished, and the bright flame of his life will not shine.”

verses.latin: Lux ob tenebras vertetur in tabernaculo illius, et lucerna ejus, quæ super ipsum est, extinguetur.
verses.english: “The light of his dwelling will turn to darkness, and his lamp, which is over his head, will be utterly extinguished.”

verses.latin: Arctabuntur gressus virtutis ejus, et præcipitabit eum consilium suum.
verses.english: “His powerful and decisive steps will be hindered, and his own plans will lead to his downfall.”

verses.latin: Immissi sunt in pedes ejus laquei, et in retibus ambulat.
verses.english: “Snares are set for his feet, and he walks right into the traps laid out like nets.”

verses.latin: Tenet pedem illius tendicula, et firmatur super eum plaga.
verses.english: “A trap will grasp his foot, and a snare will close tightly upon him.”

verses.latin: Abscondita est in terra pedica ejus, et decipula illius super semitam.
verses.english: “His trap is hidden in the ground, and a snare for him is set along the path he walks.”

verses.latin: Undique terrent eum formidines, et involvunt pedes ejus.
verses.english: “On every side, terrors startle him, and they relentlessly pursue his steps.”

verses.latin: Attenuetur fame robur ejus, et inter ipsius latera sitim commorabitur.
verses.english: “His physical strength will be weakened by starvation, and thirst will constantly torment him deep within his body.”

verses.latin: Devoret pulchritudinem cutis ejus primogenita mors, consumat membra illius.
verses.english: “The 'firstborn of death' will devour the beauty of his skin, and a fatal disease will consume his limbs.”

verses.latin: Expellatur de tabernaculo suo fiducia ejus, et quasi rex horrorum, ducatur ad impietatem.
verses.english: “His confidence will be driven from his home, and he will be led to ruin, like a king of terrors leading him to wickedness.”

verses.latin: Habitent in tabernaculo illius socii ejus, aspergatur in pavillionem illius sulphur.
verses.english: “Strangers will live in his former dwelling, and sulfur will be sprinkled over his tent as a sign of utter destruction.”

verses.latin: Desuper radices ejus siccentur, et subter rami ejus arescent.
verses.english: “His roots will dry up from above, and his branches below will wither away.”

verses.latin: Memoria illius pereat de terra, et non celebretur nomen ejus in plateis.
verses.english: “His memory will vanish from the earth, and his name will never be spoken in the public squares.”

verses.latin: Expellet eum de luce in tenebras, et de orbe terrarum auferet eum.
verses.english: “He will be driven out from the light of the living into complete darkness, and he will be swept away from the face of the entire world.”

verses.latin: Non erit proles ejus, neque pullus in populo suo, nec ullæ reliquiæ in regionibus suis.
verses.english: “He will have no children or descendants among his people, and no one remaining in his own lands.”

verses.latin: In die ejus stupebunt novissimi, et primos obtinebit horror.
verses.english: “Those who come after him will be astonished at his fate, and those living now will be seized with horror at what happens to him.”

verses.latin: Hæc sunt ergo tabernacula impii, et iste locus ejus, qui ignorat Deum.
verses.english: “These, therefore, are the dwellings of an ungodly person, and this is the ultimate fate of anyone who refuses to acknowledge God.”

verses.latin: Respondens autem Job, dixit:
verses.english: But Job responded by saying:

verses.latin: Usquequo affligitis animam meam, et atteritis me sermonibus?
verses.english: “How long will you torment my very soul and crush me with your words?

verses.latin: En decem vicibus confunditis me, et non erubescitis opprimentes me.
verses.english: Indeed, you have now shamed me many, many times—you repeatedly put me to confusion. And you show no shame in oppressing me.

verses.latin: Nempe si et erravi, mecum est error meus.
verses.english: Even if I have indeed erred, my error remains with me alone.

verses.latin: At vos contra me erigimini, et arguistis me obprobrio meo.
verses.english: Yet you exalt yourselves against me, and you use my very disgrace as an argument against me.

verses.latin: Scitote ergo quoniam Deus perversum me fecit, et gyro suo me circumdedit.
verses.english: Know therefore that it is God who has twisted me into this state, and He has encompassed me with His very power.

verses.latin: Ecce clamabo, vim patiens, et nemo audiet: vociferabor, et non est qui judicet.
verses.english: Behold, I will cry out, enduring great violence, and no one will listen to me. I will raise my voice in protest, but there is no one to grant me justice.

verses.latin: Semitam meam muravit, et transire non possum: et in tenebris posuit iter meum.
verses.english: He has walled up my path so I cannot pass through it. He has plunged my journey into darkness.

verses.latin: Spoliavit me gloria mea, et abstulit coronam de capite meo.
verses.english: He has stripped me of my glory and has taken the crown from my head.

verses.latin: Destruxit me undique, et pereo: et sicut arbor evulsam, sustulit spem meam.
verses.english: He has destroyed me from every direction, and I am perishing. Like an uprooted tree, He has torn away my hope.

verses.latin: Et iratus est contra me furor ejus: et sicut hostem suum reputavit me.
verses.english: Indeed, His fury has been kindled against me, and He has considered me as His very enemy.

verses.latin: Simul venerunt turmae ejus, et fecerunt sibi viam per me: et obsederunt in circuitu tabernaculum meum.
verses.english: His armies have advanced together, and they have forced their way through me. They have besieged my dwelling on every side.

verses.latin: Fratres meos longe fecit a me: et noti mei quasi alieni recesserunt.
verses.english: He has driven my brothers far from me, and my acquaintances have departed as if they were strangers.

verses.latin: Dereliquerunt me propinqui mei: et qui me noverant, obliti sunt mei.
verses.english: My closest relatives have forsaken me, and those who knew me have completely forgotten me.

verses.latin: Inquilini domus meae, et ancillae meae, quasi alienum habuerunt me: et quasi peregrinus fui in oculis eorum.
verses.english: Even the tenants of my house and my own maidservants have treated me as a stranger, and I have become like a foreigner in their eyes.

verses.latin: Servum meum vocavi, et non respondit: ore proprio deprecabar illum.
verses.english: I called my own servant, but he did not answer me. With my very own mouth I had to beg him.

verses.latin: Halitum meum exhorruit uxor mea, et fetor oris mei filiis uteri mei.
verses.english: My wife has abhorred my very breath, and the foul odor from my mouth is repulsive even to the children of my own body.

verses.latin: Extorres me fecerunt etiam parvuli: et cum surrexerint, loquebantur contra me.
verses.english: Even little children have made me an outcast, and when they rise up, they speak against me.

verses.latin: Abominati sunt me quondam consiliarii mei: et quos maxime diligebam, verterunt se contra me.
verses.english: My former counselors have abhorred me, and those whom I loved most have turned themselves against me.

verses.latin: Pelli meae, consumptis carnibus, adhaesit os meum: et derelicta sunt tantummodo labia circa dentes meos.
verses.english: My bone clings to my skin, my flesh having been consumed away. Only my lips remain around my teeth.

verses.latin: Miseremini mei, miseremini mei saltem vos amici mei, quia manus Domini tetigit me.
verses.english: Have pity on me, have pity on me, at least you, my friends, for the hand of the Lord has struck me down.

verses.latin: Quare persequimini me sicut Deus, et carnibus meis saturamini?
verses.english: Why do you persecute me as God does, and why are you not satisfied with devouring my very flesh?

verses.latin: Quis mihi tribuat ut scribantur sermones mei? ut exarentur in libro?
verses.english: Oh, that someone would grant me this: that my words might be written down, that they might be inscribed into a book!

verses.latin: Stilo ferreo et plumbi lammina, vel celte sculpantur in silice?
verses.english: That with an iron stylus and a leaden tablet, or with a chisel, they might be carved into rock, forever!

verses.latin: Scio enim quod Redemptor meus vivit, et in novissimo de terra surrecturus sum.
verses.english: For I know that my Redeemer lives, and that at the very end of time I will rise again from the earth.

verses.latin: Et rursum circumdabor pelle mea, et in carne mea videbo Deum meum.
verses.english: And I will again be clothed with my skin, and in my very own flesh I will see my God.

verses.latin: Quem visurus sum ego ipse, et oculi mei conspecturi sunt, et non alius: reposita est haec spes mea in sinu meo.
verses.english: It is He whom I myself shall see, and my own eyes shall behold Him, and not another's. This is the very hope that is laid up in my heart.

verses.latin: Quare ergo nunc dicitis: Quomodo persequamur eum, et radicem verbi inveniamus contra eum?
verses.english: Why then do you now say, 'How shall we persecute him and find the root of the matter to condemn him?'

verses.latin: A facie ergo gladii fugite, quoniam ultor iniquitatum est gladius: et scitote esse judicium.
verses.english: Therefore, flee from the presence of the sword, for the sword is the avenger of iniquities. And know that there will be a judgment.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Sophar Naamathites, dixit:
verses.english: Then Zophar the Naamathite responded and said:

verses.latin: Idcirco cogitationes meae varie succedunt, et mens in diversa rapitur.
verses.english: Therefore, my thoughts are agitated and conflicting, and my mind is swept in many directions.

verses.latin: Doctrinam qua me arguis, audiam: et spiritus intelligentiae meae pro me loquetur.
verses.english: I hear the argument with which you accuse me, and my inner discernment will speak on my behalf.

verses.latin: An nescis hoc a principio ex quo positus est homo super terram?
verses.english: Do you not know this truth, which has been from the very beginning, ever since mankind was placed upon the earth?

verses.latin: Quod laus impiorum brevis sit, et gaudium hypocritae ad modicum?
verses.english: That the exultation of the wicked is short-lived, and the joy of the hypocrite lasts only for a moment?

verses.latin: Si ascendero usque ad caelum in superbiam suam, et caput ejus nubes tetigero:
verses.english: Even if his arrogance reaches up to the very sky, and his head touches the clouds,

verses.latin: Quasi sterquilinium in fine perdetur, et qui eum viderant, dicent: Ubi est?
verses.english: He will be utterly destroyed like refuse at the end of his life, and those who saw him will say: 'Where has he gone?'

verses.latin: Sicut somnium avolans non invenietur, et velut visio nocturna effugiet.
verses.english: He will vanish without a trace, like a dream that flies away, and he will flee like a vision seen in the night.

verses.latin: Oculus qui eum viderat, non videbit, neque ultra intuebitur eum locus suus.
verses.english: The eye that once saw him will see him no more, and the place where he lived will not behold him again.

verses.latin: Filii ejus nudabuntur a miseria sua, et manus illius reddent ei dolores suos.
verses.english: His children will be reduced to poverty because of his suffering, and his own hands will return his sorrows to him.

verses.latin: Ossa ejus implebuntur vitiis adolescentiae ejus, et cum eo in pulverem dormient.
verses.english: His bones are filled with the iniquities of his youth, and these will lie down with him in the dust of the grave.

verses.latin: Cum enim dulce fuerit in ore ejus malum, abscondet illud sub lingua sua:
verses.english: Even if evil tastes sweet in his mouth, so that he hides it under his tongue,

verses.latin: Parcet ei, et non derelinquet illud, et celabit in gutture suo:
verses.english: Even if he cherishes it and will not let it go, hiding it deep within his throat,

verses.latin: Panis ejus in utero illius vertetur in fel aspidum intrinsecus.
verses.english: That same bread of evil will turn to viper's venom inside his stomach.

verses.latin: Divitias quas devoravit, evomet, et de ventre illius extrahet eas Deus.
verses.english: The riches that he swallowed down, he will vomit up again, for God will extract them from his belly.

verses.latin: Venena aspidum suget, et occidet eum lingua viperae.
verses.english: He will suck the venom of serpents, and the viper's tongue will kill him.

verses.latin: Non videat affluentia rivium, torrentes mellis et butyri.
verses.english: He will not see the abundant flow of streams, nor the rivers flowing with milk and honey.

verses.latin: Reddet quae laboravit, et non consumet: juxta operum suorum multitudinem sic et patitur, nec tamen consumitur.
verses.english: He will restore what he gained by his labor, but he will not enjoy it; in proportion to the multitude of his evil deeds, so he suffers, yet he cannot consume them.

verses.latin: Quoniam confringens et nudans pauperes, domum rapuit, et non aedificavit.
verses.english: Because he crushed and stripped the poor, and violently seized a house but did not build it fairly.

verses.latin: Nec est satiatus venter ejus: et cum habuerit quae desideravit, possidere non poterit.
verses.english: His appetite for gain was never satisfied, and even when he had what he desired, he could not truly possess it.

verses.latin: Non remansit de cibo ejus, et propter hoc non permanebunt bona ejus.
verses.english: Nothing remained of his greedy consumption, and because of this, his ill-gotten gains will not endure.

verses.latin: Cum sufficerit ei, et abundabit, arctabitur: et omnis dolor irruet super eum.
verses.english: When he thinks he has enough and is abundant, he will be constrained; then every kind of sorrow will rush upon him.

verses.latin: Implebitur omnis venter ejus: et mittet in illum iram furoris sui Deus, et pluet super eum bellum suum.
verses.english: God will fill his stomach with retribution; He will send His fierce anger into him and rain His war upon him.

verses.latin: Fugiet a telis ferreis, et irruet in arcum aereum.
verses.english: He will flee from weapons of iron, only to be struck by arrows of bronze.

verses.latin: Eductus est, et egreditur de vagina, et fulgurans in amaritudine sua pertransivit: et horror mortis super ipsum.
verses.english: An arrow is drawn, it comes out from its quiver, flashing in its bitterness it pierces him: and the horror of death falls upon him.

verses.latin: Omnis abscondita illius tenebrae: devorabit eum ignis qui non succenditur: urgetur afflictus in tabernaculo suo.
verses.english: Every hidden treasure of his will be lost in darkness; a fire not kindled by human hands will consume him; he will be oppressed and afflicted in his own dwelling.

verses.latin: Revelabunt caeli iniquitatem ejus, et terra consurget contra eum.
verses.english: The very sky will reveal his iniquity, and the earth itself will rise up against him.

verses.latin: Apertum erit germen domus illius, detrahetur in die irae illius.
verses.english: The harvest of his house will be laid bare and stripped away on the day of God's wrath.

verses.latin: Haec est pars hominis impii a Deo, et haereditas verborum ejus a Domino.
verses.english: This is the portion for the wicked man from God, and this is the inheritance ordained by the Lord for his words and deeds.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Job, dixit:
verses.english: But Job answered, and then he spoke:

verses.latin: Audite, quaeso, sermones meos, et agite pœnitentiam.
verses.english: Please, listen to my words, and reconsider what you believe.

verses.latin: Sustinete me ut loquar : et post verba mea ridebitis.
verses.english: Bear with me until I have finished speaking; then, after my words, you can laugh at me.

verses.latin: Numquid ad hominem sermo meus est, ut jure non doleam?
verses.english: Are my complaints just about men? No, they are about God. So why wouldn't I grieve over this?

verses.latin: Attendite me, et obstupescite, et ponite digitum super os vestrum.
verses.english: Listen to me, and be shocked by what I say, then put your finger over your mouth to remain silent.

verses.latin: Et quidem, cum recordatus fuero, perhorresco, et concutit carnem meam tremor.
verses.english: Indeed, when I remember these things, I am filled with horror, and a tremor shakes my entire body.

verses.latin: Quare ergo impii vivunt, sublevati sunt, et confortati divitiis?
verses.english: Why then do the wicked live? They prosper and become powerful with wealth.

verses.latin: Semen eorum permanet coram eis: et stirps eorum cum ipsis.
verses.english: Their children survive to adulthood right before their eyes, and their descendants live with them.

verses.latin: Domus eorum securæ sunt a timore: et non est virga Dei super illos.
verses.english: Their homes are safe from any fear, and the rod of God's judgment is not upon them.

verses.latin: Taurus eorum concepit, et non abortivit: vacca eorum genuit, et non est infecunda.
verses.english: Their bull mates, and the cow doesn't miscarry; their cow gives birth, and it is never barren.

verses.latin: Emittunt quasi gregem parvulos suos: et infantes eorum exsultant ludendo.
verses.english: They send out their little children like a flock of sheep, and their children skip and dance with joy.

verses.latin: Tenent tympanum et citharam, et gaudent ad sonitum organi.
verses.english: They celebrate with tambourines and harps, and they rejoice at the sound of the pipe organ.

verses.latin: Ducunt in bonis dies suos, et in puncto ad inferos descendunt.
verses.english: They spend their days in prosperity and happiness, and in an instant, they descend into the grave.

verses.latin: Qui dixerunt Deo: Recede a nobis: et scientiam viarum tuarum nolumus.
verses.english: These are the ones who said to God: 'Get away from us! We do not want to know your ways!'

verses.latin: Quid est Omnipotens, ut serviamus ei? et quid nobis prodest si oraverimus illum?
verses.english: Who is the Almighty God, that we should serve Him? What benefit would we gain if we prayed to Him?

verses.latin: Ecce non in manu eorum sunt bona sua: consilium impiorum longe sit a me.
verses.english: Look, their good fortune does not come from their own hands, and may the counsel of the wicked be far from me.

verses.latin: Quam sæpe lucerna impiorum extinguitur, et supervenit illis calamitas? Quam sæpe dividit dolores in ira sua?
verses.english: How often does the lamp of the wicked truly go out, and calamity come upon them? How often does God distribute sorrows in His anger to them?

verses.latin: Sunt sicut paleæ ante faciem venti, et sicut favilla quam turbo rapit.
verses.english: Are they truly like chaff before the wind, and like dust that a whirlwind carries away?

verses.latin: Deus reservavit filiis illius dolorem patris. Reddat ei, et sciat.
verses.english: You say God saves the punishment of a man for his children. Let Him punish the man himself, so that the man knows he is being judged.

verses.latin: Videant oculi ejus interfectionem suam, et de furore Omnipotentis bibat.
verses.english: Let his own eyes see his destruction, and let him drink deeply of the Almighty's fury.

verses.latin: Quid enim ad eum pertinet de domo sua post se: et si numerus mensium ejus dimidiatus fuerit?
verses.english: For what does the wicked man care about his household after he's gone, even if the number of his months is cut in half?

verses.latin: Numquid doctrinam Dei quispiam docere potest, qui excelsos judicat?
verses.english: Can anyone teach God anything, when He judges even those who are exalted?

verses.latin: Iste moritur robustus et sanus, dives et felix.
verses.english: One man dies strong and healthy, rich and content.

verses.latin: Viscera ejus plena sunt adipe, et medullis ossa ejus irrigantur.
verses.english: His body is well-fed and full of vigor, and his bones are full of strong marrow.

verses.latin: Et alter moritur in amaritudine animæ, absque ullis opibus:
verses.english: And another man dies with a bitter soul, having never known prosperity.

verses.latin: Et simul in pulvere dormient, et vermes operient eos.
verses.english: And both of them will lie down together in the dust, and worms will cover them.

verses.latin: Certe novi cogitationes vestras, et sententias, quibus me opprimere contenditis.
verses.english: I certainly know your thoughts, and the judgments by which you try to crush me.

verses.latin: Dicetis enim: Ubi est domus principis? et ubi tabernacula impiorum?
verses.english: For you will say: 'Where is the house of the great man? And where are the tents of the wicked?'

verses.latin: Interrogate quemlibet de viatoribus, et quæ cognoverunt ab eis discite.
verses.english: Ask anyone who travels widely, and learn from them what they have observed.

verses.latin: Quia in diem perditionis servatur malus: et ad diem furoris ducitur.
verses.english: They will tell you that the evil person is kept safe until the day of their destruction, and is led to the day of wrath.

verses.latin: Quis arguet coram eo viam ejus? et quis faciet ei quod gessit?
verses.english: Who will directly confront a wicked man about his lifestyle? And who will repay him for what he has done?

verses.latin: Et ipse ad sepulchra ducetur, et in congerie mortuorum vigilabit.
verses.english: Even he himself is carried to his grave, and will remain among the gathered dead.

verses.latin: Dulcis fuit illi glarea Cocyti: et post eum omnes homines trahentur, et ante eum innumerabiles.
verses.english: The dust of the grave will be sweet to him when he dies without suffering. And after him, all men are drawn to death, just as countless others have gone before him.

verses.latin: Quomodo igitur consolamini me frustra, cum responsio vestra repugnare probationi?
verses.english: How then can you comfort me in such a useless way, when your answer clearly contradicts the evidence?

verses.latin: Respondens autem Eliphaz Themanites, dixit:
verses.english: And Eliphaz the Temanite then answered, saying:

verses.latin: Numquid Deo prodesse potest homo, cum sapiens sibi ipsi sit utilis?
verses.english: “Can any human being really benefit God, even when a wise man is useful only to himself?

verses.latin: Quid prodest Altissimo, si justus fueris? aut quid illi commodum est, si immaculata fuerit via tua?
verses.english: What benefit is it to the Most High if you are righteous, or what advantage does He gain if your ways are pure?

verses.latin: Numquid propter timorem tuum arguet te, et veniet tecum in judicium?
verses.english: Is it because of your reverence that He judges you, bringing you into judgment?

verses.latin: Nonne malitia tua plurima est, et infinitæ iniquitates tuæ?
verses.english: Is it not rather that your wickedness is immense, and your iniquities are boundless?

verses.latin: Sublata enim veste fratrum tuorum pignore, et nudos spoliasti.
verses.english: For you took your brothers’ garments as security for loans, and you left the truly naked without their coverings.

verses.latin: Aquam lasso non dedisti, et esurienti denegasti panem.
verses.english: You gave no water to the weary, and you withheld bread from the hungry.

verses.latin: In fortitudine brachii tui possidebas terram, et potentissimus obtinebas eam.
verses.english: By the mere strength of your arm, you took possession of the land, and as the most powerful, you seized it for yourself.

verses.latin: Viduae dimisisti vacuas, et pupillorum brachia contrivisti.
verses.english: You sent widows away with nothing, and you crushed the hopes and strength of orphans.

verses.latin: Propterea circumdederunt te laquei, et conturbat te subita formido.
verses.english: Because of this, traps surround you, and sudden terror utterly confuses you.

verses.latin: Aut si scire volueris, tenebrae, et non videbis, et abundans aquarum te operiet.
verses.english: Or if you want to know what’s coming, it’s darkness, and you will see nothing; a deluge of waters will completely overwhelm you.

verses.latin: Numquid non Deus in excelsis? et stellarum verticem cernis, quam excelsae sunt?
verses.english: Is God not truly in the highest heavens? Just look at the furthest stars; can you not see how immensely high they are?

verses.latin: Et dicis: Quid enim novit Deus? et si per tenebras judicat?
verses.english: Yet you then say, “What could God possibly know? Can He truly judge through the darkness?”

verses.latin: Nubes latibulum ejus, et non considerat nostra, et circa cardines caeli perambulat.
verses.english: You think the clouds hide Him, that He does not consider our affairs, and that He merely walks around the edges of the universe.

verses.latin: Semitam saeculi custodi, quam calcaverunt viri iniqui:
verses.english: Are you following the ancient path that wicked men have walked?

verses.latin: qui sublati sunt ante tempus suum, et fluvius irruit fundamentum eorum:
verses.english: Those men were swept away before their time, and a sudden flood washed away their very foundation.

verses.latin: Qui dicebant Deo: Recede a nobis: et Altissimi quasi nihil faciebant:
verses.english: They were the ones who said to God, “Leave us alone!” and treated the Most High as though He were utterly insignificant.

verses.latin: Cum ille implesset domos eorum bonis, quorum procul sit cogitatio ab illo.
verses.english: Even though He had filled their homes with good things, they rejected Him. May such a thought be far from you.

verses.latin: Videbunt justi, et laetabuntur: et innocens subsannabit eos.
verses.english: The righteous will see this and rejoice, and the innocent will scorn these wicked men, saying:

verses.latin: Nonne succisus est qui steterat, et reliquias eorum comedit ignis?
verses.english: “Has not the one who stood against God been utterly cut down, and has not fire consumed what remained of them?”

verses.latin: Acquiesce igitur ei, et habeto pacem: et per haec habebis fructus optimos.
verses.english: Therefore, submit yourself to Him and live in peace; through this, you will attain the most excellent rewards.

verses.latin: Suscipe ex ore illius legem, et pone sermones ejus in corde tuo.
verses.english: Receive His divine law from His own mouth, and engrave His very words upon your heart.

verses.latin: Si reversus fueris ad Omnipotentem, aedificaberis, et longe facies iniquitatem a tabernaculo tuo.
verses.english: If you truly return to the Almighty, you will be restored; and you will remove all wickedness far from your dwelling.

verses.latin: Dabit pro luto aurum, et pro silicibus torrentis, aurum Ophir.
verses.english: He will give you gold instead of dust, and for the ordinary stones of the riverbed, He will give you the finest gold of Ophir.

verses.latin: Et erit Omnipotens contra hostes tuos, et argentum coacervabitur tibi.
verses.english: And the Almighty Himself will stand against your enemies, and silver will be accumulated in abundance for you.

verses.latin: Tunc super Omnipotentem deliciis afflueris, et elevabis ad Deum faciem tuam.
verses.english: Then you will find your greatest delight in the Almighty, and you will confidently lift your face to God.

verses.latin: Rogabis eum, et exaudiet te: et vota tua reddes.
verses.english: You will call upon Him in prayer, and He will hear you; then you will fulfill the vows you made.

verses.latin: Decernes rem, et veniet tibi: et in viis tuis splendor apparebit.
verses.english: You will make a decree, and it will be established for you; and a radiant light will shine upon your path.

verses.latin: Humiliatum fueris, dices: Superbus fui: et qui demissos habuerit oculos, salvabitur.
verses.english: If you have been humbled, you will say, “I was proud,” and the one who casts down his eyes in humility will be saved.

verses.latin: Salvabitur innocens, et salvabitur in munditia manuum suarum.
verses.english: The innocent person will be saved, and he will be delivered through the purity of his hands.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Iob ait:
verses.english: Job then spoke and said:

verses.latin: Nunc quoque amaritudo mea rebellis est, et plaga mea aggravata super gemitum meum.
verses.english: Even now, my bitterness rises up against me, and my suffering is made heavier by my own groans.

verses.latin: Quis mihi tribuat ut cognoscam, et inveniam illum, et veniam usque ad thronum eius?
verses.english: If only someone would grant me to know Him, to find Him, so I could come all the way to His very throne.

verses.latin: Ponam coram eo judicium, et os meum replebo increpationibus.
verses.english: I would lay out my case before Him, and fill my mouth with arguments against what has happened.

verses.latin: Scirem verba quae responderet mihi, et intelligerem quid loqueretur mihi.
verses.english: I would know what words He would use to answer me, and I would understand what He would say to me.

verses.latin: Num multis sermonibus aget contra me? et ipse mecum contendens audiet.
verses.english: Would He argue against me with many words? No, He Himself, contending with me, would listen.

verses.latin: Ibi aequus judex loqueretur mecum, et liberarer procul a judicio meo.
verses.english: There, a just Judge would speak with me, and I would be set free from my own judgment of myself.

verses.latin: Si ad orientem iero, non est ibi: si ad occidentem, non intelligam eum.
verses.english: If I go to the east, He is not there; if to the west, I would not perceive Him.

verses.latin: Si ad sinistram, quomodo potest esse, non apprehendam: si ad dexteram, non conspiciam illum.
verses.english: If to the north (the left hand), how can He be there? I will not grasp Him. If to the south (the right hand), I will not catch sight of Him.

verses.latin: Ipse vero scit viam meam, et probavit me quasi aurum quod per ignem purgatur.
verses.english: But He Himself knows my way. He has tested me like gold, which is purified through fire.

verses.latin: Vestigia eius secutus est pes meus, viam eius custodivi, et non declinavi ex ea.
verses.english: My foot has followed His footsteps. I have kept His way and have not turned aside from it.

verses.latin: A mandatis labiorum eius non recessi, et in sinu meo abscondi verba oris eius.
verses.english: From the commands of His lips, I have not turned away. I have hidden the words of His mouth in my heart.

verses.latin: Ipse enim solus est, et nemo avertere potest cogitationem eius: et anima eius, quodcumque voluit, hoc fecit.
verses.english: For He alone is God, and no one can turn aside His thoughts. Whatever His soul desires, that He does.

verses.latin: Et cum compleverit me, tunc consummabit: et multa talia sunt apud eum.
verses.english: And when He completes what He wills for me, then He will finish it. Many such things are with Him.

verses.latin: Et propter hoc conturbatus sum a facie eius, et considerans expavesco.
verses.english: And because of this, I am troubled before His presence. When I consider it, I am filled with dread.

verses.latin: Deus mollivit cor meum, et omnipotens conturbavit me.
verses.english: God has softened my heart, but the Almighty has also troubled me.

verses.latin: Non enim periere tenebrae super faciem meam, et operuit caligo faciem meam.
verses.english: For the darkness has not vanished from before my face, and deep gloom has covered my face.

verses.latin: Cur non sint abscondita tempora a Deo, et illi qui novunt eum, ignorabunt dies illius?
verses.english: Why doesn't God keep His appointed times hidden? And why do those who know Him not understand His specific days of judgment?

verses.latin: Alii terminos transtulerunt, diripuerunt greges, et paverunt.
verses.english: There are wicked men who move boundary markers to steal land. They violently seize flocks of animals and then feed themselves from them.

verses.latin: Asinum et bovem pupillorum abegerunt, et camelum viduae tulerunt pignori.
verses.english: They drive away the donkeys and oxen that belong to orphans, and they take the camel of a widow as collateral, seizing it for themselves.

verses.latin: Subverterunt pauperem de via, et simul elegerunt omnes mansueti terrae.
verses.english: They push the poor off the path. All the meek and humble people of the land are forced to hide from them together.

verses.latin: Alii quasi onagri in deserto egressi sunt ad opus suum: vigilantes ad praedam, et terra eorum praebuit illis panem in solitudine.
verses.english: Look! Like wild donkeys in the desert, the poor go out to their work, diligently watching for any food they can find. The desolate land itself provides them with their sustenance in their loneliness.

verses.latin: Agrum non suum demessura est, et vineam pauperis calumniator detraxit.
verses.english: These wicked men harvest a field that is not theirs. A slanderer will also strip the vineyard of a poor person.

verses.latin: Nudi et absque vestimento pernoctant, et non est illis operimentum in frigore.
verses.english: The poor spend the night naked and without clothing, and they have no covering against the biting cold.

verses.latin: Qui imbribus montium perfusi sunt, et non habentes refugium, amplexati sunt silicem.
verses.english: They are drenched by the mountain rains, and having no shelter, they cling to the bare rock for warmth and protection.

verses.latin: Rapuerunt pupillum ab ubere, et pallium pauperis pignori tulerunt.
verses.english: The wicked steal an orphan from its mother's breast, and they take the cloak of the poor as a pledge, leaving them exposed and destitute.

verses.latin: Nudi et indumentis carentes ambulabant, et esurientes portabant spicas.
verses.english: So the poor walk around naked and lacking clothing, and, being hungry, they carry sheaves of grain, having gleaned what little they can.

verses.latin: Inter acervos eorum meridiati sunt, qui calcatis torcularibus sitierunt.
verses.english: They labor at noon among the piles of grain, and though they have trodden the wine presses, they still suffer thirst.

verses.latin: De civitatibus singulis ingemuerunt, et anima vulneratorum clamavit: et Deus non eorum permisit succurrere.
verses.english: From out of individual cities, groans rise up. The souls of the wounded cry out for justice, yet God does not appear to permit anyone to come to their aid.

verses.latin: Ipsi sunt lucis inimici, nescierunt vias ejus, nec manserunt in semitis ejus.
verses.english: These wicked men are enemies of the light. They do not know its ways, nor do they stay in its paths.

verses.latin: Mane primo surgit homicida, interficit egenum et pauperem, et nocte erit quasi fur.
verses.english: The murderer rises early in the morning. He kills the needy and the poor, and by night, he becomes like a common thief.

verses.latin: Oculum adulteri observavit caligo, dicens: Non me videbit oculus. Et operuit faciem suam.
verses.english: The eye of the adulterer watches for the deep darkness, saying to himself, 'No eye will see me.' And he covers his face.

verses.latin: In tenebris effodiunt domos, sicut sibi proposuerunt in die, et ignorabunt lucem.
verses.english: In the darkness, these criminals break into houses as they planned to do in daylight. They will never know the light.

verses.latin: Si subito apparuerit aurora, arbitrantur umbram mortis: et sic in tenebris quasi in luce versantur.
verses.english: If the dawn should suddenly appear, they consider it the very shadow of death. So it is that they spend their time dwelling in darkness as if it were their light.

verses.latin: Levis est super faciem aquae: maledicta sit pars ejus in terra, nec operetur amplius in via vinearum.
verses.english: This wicked man is swift to act on the surface of the earth. May his portion on earth be cursed, and may he no longer work his evil deeds in the path leading to the vineyards.

verses.latin: Ad siccitatem et calorem transibit ab aquis nivium, et ad inferos eos qui peccaverunt.
verses.english: Just as drought and heat consume snow water, so too will those who have sinned be swept away to the underworld.

verses.latin: Obliviscatur eum misericordia, dulcedo illius vermis non memor sit, sed conteratur quasi lignum iniquitas ejus.
verses.english: May mercy completely forget such a man. May the worms not even remember his body's sweetness. Instead, let his wickedness be broken apart like decaying wood.

verses.latin: Pascitur sterilis, et non parit: et viduae non bene facit.
verses.english: This wicked man preys on the barren woman who cannot bear children, and he does not do any good for the widow.

verses.latin: Detraxit fortes in fortitudine sua, et cum steterit, non credet vitae suae.
verses.english: By his own strength, this man pulls down even the mighty. When he stands, he has no lasting belief in his own life, for his end is coming.

verses.latin: Producet eum ad securitatem, et fulcietur ibi: et oculi ejus respiciunt in vias eorum.
verses.english: God seems to lead him to a false sense of security, and he will be sustained there for a time. Yet, God's eyes constantly watch all of their wicked ways.

verses.latin: Elevati sunt ad modicum, et non subsistent: et humiliabuntur sicut omnia, et auferentur, et sicut summum stipulae corruent.
verses.english: The wicked are exalted for a short time, but they will not truly endure. They will be brought low like all other mortals, taken away, and they will collapse like the tops of withered grain stalks.

verses.latin: Et si hoc non est, quis me reprehendere potest, manifestamque facere mendacium meum?
verses.english: If all of this is not true, then who can refute me and clearly demonstrate that my words are a lie?

verses.latin: Respondens Bildad Suhites, dixit:
verses.english: Bildad the Shuhite replied to Job by saying this:

verses.latin: Quid habet cum eo potestas et terror, qui facit concordiam in sublimibus suis?
verses.english: What power and terror God possesses! He is the One who establishes perfect order throughout all the highest heavens.

verses.latin: Numquid est numerus militum ejus? et super quem non orietur lumen illius?
verses.english: Can anyone number God’s armies in the heavens? And is there anyone whom His light does not reach?

verses.latin: Quomodo justificari potest homo comparatus Deo? aut quomodo mundus erit natus de muliere?
verses.english: How can any human claim to be righteous when compared to God? Or how can anyone born from a woman truly be pure and clean?

verses.latin: Ecce luna etiam non splendet, et stellae non sunt mundae in conspectu ejus:
verses.english: Behold, even the moon itself does not shine brightly enough in His presence, and even the stars are not pure in His sight.

verses.latin: Quanto magis homo putredo, et filius hominis vermis?
verses.english: How much more, then, is a human being mere decay, and the son of man nothing more than a worm?

verses.latin: Respondens autem Job, dixit:
verses.english: But Job responded and said:

verses.latin: Cui auxiliatus es? forsitan imbecilli? et brachium fortitudinis roborasti?
verses.english: “Who have you helped? Was it perhaps the weak? And did you strengthen the arm of the powerful?”

verses.latin: Cui dedisti consilium? forsitan non habenti sapientiam? et prudentiam plurimam ostendisti?
verses.english: “To whom did you give counsel? Was it perhaps to one lacking wisdom? And have you shown much prudence?”

verses.latin: Quem docere voluisti? numquid non eum qui spiritum habet?
verses.english: “Whom did you wish to teach? Is it not the one who already has spirit and understanding?”

verses.latin: Ecce gigantes gemunt sub aquis, et qui habitant cum eis.
verses.english: “Look, the mighty ones groan beneath the waters, along with those who dwell with them.”

verses.latin: Nudus est infernus coram illo, et nullum est operimentum perditioni.
verses.english: “The underworld is exposed before Him, and there is no covering for the place of destruction.”

verses.latin: Extendit aquilonem super vacuum, et appendit terram super nihilum.
verses.english: “He stretches out the north over the void, and He hangs the earth upon nothing in the vastness of the universe.”

verses.latin: Ligans aquas in nubibus suis, ut non erumpant pariter deorsum.
verses.english: “He binds the waters in His clouds, so that they do not burst forth all at once downwards as a flood.”

verses.latin: Comprehendit faciem solii ejus, extendens super illud nubem suam.
verses.english: “He grasps the face of His throne, spreading His cloud over it, veiling His majesty.”

verses.latin: Terminum circumdedit aquis, usque dum lux et tenebræ finiantur.
verses.english: “He has drawn a boundary around the waters, reaching to the very edge where light and darkness meet and end in the cosmos.”

verses.latin: Columnæ cæli contremiscunt, et pavent ad nutum ejus.
verses.english: “The very pillars of the universe tremble and are terrified at His command.”

verses.latin: In fortitudine sua perturbavit maria, et intelligentia sua percussit superbum.
verses.english: “By His strength, He stirs up the seas, and by His understanding, He strikes down any proud, rebellious force.”

verses.latin: Spiritus ejus ornavit cælos, et obstetricante manu ejus eductus est Coluber tortuosus.
verses.english: “His Spirit adorned the skies with constellations and stars, and by His guiding hand, the twisted Serpent—representing cosmic evil—was brought forth into its appointed place.”

verses.latin: Ecce hæc sicut parvulæ partes viarum ejus: et cum susurru verborum ejus audivimus. Quis enim poterit tonitruum magnitudinis ejus intueri?
verses.english: “Look, these are but the merest fragments of His ways; we have heard only a whisper of His words. For who can truly grasp and contemplate the thunder of His immeasurable greatness?”

verses.latin: Assumpsit quoque Job parabolam suam, et dixit:
verses.english: Job then began his solemn discourse again, and said:

verses.latin: Vivat Deus, qui abstulit judicium meum, et Omnipotens, qui ad amaritudinem adduxit animam meam;
verses.english: "As surely as God lives, He is the One who has refused to judge my case fairly, and the Almighty is the One who has brought such bitterness to my soul."

verses.latin: Quia donec superest halitus in me, et spiritus Dei in naribus meis,
verses.english: "For as long as there is breath in me, and as long as the life-giving Spirit of God is in my nostrils,"

verses.latin: Non loquentur labia mea iniquitatem, nec lingua mea meditabitur mendacium.
verses.english: "My lips will not speak injustice, nor will my tongue utter any lie."

verses.latin: Absit a me ut justificem vos! usque ad unum animum meum non relinquam.
verses.english: "Far be it from me to ever declare you in the right! Until my very last breath, I will not give up my integrity."

verses.latin: Justificationem meam, quam cœpi, non derelinquam; neque enim agnosco quod inique egerim.
verses.english: "I will never abandon the righteous defense I have begun to make for myself. Indeed, I do not acknowledge that I have acted unjustly."

verses.latin: Sit ut inimicus meus quasi impius, et adversarius meus quasi iniquus.
verses.english: "May my enemy suffer the fate of the wicked, and may my adversary be treated like the unjust."

verses.latin: Quæ enim est spes hypocritæ, si rapuerit aliquid, et non liberet Deus animam ejus?
verses.english: "For what hope does the hypocrite have, if he has gained something by violence, yet God does not deliver his soul from judgment?"

verses.latin: Numquid exaudiet Deus clamorem ejus, cum incubuerit super eum angustia?
verses.english: "Will God truly hear his cry when distress overwhelms him?"

verses.latin: Aut numquid in Omnipotente delectabitur, et invocabit Deum in omni tempore?
verses.english: "Or will he take delight in the Almighty, or call upon God at all times?"

verses.latin: Docebo vos manu Dei quid sit, et quæ sint apud Omnipotentem non abscondam.
verses.english: "I will teach you about what God's hand does, and I will not hide from you what belongs to the Almighty."

verses.latin: Ecce vos omnes nostis; et quid frustra loquimini?
verses.english: "Behold, you all already know this; why then do you speak in vain?"

verses.latin: Hæc est pars hominis impii apud Deum, et hæreditas violentorum quam de Omnipotente suscipient.
verses.english: "This is the portion of the wicked person from God, and it is the inheritance of violent individuals that they will receive from the Almighty."

verses.latin: Si multiplicati fuerint filii ejus, in gladio erunt; et nepotes ejus non saturabuntur pane.
verses.english: "If his children multiply, they will be destined for the sword; and his descendants will never have enough bread to satisfy them."

verses.latin: Qui reliqui fuerint ex eo sepelientur in interitu, et viduæ ejus non plorabunt.
verses.english: "Those who are left of his family will be buried by a plague, and his widows will not weep for them."

verses.latin: Si congerit quasi terram argentum, et sicut lutum præparat vestimenta;
verses.english: "If he piles up silver as if it were mere dust from the earth, and if he prepares garments as if they were mud;"

verses.latin: Præparabit quidem, sed justus vestietur illis, et argentum innocens dividet.
verses.english: "He may prepare them indeed, but the righteous person will wear those garments, and the innocent will divide his silver."

verses.latin: Ædificavit quasi tinea domum suam, et sicut custos fecit tugurium.
verses.english: "He built his house like a moth's nest, and he made his shelter like a temporary booth."

verses.latin: Dives cum dormierit, nihil secum auferet; aperiet oculos suos, et nihil inveniet.
verses.english: "When the rich man lies down in death, he will take nothing with him. He will open his eyes in the afterlife, and find that he has nothing."

verses.latin: Apprehendet eum quasi aqua inopia, et in nocte furabitur turbo.
verses.english: "Misfortune will seize him like a flood of water, and a whirlwind will snatch him away in the night."

verses.latin: Tollet eum ventus urens, et auferet, et velut turbo rapiet de loco suo.
verses.english: "A scorching wind will carry him off and sweep him away; like a whirlwind, it will snatch him from his place."

verses.latin: Et mittet super eum, et non parcet; de manu ejus fugiens fugiet.
verses.english: "God will hurl calamity upon him without mercy; he will desperately try to flee from God's hand."

verses.latin: Plaudent super eum homines manibus suis, et sibilabunt de loco suo.
verses.english: "People will clap their hands at him in scorn, and hiss him away from his place."

verses.latin: Argento quidem est venarum suarum principium, et auro locus est in quo conflatur.
verses.english:
Indeed, silver has its origin within specific veins in the earth,
and gold has a designated place where it is melted and purified.

verses.latin: Ferrum de terra tollitur, et lapis solutus calore in aes vertitur.
verses.english:
Iron is extracted from the earth,
and stone, when dissolved by intense heat, is transformed into copper.

verses.latin: Tempus posuit rebus: et finem dedit universis. Lapidem quoque caliginis et umbræ perquirit, et in omne tempus.
verses.english:
Man himself sets limits to the dark earth, exploring its deep places,
and he pursues all things to their ultimate end.
He also unearths the precious stones from utter darkness and the shadow of death, enduringly searching.

verses.latin: Dirigit in flumen rivos: et abscondita revelat in luce.
verses.english:
Man directs streams of water underground to his workings,
and he brings what was hidden deep within the earth out into the light.

verses.latin: Terra de qua oriebatur panis, in profundum suffossa est sicut ignis.
verses.english:
The very earth from which our bread comes is undermined far beneath the surface,
turned over and searched out as if by the intensity of fire.

verses.latin: Locus sapphiri lapides ejus: et glebae illius aurum.
verses.english:
Its stones are the source of sapphires,
and its very soil yields gold.

verses.latin: Semita ignoravit eam avis, nec intuitus est oculus vulturis.
verses.english:
No bird of prey knows the path to these depths,
nor has the keen eye of a vulture ever seen such places.

verses.latin: Non calcaverunt eam filii superbi, nec transivit per eam leaena.
verses.english:
No proud, mighty animal has ever walked this path,
nor has a lioness passed through these passages.

verses.latin: In silice manum suam extendit, subvertit montes a radicibus.
verses.english:
Man stretches out his hand against the flinty rock,
and he tunnels beneath mountains, overturning them from their foundations.

verses.latin: In petris rivos excidit, et omne pretiosum videt oculus ejus.
verses.english:
He carves out tunnels and channels through the rocks,
and his eye spots every precious thing hidden within them.

verses.latin: Profunda fluviorum scrutatus est, et abscondita produxit in lucem.
verses.english:
He has explored the depths of rivers,
and he brings forth hidden treasures into the light.

verses.latin: Sapientia vero ubi invenitur? et quis est locus intelligentiæ?
verses.english:
But true wisdom, where can it be found?
And where is the dwelling place of true understanding?

verses.latin: Nescit homo pretium ejus, nec invenitur in terra suaviter viventium.
verses.english:
Mankind does not know its true value,
nor can it be found in the land of those who live in ease and comfort.

verses.latin: Abyssus dicit: Non est in me: et mare loquitur: Non est mecum.
verses.english:
The great deep says: 'It is not hidden within me,'
and the sea proclaims: 'It is not found with me.'

verses.latin: Non dabitur aurum obrizum pro ea, nec appendetur argentum in commutatione ejus.
verses.english:
No amount of purest refined gold can buy it,
nor can silver be weighed out as a fair exchange for it.

verses.latin: Non comparabitur tinctis Indiæ coloribus, nec lapide sardonycho pretiosissimo, vel sapphiro.
verses.english:
It cannot be purchased with the finest colored gems from India,
nor can it be compared to the most precious sardonyx or sapphire.

verses.latin: Non æquabitur ei aurum, vel vitrum: nec commutabuntur pro ea vasa auri.
verses.english:
Neither gold nor precious crystal can be compared to it,
nor can vessels made of pure gold be given in exchange for it.

verses.latin: Excelsa et eminentia non memorabuntur comparatione ejus: trahitur autem sapientia de occultis.
verses.english:
Coral and crystal are not even mentioned in comparison to it;
true wisdom, however, is drawn not from these hidden earthly places, but from divine mysteries.

verses.latin: Non æquabitur ei topazius Æthiopiæ, nec tinctissimis comparabitur coloribus.
verses.english:
The finest topaz from Ethiopia cannot equal it,
nor can it be compared to the most intensely colored dyes.

verses.latin: Unde ergo sapientia venit? et quis est locus intelligentiæ?
verses.english:
So, where then does wisdom truly come from?
And what is the actual place where understanding resides?

verses.latin: Abscondita est ab oculis omnium viventium: et a volucribus cæli celata est.
verses.english:
It is hidden from the sight of all living beings,
and it is concealed even from the birds of the sky.

verses.latin: Perditio et Mors dixerunt: Auribus nostris audivimus famam ejus.
verses.english:
The realms of Destruction and Death themselves have declared:
'We have only heard a rumor of its existence with our own ears.'

verses.latin: Deus intelligit viam ejus, et ipse novit locum illius.
verses.english:
God alone fully comprehends its path,
and He Himself knows its true location.

verses.latin: Ipse enim respicit usque ad fines mundi: et omnia quæ sub cælo sunt, respicit.
verses.english:
For He looks upon all things, even to the very ends of the universe,
and He observes everything that exists under the sky.

verses.latin: Qui fecit ventis pondus: et aquas appendit in mensura.
verses.english:
It is He who gave the winds their proper force and weight,
and who measured out the waters with exact precision.

verses.latin: Quando posuit pluviis legem, et viam procellis sonantibus.
verses.english:
It was He who established the laws for the rain,
and who set the path for the roaring storms.

verses.latin: Tunc vidit illam, et enarravit, et præparavit, et investigavit.
verses.english:
Then He Himself saw wisdom,
He declared its nature, He prepared its dwelling, and He completely understood it.

verses.latin: Et homini dixit: Ecce timor Domini ipsa est sapientia, et recedere a malo intelligentia.
Addidit quoque Iob assumens parabolam suam, et dixit:
verses.english: Job then continued his lament, speaking these words:

verses.latin: Quis mihi tribuat ut sim juxta menses pristinos, secundum dies quibus Deus custodiebat me?
verses.english: Oh, if only I could return to how it was in past months, to those days when God protected me!

verses.latin: Quando splendebat lucerna ejus super caput meum, et ad lumen ejus ambulabam in tenebris?
verses.english: When His lamp shone bright above my head, and I walked through the darkness by His light?

verses.latin: Sicut fui in diebus adolescentiae meae, quando secreto Deus erat in tabernaculo meo?
verses.english: As I was in the days of my youth, when God's secret presence was with me in my tent?

verses.latin: Quando erat Omnipotens mecum, et circuibant filii mei in circuitu meo?
verses.english: When the Almighty was with me, and my children gathered around me?

verses.latin: Quando lavabam pedes meos butyro, et petra fundebat mihi rivos olei?
verses.english: When I would wash my feet in cream, and the rock itself would pour out streams of olive oil for me?

verses.latin: Quando procedebam ad portam civitatis, et in platea parabam cathedram meam?
verses.english: When I went out to the city gate, and set up my seat in the public square?

verses.latin: Videbant me juvenes et abscondebantur, et senes surgebanstes adorabant.
verses.english: The young men saw me and would step aside respectfully, and the elders would rise and show reverence.

verses.latin: Principes cessabant loqui, et digitum ori suo apponebant.
verses.english: The leaders would stop speaking, and place a finger over their mouths in silence.

verses.latin: Vocem ducum tacere faciebant, et lingua eorum palato suo adhaerebat.
verses.english: They would make the voices of the noblemen fall silent, and their tongues would stick to the roof of their mouths.

verses.latin: Auris audiens beatificabat me, et oculus videns testimonium reddebat mihi:
verses.english: Every ear that heard me would bless me, and every eye that saw me bore witness in my favor:

verses.latin: Quia liberabam pauperem vociferantem, et pupillum cui non erat adjutor.
verses.english: Because I rescued the poor person who cried out for help, and the orphan who had no one to assist him.

verses.latin: Benedictio perituri super me veniebat, et cor viduae consolatus sum.
verses.english: The blessing of the one about to perish came upon me, and I brought comfort to the heart of the widow.

verses.latin: Justitia indutus sum, et vestivit me sicut vestimento et diadema judicio meo.
verses.english: I clothed myself with righteousness, and it covered me like a garment; my justice was like a royal diadem.

verses.latin: Oculus fui caeco, et pes claudo.
verses.english: I was eyes for the blind, and feet for the lame.

verses.latin: Pater eram pauperum, et causam quam nesciebam diligentissime investigabam.
verses.english: I was a father to the poor, and I diligently investigated any case I did not understand fully.

verses.latin: Conterebam molas iniqui, et de dentibus illius auferebam praedam.
verses.english: I crushed the jaws of the wicked, and snatched the prey from between his teeth.

verses.latin: Et dixi: In nidulo meo moriar, et sicut palma multiplicabo dies.
verses.english: And I said to myself: “I will die in my own nest, and I will multiply my days like the palm tree.”

verses.latin: Radix mea aperta est secus aquas, et ros morabitur in messe mea.
verses.english: My root was spread out beside the waters, and the dew would remain on my harvest.

verses.latin: Gloria mea semper innovabitur, et arcus meus in manu mea restaurabitur.
verses.english: My glory would always be renewed, and my bow in my hand would be restored to strength.

verses.latin: Me audientes sperabant, et intendentes tacebant ad consilium meum.
verses.english: Those who heard me waited patiently, and they kept silent, paying close attention to my counsel.

verses.latin: Post verba illius non addam: et super illos stillabat eloquium meum.
verses.english: After my words, they would not add anything further; and my discourse would fall upon them like gentle rain.

verses.latin: Et expectabant me sicut pluviam, et os suum aperiebant quasi ad imbrem serotinum.
verses.english: They waited for me as they would for the rain, and they opened their mouths wide as for the late spring showers.

verses.latin: Si quando ridebam ad illos, non credebant, et lux vultus mei cadebat in terram.
verses.english: If I ever smiled at them, they could hardly believe it, and the light of my countenance settled upon them.

verses.latin: Si voluissem ire ad illos, sedebam primus: et cum sederem quasi rex, circumstante exercitu, eram maestorum consolator.
verses.english: If I wanted to go to them, I would sit as the first among them; and when I sat, it was like a king surrounded by his army, and I was a comforter to those who mourned.

verses.latin: Nunc autem derident me juniores diebus, quorum non dignabar patres meos ponere cum canibus gregis mei:
verses.english: But now, those who are younger than I openly ridicule me. Their own fathers I would not have allowed to even sit with the sheepdogs of my own flock.

verses.latin: quorum virtus manuum erat et nihil erat, et vita eorum reputabatur sordes.
verses.english: The physical strength of their hands was entirely useless; their whole life was considered nothing but refuse and filth.

verses.latin: Egestate indigi, et fame steriles, qui rodebant in solitudine, squalentes calamitate et miseria.
verses.english: They were utterly destitute and barren from hunger, gnawing on roots and scraps in the wilderness, wasting away with calamity and misery.

verses.latin: Et mandebant herbas, et arborum cortices, et radix juniperorum erat cibus eorum.
verses.english: They chewed on wild herbs and tree bark, and juniper roots were all the food they had.

verses.latin: De mediis vallibus arripiebantur, et juxta speluncas terræ, et super acervos sabuli commorabantur.
verses.english: They were driven away from settled places into the middle of ravines, living in caves carved into the earth and among piles of sand.

verses.latin: In antris et cavernis petrarum, inter spinas et sub sentibus, jacebant.
verses.english: They lay hidden in the crevices and caverns of the rocks, among thorns and under nettles.

verses.latin: Qui inter spinas murire, et sub sentibus latere consueverant.
verses.english: They were accustomed to making animal-like noises among the thorns and hiding under the nettles.

verses.latin: Filii stultorum et ignobilium, et absque nomine terræ penitus deleti.
verses.english: They were the sons of fools and nobodies, utterly erased from the memory of the land, without any name or standing.

verses.latin: Nunc in eorum canticum versus sum, et factus sum eis quasi ad proverbium.
verses.english: Now, I have become the subject of their mocking songs; I have become like a proverb or a byword to them.

verses.latin: Abominantur me, et longe fugiunt a me, et faciem meam conspuere non verentur.
verses.english: They detest me and flee far from my presence; they do not hesitate to spit in my face.

verses.latin: Quia pharetram meam laxavit, et afflixit me, et frenum suum effregerunt.
verses.english: Because God has loosened my bowstring and afflicted me, they have also broken the restraint they once had against me.

verses.latin: Ad dexteram pariter consurgunt, pedes meos subvertunt, et complantant quasi fluctibus semitas meas.
verses.english: On my right, they rise up together, tripping my feet and barricading my pathways as if with surging waves.

verses.latin: Dissipant semitas meas, insidiantur mihi, et obtinent victoriam, et non est qui adjuvet.
verses.english: They destroy my paths, they lie in ambush for me, and they gain the victory, and there is no one who will help me.

verses.latin: Quasi rupto muro et aperta janua, irruerunt super me, et sicut vastata civitate, irrumpunt mihi.
verses.english: Like a breach in a wall or an open gate, they have rushed in upon me; they break into my life as if it were a devastated city.

verses.latin: Redactæ sunt in nihilum viæ meæ, velut ventus rapuit patientiam meam, et salus mea quasi nubicula abiit.
verses.english: My paths have been reduced to nothing; my patience has been swept away like the wind, and my salvation has departed like a fleeting cloud.

verses.latin: Nunc autem in memetipso liquefacta est anima mea, et possident me dies afflictionis.
verses.english: But now, my very soul is melted within me, and days of affliction have taken possession of me.

verses.latin: Nocte os meum perforatur doloribus, et hi qui me comëdunt, non dormiunt.
verses.english: At night, my very bones are pierced with pain, and those things which consume me do not rest.
