verses.latin: In multitudine eorum vexatur vestimentum meum, et quasi tunicæ curiossimæ, circumdederunt me.
verses.english: By their great number, my clothing is vexed and torn, and they have surrounded me like a tightly-woven garment.

verses.latin: In lutum me misit, et assimilatus sum favillæ et cineri.
verses.english: God has thrown me into the mud, and I have become like dust and ashes.

verses.latin: Clamo ad te, et non exaudis me: sto, et non respicis me.
verses.english: I cry out to you, God, but you do not hear me; I stand before you, but you do not look at me.

verses.latin: Mutatus es mihi in crudelem, et in duritia manus tuæ adversaris mihi.
verses.english: You have changed your disposition toward me, becoming cruel; with the hardness of your hand, you oppose me.

verses.latin: Elevasti me, et quasi super ventum me posuisti: et illisisti me validis fluctibus.
verses.english: You lifted me up, as if setting me upon the wind, and then you dashed me down with powerful waves.

verses.latin: Scio enim quod ad mortem me tradas, ubi constituta est omnis viventium domus.
verses.english: For I know that you will hand me over to death, to that place appointed for all who live.

verses.latin: Verumtamen non ad consumptionem eorum qui in manu sua habent: et si fuerint in pernicie, ipsi salvabuntur.
verses.english: Yet, no one will stretch out their hand against those already consumed; even if they are in ruin, they themselves will be saved.

verses.latin: Flevi quondam super eum qui afflictus erat, et anima mea indoluit super pauperem.
verses.english: I once wept over those who were afflicted, and my soul grieved for the poor.

verses.latin: Expectabam bonum, et venit mihi malum: præstolebar lucem, et eruperunt tenebræ.
verses.english: I was expecting good to come, but instead, evil came to me; I looked for light, but darkness erupted.

verses.latin: Interiora mea efferbuerunt absque ulla requie, prævenerunt me dies afflictionis.
verses.english: My inner being is in turmoil without any rest; days of affliction have come upon me.

verses.latin: Mærens ingrediebar, sine furore, consurgens in turba, clamabam.
verses.english: I walked about in mourning, without my former strength, rising up in the public assembly, I cried out in agony.

verses.latin: Frater fui draconum, et socius struthionum.
verses.english: I have become a brother to jackals and a companion to ostriches, living among the desolate.

verses.latin: Pellis mea denigrata est super me, et ossa mea aruerunt æstu.
verses.english: My skin has turned black upon me, and my bones are parched from the heat of my suffering.

verses.latin: Muta est in luctum cithara mea, et organum meum in vocem flentium.
verses.english: My harp is turned to mourning, and my pipe plays the sound of those who weep.

verses.latin: Pepigi pactum cum oculis meis, ut ne cogitarem quidem de virgine.
verses.english: I made a solemn promise to my own eyes, to never even let my thoughts dwell on an unmarried woman with lust.

verses.latin: Quae enim esset pars Dei desuper, et haereditas Omnipotentis de excelso?
verses.english: For what reward would I then expect from God in heaven, what inheritance from the Almighty Lord on high?

verses.latin: Numquid non calamitas est iniquo, et pernicies operantibus injustitiam?
verses.english: Isn’t there misfortune for evil people? Isn’t there ruin for those who commit injustice?

verses.latin: Nonne ipse considerat vias meas, et cunctos gressus meos dinumerat?
verses.english: Doesn’t God Himself carefully observe all my paths, and meticulously count every single step I take?

verses.latin: Si ambulavi cum mendacio, et ad fraudem festinavit pes meus,
verses.english: If I have lived a life of deceit, or if my feet have eagerly rushed toward dishonesty,

verses.latin: appendat me statera justa, et sciat Deus simplicitatem meam.
verses.english: then let God weigh me on a truly just scale, and He will know my integrity and sincerity.

verses.latin: Si declinavit gressus meus de via, et si secutum est oculos meos cor meum, et si manibus meis quicquam iniquitatis adhaesit:
verses.english: If my steps have ever strayed from the righteous path, or if my heart has followed after what my eyes desired unlawfully, or if any injustice has stained my hands through my actions:

verses.latin: seram, et alius comedat: et progenies mea eradicetur.
verses.english: then let me plant my crops only for another to eat them, and let my whole family line be utterly wiped out.

verses.latin: Si deceptum est cor meum super mulierem, et juxta hostium amici mei insidiatus sum:
verses.english: If my heart has ever been seduced by another man's wife, and if I have ever lurked near my neighbor’s door with ill intent:

verses.latin: detrahat uxor mea alteri, et super eam incurvetur alius.
verses.english: then let my own wife grind grain for another man, and let another man have relations with her.

verses.latin: Hoc enim scelus est turpissimum, et iniquitas maxima.
verses.english: For this kind of act is a most disgraceful crime, indeed, a very great wickedness.

verses.latin: Ignis est usque ad perditionem devorans, et omnes fructus meos eradicans.
verses.english: It is like a consuming fire that burns all the way down to destruction, uprooting and destroying all the fruits of my life.

verses.latin: Si sprevi judicium servi, et ancillae meae, cum disceptarent adversum me:
verses.english: If I have ever ignored the just complaints of my male servant or my female servant, when they had a dispute against me:

verses.latin: quid enim faciam cum surrexerit ad judicandum Deus? et cum quaesierit, quid respondebo illi?
verses.english: what then will I do when God rises up to judge? And when He questions me about it, what answer will I give Him?

verses.latin: Nonne qui fecit me in utero, fecit et illum: et formavit in vulva unum?
verses.english: Didn't the very same God who made me in my mother's womb also make them? And didn't the same God form all of us, each one in the womb?

verses.latin: Si negavi quod volebant pauperibus, et oculos viduae feci tabescere:
verses.english: If I have ever denied the poor what they needed, or if I have caused the eyes of a widow to become weak with desperate longing for help:

verses.latin: si comedi buccellam meam solus, et non comedit pupillus ex ea:
verses.english: if I have ever eaten my portion of bread alone, and an orphan did not eat from it alongside me:

verses.latin: (quia ab infantia mea crevit mecum quasi pater, et de utero matris meae egressus mecum est):
verses.english: (For from my infancy, I was raised with the orphan as if I were a father to them, and from my mother’s womb, the orphan has always been with me in my care and concern):

verses.latin: si aspexi pereuntem, eo quod non esset indumentum, et pauperem non habentem quo tegeretur:
verses.english: if I have ever seen someone perishing because they had no clothing, or a poor person who had nothing to cover themselves with:

verses.latin: si non benedixerunt mihi lumbi ejus, et de velleribus ovium mearum calefactus non est:
verses.english: if their loins have not blessed me, meaning if they have not felt relief and gratitude, and if they have not been warmed by the wool from my own sheep:

verses.latin: si levavi super pupillum manum meam, etiam cum viderem me in porta superiorem:
verses.english: if I have ever lifted my hand against an orphan, even when I saw that I had the upper hand and legal advantage in the city gate:

verses.latin: brachium meum de humero suo cadat, et cum omnibus ossibus confringatur.
verses.english: then let my arm fall from its shoulder, and let it be broken into pieces along with all my bones.

verses.latin: Semper enim quasi tumentem super me habui Deum, et pondus illius ferre non potui.
verses.english: For I have always regarded God as a looming threat over me, and I could not bear the weight of His judgment for such sins.

verses.latin: Si putavi aurum fortitudinem meam, et obrizo dixi: Fiducia mea es:
verses.english: If I ever considered gold to be my strength, or if I said to fine gold, 'You are my ultimate trust and security':

verses.latin: si laetatus sum super magnis divitiis meis, et super multa manu mea repererat:
verses.english: if I have ever rejoiced greatly over my vast riches, or because my hand had acquired much wealth:

verses.latin: si vidi solem cum fulgeret, et lunam incedentem clare:
verses.english: if I have ever looked at the sun when it shone brightly, or at the moon as it moved clearly through the night sky:

verses.latin: et laetatum est in abscondito cor meum, et osculatus est manum meam os meum:
verses.english: and in secret, my heart was glad with a forbidden joy, and my mouth kissed my hand in a gesture of idolatry towards them:

verses.latin: haec quoque iniquitas judicii est maxima, et negassem Deum magnum desuper.
verses.english: this too would be a most grievous sin of judgment, for I would have denied the great God who is above all creation.

verses.latin: Si gavisus sum ad ruinam ejus qui me oderat, et exultavi quod invenisset eum malum:
verses.english: If I have ever rejoiced at the downfall of someone who hated me, or exulted because evil had befallen him:

verses.latin: neque enim dedi ad peccandum os meum, ut expeterem maledicto animam ejus:
verses.english: for I have never allowed my mouth to sin by uttering a curse, wishing for his death or destruction.

verses.latin: si non dixerunt viri tabernaculi mei: Quis det de carnibus ejus, ut saturemur?
verses.english: If the men of my tent have not said, 'Who can find someone who has not been satisfied with his meat?' meaning, who has not been fed generously by Job:

verses.latin: foris morabatur peregrinus, et ostium meum viatori patuit.
verses.english: the stranger never stayed outside my home, and my door was always open to the traveler.

verses.latin: Si quasi homo abscondi scelus meum, et celavi in sinu meo iniquitatem meam:
verses.english: If I have ever concealed my wrongdoing like other men do, hiding my iniquity deep within my own heart:

verses.latin: si pertimescebam ad multitudinem nimiam, et a despectu propinquorum, plus quam debui, conturbatus sum: et non magis tacui, nec egressus sum ostium.
verses.english: if I have been too afraid of the great multitude, and troubled more than I ought by the contempt of my relatives, and because of that, I kept silent, and did not go out my door to do justice.

verses.latin: Quis mihi tribuat auditorem, ut omnipotentis desuper desiderem librum?
verses.english: Oh, that someone would listen to me now! I desire that the Almighty in heaven write down His charges against me in a book.

verses.latin: Utique portarem illum in humero meo, et circumdarem mihi quasi coronam.
verses.english: Truly, I would carry it on my shoulder, and bind it around myself like a crown of honor.

verses.latin: Per singulos gressus meos annuntiarem illi, et quasi principi offerrem eum.
verses.english: I would declare to Him an account of my every step and action, and present it to Him as if I were a prince.

verses.latin: Si exclamavit adversum me terra mea, et cum ipsa sulci ejus ploraverunt:
verses.english: If my land has ever cried out against me, and if its furrows have wept along with it, indicating I seized it unjustly:

verses.latin: si fructus ejus comedi absque pecunia, et animam agricolarum ejus afflixi:
verses.english: if I have eaten its produce without paying for it, and if I have oppressed the souls of its laborers:

verses.latin: pro tritico oriatur mihi carduus, et pro hordeo spina. Finiti sunt sermones Job.
verses.english: then let thistles grow for me instead of wheat, and thorns instead of barley. Here ends the discourse of Job.

verses.latin: Itaque cessaverunt tres viri isti respondere Iob: eo quod iustus sibi videretur.
verses.english: So these three men stopped answering Job because he was convinced of his own righteousness.

verses.latin: Et iratus est Eliu filius Barachel Buzites, de cognatione Ram, et irascens indignatus est, eo quod Iob iustum se esse diceret coram Deo.
verses.english: But Elihu, son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became very angry. His anger burned because Job declared himself righteous before God.

verses.latin: Porro adversum amicos eius indignatus est, eo quod non invenissent responsionem, sed tantum condemnassent Iob.
verses.english: Furthermore, he was angry with Job's three friends, because they had failed to find a proper answer to Job, and instead had only condemned him.

verses.latin: Igitur Eliu expectavit super Iob verba, eo quod seniores essent.
verses.english: So Elihu waited before speaking to Job, because the others were older than him.

verses.latin: Cum ergo vidisset quod non esset responsio in ore trium virorum, iratus est vehementer.
verses.english: When he saw that the three men had no further answers to offer, he became extremely angry.

verses.latin: Et respondens Eliu filius Barachel Buzites, dixit: Junior sum tempore, et vos seniores; propterea veritus sum, et timui vobis proferre meam sententiam.
verses.english: So Elihu, son of Barachel the Buzite, began to speak. He said: 'I am young, and you are elders, so I was respectful and feared to speak my opinion to you.'

verses.latin: Dixi enim: Forsitan dies loquentur, et annorum multitudo docet sapientiam.
verses.english: For I thought, 'Surely older men will speak, and the abundance of years will teach wisdom.'

verses.latin: Sed utique spiritus est in hominibus, et inspiratio Omnipotentis dat intelligentiam.
verses.english: But truly, there is a spirit within human beings, and the inspiration of the Almighty God gives understanding.

verses.latin: Non sunt gigantes qui excellunt sapientia, nec antiqui possident iudicium.
verses.english: It is not necessarily the great in stature who are wise, nor do only the aged possess true judgment.

verses.latin: Propterea dixi: Audite me, ostendam vobis et ego meam sententiam.
verses.english: That is why I said, 'Listen to me; I also will present my opinion to you.'

verses.latin: Expectavi enim sermones vestros, audivi prudentiam vestram, donec sermo compleretur.
verses.english: For I waited for your speeches, I listened closely to your reasoning, until your discourse was finished.

verses.latin: Et usque ad attentionem vestram consideravi: et ecce non est qui arguere possit Iob, et de sermonibus eius respondere cuiquam vestrum.
verses.english: I paid close attention to all of you, and indeed, none of you could refute Job or provide a suitable response to his arguments.

verses.latin: Ne forte dicatis: Invenimus sapientiam; Deus proiecit eum, et non homo.
verses.english: Do not say in your hearts, 'We have found wisdom here; God is the one who will prove him wrong, not a human being.'

verses.latin: Non vobis locutus est, et in sermonibus vestris non respondebo illi.
verses.english: Job's arguments were not directed at you, so I will not answer him using your arguments.

verses.latin: Conturbati sunt, nec responderunt ultra, abstuleruntque sibi eloquia.
verses.english: They were dismayed; they replied no more, having nothing further to say.

verses.latin: Quia ergo expectavi, et non sunt locuti, steterunt, nec responderunt ultra:
verses.english: Since I waited and they did not speak, since they stood silent and gave no more replies,

verses.latin: Respondens et ego partem meam reddam, et ostendam scientiam meam.
verses.english: I will also give my part in answering, and I will make known what I know.

verses.latin: Plenus quippe sum sermonibus, et coarctat me spiritus uteri mei.
verses.english: For I am full of words, and the spirit within me presses upon me.

verses.latin: Ecce venter meus quasi mustum absque spiraculo, quod lagunculas novas dirumpit.
verses.english: My inner being is like new wine that has no vent, like new wineskins that are about to burst.

verses.latin: Loquar et respirabo paululum: aperiam labia mea, et respondebo.
verses.english: I must speak to find relief; I will open my lips and reply.

verses.latin: Non accipiam personam viri, et Deum homini non aequabo.
verses.english: I will not show partiality to any man, nor will I flatter any human being.

verses.latin: Nescio enim quamdiu subsistam, et si post modicum tollat me factor meus.
verses.english: For I do not know how long I will endure, and if my Maker will take me away soon.

verses.latin: Audivit ergo, Job, sermones meos, et omnes sermones meos ausculta.
verses.english: Therefore, Job, pay attention to my message. Listen carefully to everything I am about to say.

verses.latin: Aperi os tuum, et loquere, si quid habes.
verses.english: Go ahead and speak, if you have anything to say.

verses.latin: Si autem non habes, audi me: et ego loquar tibi sermonem vitae.
verses.english: But if you have nothing to say, then listen to me. I will speak words to you that will give you understanding and life.

verses.latin: Spiritus Dei fecit me, et spiraculum Omnipotentis vivificavit me.
verses.english: God's Spirit made me, and the very breath of the Almighty gave me life.

verses.latin: Si potes, responde mihi, et sta contra faciem meam.
verses.english: If you can, then answer me. Stand here before me and present your case.

verses.latin: Ecce, ego sicut et tu de luto factus sum, et de eodem luto figuratus sum.
verses.english: Look, I am just like you, made from clay. I was also formed from the same earth.

verses.latin: Non te terreat terror meus, et gravitas mea non te premat.
verses.english: My authority won't terrify you, and my seriousness won't overwhelm you.

verses.latin: Dixisti ergo in auribus meis, et vocem verborum tuorum audivi:
verses.english: You have spoken these things within my hearing, and I have listened to the sound of your words.

verses.latin: Mundus sum, et absque peccato; immaculatus, et absque iniquitate.
verses.english: You said, 'I am pure, without sin. I am spotless and without any wrongdoing.'

verses.latin: Quia invenit in me occasiones sermonum, idcirco reputavit me inimicum sibi.
verses.english: You claim that God found reasons to accuse you, and therefore He considered you His enemy.

verses.latin: Posuit in nervo pedem meum, observavit omnes semitas meas.
verses.english: You said He put your foot in a snare and watched all your paths.

verses.latin: Ecce, in hoc non es justificatus, respondebo tibi: quia major est Deus homine.
verses.english: Listen, in this you are not justified, and I will answer you: for God is greater than any human being.

verses.latin: Cur contendis adversus eum? quia ad omnia verba tua non respondet.
verses.english: Why do you argue against Him? It's because He does not respond to all your words.

verses.latin: Semel loquitur Deus, et secundo idipsum non repetit.
verses.english: God speaks once, and then a second time, though not always repeating the exact same message.

verses.latin: Per somnium in visione nocturna, quando irruit sopor super homines, et dormiunt in lectulo:
verses.english: He speaks through dreams in a night vision, when a deep sleep falls upon people and they are sleeping in their beds.

verses.latin: tunc aperit aures virorum, et erudiens eos, instruit disciplina.
verses.english: Then He opens the ears of men, and by instructing them, He teaches them wisdom and discipline.

verses.latin: Ut avertat hominem ab his quae facit, et liberet eum a superbia.
verses.english: This is to turn a person away from the wrong things he is doing and to free him from his pride.

verses.latin: Erudivit animam ejus ut erueret eam de fossa: et vitam ejus ne pertransiret ad inferos.
verses.english: He instructs his very self to rescue it from the pit of destruction, and to prevent his life from passing into the realm of the dead.

verses.latin: Increpat quoque per dolorem in lectulo, et ossa ejus quasi tinea comminuit.
verses.english: He also corrects a person through pain on his sickbed, and his bones are crushed as if by a moth.

verses.latin: Abominabilis ei effecta est in vita sua panis, et animae illius cibus primus.
verses.english: During his illness, food becomes repulsive to him, and his very self rejects his most basic nourishment.

verses.latin: Extenuata est caro ejus, et ossa quae tecta fuerant, nudata sunt.
verses.english: His flesh wastes away, and his bones, which had been covered, become exposed.

verses.latin: Appropinquavit ad corruptionem anima ejus, et vita illius ad penetrales mortis.
verses.english: His very self draws near to decay, and his life approaches the innermost chambers of death.

verses.latin: Si fuerit angelus cum eo, unus de millibus, qui annunciet hominis aequitatem,
verses.english: If there is an angel with him—one of a thousand—who can declare a person's uprightness,

verses.latin: Miserebitur ejus, et dicet: Libera eum ut non descendat in interitum; inveni in quo ei propitier.
verses.english: Then the angel will have mercy on him and say: 'Deliver him so that he does not go down into destruction; I have found a ransom for him.'

verses.latin: Reddetur caro ejus sicut infantis, atque ad annos adolescentiae revertetur.
verses.english: His flesh will be restored like that of a child, and he will return to the vigor of his youth.

verses.latin: Deprecabitur Deum, et placabilis ei erit: et videbit faciem ejus in jubilo, et reddet homini justitiam suam.
verses.english: He will pray to God, and God will be favorable to him. He will see God's face with joy, and God will restore his righteousness to him.

verses.latin: Respiciet homines, et dicet: Peccavi, et vere deliqui, et ut eram, non recepi.
verses.english: He will look at others and declare: 'I have sinned, and indeed I have done wrong, and I did not receive what I deserved.'

verses.latin: Liberavit animam meam ut non intraret in interitum, et vita mea lucem videbit.
verses.english: God rescued my very self from entering destruction, and my life will see the light of life.

verses.latin: Ecce, haec omnia facit Deus tribus vicibus per singulos.
verses.english: See, God does all these things three times, with each individual person.

verses.latin: Ut revocet animas eorum de corruptione, et illuminet luce viventium.
verses.english: He does this to bring their very selves back from decay and to illuminate them with the light of the living.

verses.latin: Attende, Job, et audi me: et tace, et ego loquar.
verses.english: Pay attention, Job, and listen to me. Be silent, and I will speak.

verses.latin: Si autem habes aliquid quod loquaris, responde mihi, loquere: volo enim te justificari.
verses.english: But if you have anything to say, answer me. Speak, for I wish for you to be justified.

verses.latin: Quod si non, audi me, et tace: et docebo te sapientiam.
verses.english: But if not, then listen to me and be silent, and I will teach you wisdom.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Eliu, ait:
verses.english: Eliu then continued speaking, saying:

verses.latin: Audite, sapientes, verba mea, et eruditi, auscultate me.
verses.english: “Listen to my words, you who are wise, and you who are learned in the ways of God, give heed to what I say.

verses.latin: Aures enim judicant verba, et sicut palatum cibos.
verses.english: For just as the mouth tastes and discerns food, so the ears judge and discern words.

verses.latin: Eligamus nobis judicium, et inter nos videamus quid sit optimum.
verses.english: Let us choose what is right and just for ourselves, and let us together discern what is truly best.

verses.latin: Dixit enim Job: Justus ego sum, et Deus avertit judicium meum.
verses.english: For Job has said: ‘I am righteous, and God has turned away my judgment, refusing to acknowledge my innocence.

verses.latin: Mentitus est enim, dicens: Violenta est causa mea; sagitta mea vulnerata est absque ulla peccati culpa.
verses.english: He has lied, saying: ‘My cause is one of violence and injustice; my wound has been inflicted without any fault or sin on my part.’

verses.latin: Quis est vir ut Job, qui bibit iram quasi aquam?
verses.english: Who is there like Job, who drinks down scorn and anger as if it were water, saturating himself with bitterness?

verses.latin: Qui graditur cum operantibus iniquitatem, et ambulat cum viris impiis.
verses.english: He walks and associates with those who commit wickedness, and he keeps company with impious men.

verses.latin: Dixit enim: Non placebit viro, etiam si cucurrerit cum Deo.
verses.english: For he has declared: ‘It will not please a man, even if he strives to run with God, to be righteous.’ This means that striving for God's approval is fruitless.

verses.latin: Idcirco, viri cordati, audite me: absit a Deo impietas, et a Patre omnipotente iniquitas.
verses.english: Therefore, listen to me, you men of understanding and insight: may ungodliness and wickedness be far from God, and may injustice be far from God the Father Almighty.

verses.latin: Sed reddet homini opus suum, et juxta vias singulorum restituet eis.
verses.english: But He will surely repay each person for his work, and He will restore to each according to their individual ways and deeds.

verses.latin: Vere enim Deus non faciet impie, nec Omnipotens subvertet judicium.
verses.english: Truly, God will not act impiously, nor will the Almighty ever subvert justice.

verses.latin: Quis alius dedit illi terram? aut quis orbem condidit quem regit?
verses.english: Who else gave Him the earth? Or who founded the world that He now rules? No one.

verses.latin: Si direxerit ad eum cor suum, spiritum ejus et halitum ad se trahet:
verses.english: If He were to direct His attention to Himself alone, and withdraw His own Spirit and the breath of life back to Himself from all creation,

verses.latin: deficiet omnis caro simul, et homo in cinerem revertetur.
verses.english: then all flesh would perish together instantly, and every human being would return to dust.

verses.latin: Si habes ergo intellectum, audi quod dicor, et ausculta vocem eloquii mei.
verses.english: Therefore, if you possess understanding, hear what I am saying, and listen carefully to the voice of my discourse.

verses.latin: Numquid qui non amat judicium, potest stare? et quomodo tu eum qui justus est, et fortis, atque operatur judicium, condemnas?
verses.english: Can one who does not love justice endure? And how can you condemn Him who is righteous, mighty, and perfectly executes justice?

verses.latin: Qui dicit regi: Apostata, qui vocat duces: Impio?
verses.english: Is it right to say to a king, ‘You are a renegade!’ or to call rulers, ‘You are impious!’?

verses.latin: Qui non accipit personas principum, nec novit tyrannum cum pastore: quia omnium opus est manus ejus.
verses.english: God does not show partiality to princes, nor does He regard a tyrant more than a shepherd, because all are the work of His hands.

verses.latin: Momento morientur, et subito in media nocte turbabuntur populi, et pertransibunt: et auferent violentum absque manu.
verses.english: In a moment they will die, and suddenly in the middle of the night, peoples will be troubled and pass away; and the violent one will be taken away without any human hand.

verses.latin: Quia oculi ejus super vias hominum, et omnes gressus eorum considerat.
verses.english: For His eyes are upon the ways of men, and He considers all their steps and movements.

verses.latin: Non sunt tenebrae, et non est umbra mortis, ut abscondantur ibi qui operantur iniquitatem.
verses.english: There are no dark places, nor is there any shadow of death deep enough for those who commit wickedness to hide themselves there from Him.

verses.latin: Neque enim ultra tendit homo ad Deum, ut veniat cum illo in judicium.
verses.english: For God does not need to extend His examination further, nor does He summon a man to come before Him for judgment in the way human courts do.

verses.latin: Conteret multos innumerabiles, et stabiles faciet pro eis.
verses.english: He crushes many countless individuals, and He raises up others in their place.

verses.latin: Novit enim opera eorum, et idcirco inducet noctem, et conterentur.
verses.english: For He knows their works, and therefore He brings the darkness of punishment upon them, and they are crushed.

verses.latin: Quasi impios percussiit eos in loco videntium.
verses.english: He strikes them down as impious men in a place where all can see.

verses.latin: Qui quasi de industria recesserunt ab eo, et omnes vias ejus intelligere noluerunt,
verses.english: They deliberately turned away from Him, and they refused to understand all of His ways and commands.

verses.latin: ut pervenire facerent ad eum clamorem pauperis, et audiret voces inopum.
verses.english: This means they caused the cry of the poor to reach Him, and He heard the voices of the needy.

verses.latin: Si enim ipse dederit requiem, quis est qui condemnet? si absconderit vultum, quis est qui contempletur eum? et super gentes et super omnes homines.
verses.english: If He Himself grants peace and rest, who then can condemn? If He hides His face, who can behold Him? This applies to both nations and to all individual human beings.

verses.latin: Qui regnare facit hominem hypocritam propter peccata populi.
verses.english: He allows a hypocritical man to reign as king because of the sins of the people.

verses.latin: Numquid dicet aliquis Deo: Suscepi, non peccabo?
verses.english: Will anyone say to God: ‘I have received my just punishment, I will not sin again’?

verses.latin: Absque eo quod offendi, doce me; si iniquitatem operatus sum, ultra non addam.
verses.english: If I have offended unknowingly, teach me what I did wrong; if I have committed iniquity, I will not add to it further.

verses.latin: Numquid juxta arbitrium tuum reputabit illud? quia repugnasti. Tu enim eliges, et non ego: et si quid nosti melius, loquere.
verses.english: Will God reckon it according to your judgment, because you have resisted Him? For you, not I, choose what you believe; and if you know anything better, speak it now.

verses.latin: Viri intelligentes loquantur mihi, et vir sapiens audiat me.
verses.english: Let men of understanding speak to me, and let a wise man hear what I say.

verses.latin: Job autem stulto sermone locutus est, et verba illius non sonant disciplinam.
verses.english: But Job has spoken with foolish discourse, and his words do not sound like true instruction or wisdom.

verses.latin: Ob quam rem, Patrem deprecor: ut Job probetur usque ad finem,
verses.english: For this reason, I pray to the Father that Job be tested to the very end,

verses.latin: eo quod addat ad peccatum suum delictum, et inter nos cunctis sermonibus ejus provocet.
verses.english: because he adds transgression to his sin, and in all his words, he provokes us, and challenges God Himself.

verses.latin: Haec rursum locutus est Eliu, et ait:
verses.english: Eliu spoke again, and he said:

verses.latin: Numquid aequum tibi videtur, ut diceres: Justior sum Deo?
verses.english: Do you think it is right for you to declare, 'I am more righteous than God?'

verses.latin: Dixisti enim: Non tibi prodest si cessavero a peccato.
verses.english: For you have said, 'What profit is there for You, O God, if I do not sin?'

verses.latin: Ego ad te eloquar, et ad amicos tuos tecum.
verses.english: I will speak to you concerning this, and to your friends who are with you.

verses.latin: Contemplare caelum, et intuearis: et aspice ad ethera, quae altiora te sunt.
verses.english: Look up at the universe, and observe it; behold the skies, which are higher than you.

verses.latin: Si peccaveris, quid ei nocebis? et si multiplicata fuerint iniquitates tuae, quid ei facies?
verses.english: If you have sinned, how do you harm God? And if your iniquities are multiplied, what do you do to Him?

verses.latin: Si juste egeris, quid donabis ei? aut quid de manu tua accipiet?
verses.english: If you have acted righteously, what do you give to Him? Or what does He receive from your hand?

verses.latin: Homini qui similis tui est, nocebit impietas tua: et filium hominis adjuvabit justitia tua.
verses.english: Your wickedness harms only a human being who is like you; and your righteousness helps only a son of man.

verses.latin: Propter multitudinem vocum tyranni, clamabunt: et eiulabunt a facie brachii potentiae.
verses.english: Because of the many oppressions from powerful rulers, people cry out and wail for rescue from violent power.

verses.latin: Et non est qui dicat: Ubi est Deus, qui fecit me, qui dedit carmina in nocte?
verses.english: Yet no one says, 'Where is God, my Creator, who gives songs of comfort in the darkest night?'

verses.latin: Qui docuit nos supra jumenta terrae, et super volucres caeli erudivit nos.
verses.english: He who teaches us more than the beasts of the earth and makes us wiser than the birds of the sky, is not questioned.

verses.latin: Ibi clamabunt, et non exaudietur propter superbiam malorum.
verses.english: There, people will cry out, but God will not hear them because of the arrogance and pride of the wicked.

verses.latin: Ergo frustra audit Deus, et Omnipotens vacua non intuetur.
verses.english: Therefore, God does not hear their prayers in vain, for the Almighty does not look upon empty pleas without cause.

verses.latin: Quanto magis cum dixeris: Non judicat, stat causam tuam, et expecta eum.
verses.english: How much more so, when you say, 'God does not judge, He sets aside your cause, and you must just wait for Him.'

verses.latin: Nunc enim non judicat, sed est judicium ante eum, et tu sustines.
verses.english: But for now, He does not judge, though judgment is before Him, and you are enduring this trial.

verses.latin: Ergo Job frustra aperit os suum, et absque scientia verba multiplicat.
verses.english: Therefore, Job vainly opens his mouth, and without true knowledge multiplies his words.

verses.latin: Non sum tibi locutus, ut sis justior Deo?
verses.english: Have I not spoken to you, to prove that you think yourself more righteous than God?

verses.latin: Multa patior, et non exaudior, nec est qui me vindicet.
verses.english: You say: 'I suffer much, and I am not heard, nor is there anyone to vindicate me.'

verses.latin: Et dixit Eliu: Adhuc eloquar verba Dei, ut ostendam tibi quod justus sit factor meus.
verses.english: And Eliu said: 'I will yet speak words from God to show you that my Maker is just.'

verses.latin: Verbis meis addiscere poteris scientiam, et non quasi a meipso.
verses.english: You will be able to learn knowledge from my words, and not as if they came from myself alone.

verses.latin: Vere absque mendacio sermonem meum proferam, et non est in me fallacia.
verses.english: Truly, I will speak my discourse without deceit, and there is no falsehood in me.

verses.latin: Dominus autem est potens in fortitudine, et absque ullius comparationis scientia.
verses.english: But the Lord is powerful in strength, and He possesses knowledge beyond any comparison.

verses.latin: Non deponit quemquam, qui sibi crediderit: et facit judicium in omnes, qui in se speraverint.
verses.english: He does not cast away anyone who trusts in Him; and He executes judgment on all who hope in Him.

verses.latin: Est autem potentior omni populo, nec est qui consimilis ei sit.
verses.english: Indeed, He is more powerful than any people, and there is no one who is like Him.

verses.latin: Non est qui se audeat illi opponere: nec est qui consimilis ei sit.
verses.english: There is no one who dares to oppose Him; and there is no one who is like Him.

verses.latin: Et quis dicet ei: Quid agis? aut quis se opponet ei?
verses.english: And who will say to Him: 'What are You doing?' Or who will set himself against Him?

verses.latin: Memor esto ut magnifices opus ejus, de quo cecinerunt viri.
verses.english: Remember to praise His work, about which people have sung.

verses.latin: Omnes homines viderunt illud: et in altum contemplati sunt procul.
verses.english: All humanity has seen it, and from afar they have contemplated it in its height.

verses.latin: Ecce Deus magnus vincens scientias, et qui est in multis annis.
verses.english: Behold, God is great, excelling in knowledge, and who is from many years ago, that is, eternal.

verses.latin: Qui autem facit judicium, non est similis ei.
verses.english: He who executes judgment, there is no one like Him.

verses.latin: Nemo est qui consimilis ei sit in fortitudine, aut qui se opponat ei.
verses.english: There is no one who is like Him in strength, or who can set himself against Him.

verses.latin: Qui facit judicium, non est similis ei.
verses.english: He who executes judgment, there is no one like Him.

verses.latin: In cordibus eorum posuit sapientiam, et non est qui consimilis ei sit.
verses.english: He has put wisdom in their hearts, yet there is no one who is like Him.

verses.latin: Ecce iste magnus, et non cognoscimus: numerus annorum ejus est, et non est qui consimilis ei sit.
verses.english: Behold, this One is great, and we do not know Him; His years are beyond number, and there is no one who is like Him.

verses.latin: Numquid scire poteris semitas ejus, et comprehendere vias ejus, et non est qui consimilis ei sit?
verses.english: Can you truly know His paths, and understand His ways, and yet there is no one who is like Him?

verses.latin: Qui disponit caelos, et non est qui consimilis ei sit.
verses.english: He who arranges the skies, yet there is no one who is like Him.

verses.latin: Et qui disposuit opera sua, et non est qui consimilis ei sit.
verses.english: And He who has ordered His works, yet there is no one who is like Him.

verses.latin: Quis potest simul intelligere omnia opera Dei, quae sunt a seculo, et non est qui consimilis ei sit?
verses.english: Who can simultaneously understand all the works of God, which exist from eternity, and yet there is no one who is like Him?

verses.latin: Et qui dedit eis scientiam, et non est qui consimilis ei sit.
verses.english: And He who has given them knowledge, yet there is no one who is like Him.

verses.latin: Qui facit mirabilia magna, et inscrutabilia, et non est qui consimilis ei sit.
verses.english: He who performs great and inscrutable wonders, yet there is no one who is like Him.

verses.latin: Adjiciens quoque Eliu, hæc locutus est:
verses.english: Elihu then continued to speak, saying these things:

verses.latin: Sustinere me paullulum, et ostendam tibi: adhuc enim habeo quod pro Deo loquar.
verses.english: Wait for me for a short while, and I will show you; for I still have more to say, speaking on God’s behalf.

verses.latin: Repetam scientiam meam a principio, et sermonibus meis probabo justum factorem meum.
verses.english: I will review my wisdom from its very beginning, and with my words, I will prove that my Creator is just.

verses.latin: Vere enim absque mendacio, sermones mei, scientia perfecta tibi probabitur.
verses.english: Truly, my words are without falsehood, for perfect knowledge will be proven to you.

verses.latin: Deus potentes est, et neminem abjicit, potens in fortitudine cordis.
verses.english: God is powerful, and He rejects no one, for He is mighty in the strength of His will.

verses.latin: Non salvat impios, et judicium pauperibus tribuit.
verses.english: He does not save the impious, but He grants justice to the poor.

verses.latin: Non aufert a justo oculos suos: et reges in solio collocat, et illos firmiter constituit in perpetuum.
verses.english: He does not turn His eyes away from the just; He sets up kings on their thrones, and establishes them firmly forever.

verses.latin: Qui si fuerint in catenis, et vinciantur funibus paupertatis:
verses.english: If they are held captive in chains, and are bound by the cords of affliction:

verses.latin: indicabit eis opera eorum, et scelera eorum, quia excesserunt.
verses.english: He reveals to them their works, and their transgressions, because they have gone too far.

verses.latin: Aperiet quoque aures eorum, ut corripiat: et loquetur ut revertantur ab iniquitate.
verses.english: He also opens their ears to receive correction, and He speaks so that they might turn away from wickedness.

verses.latin: Si audierint, et observaverint, complebunt dies suos in bono, et annos suos in gloria.
verses.english: If they listen and obey, they will live out their days in prosperity, and their years in honor.

verses.latin: Si autem non audierint, transibunt per gladium, et consumentur in stultitia.
verses.english: But if they do not listen, they will perish by the sword, and will be consumed by their own folly.

verses.latin: Simulatores et callidi provocant iram Dei, neque clamabunt cum vincti fuerint.
verses.english: Those who are hypocritical and cunning provoke God’s wrath, and they will not cry out to Him when they are bound in affliction.

verses.latin: Morietur in tempestate anima eorum, et vita eorum inter effeminatos.
verses.english: Their lives will end in disaster, and their time will be spent among the spiritually weak and defiled.

verses.latin: Eripiet de angustia pauperem per justitiam, et revelabit in tribulatione aurem ejus.
verses.english: He delivers the afflicted from their distress through His justice, and opens their ears to hear Him in times of trouble.

verses.latin: Igitur salvabit te de ore angusto, ubi non est fundamentum subter, et requies tua erit plena ubertate.
verses.english: Thus, He will deliver you from the narrow straits of trouble, where there is no firm ground beneath you. Then your rest will be filled with abundance.

verses.latin: Causa tua quasi judicium impii, judicata est: justitiam et judicium suscipies.
verses.english: Your cause has been judged as if it were the judgment of the wicked; yet you will receive justice and righteous judgment from God.

verses.latin: Ne ergo te deponat ira in superbiam: cave ne multitudine donorum, curveris.
verses.english: Therefore, do not let your anger lead you into arrogance; be careful lest by many bribes, you are led astray.

verses.latin: Non te salvet oratio tua a tribulatione, cum omnibus robustissimis.
verses.english: Your cry will not rescue you from affliction, nor will all the mightiest men be able to help you.

verses.latin: Ne desideres noctem, ut ascendat populus pro illis.
verses.english: Do not long for the night, when people are suddenly swept away from their places.

verses.latin: Cave ne declines ad iniquitatem: hanc enim cœpisti sequi post miseriam.
verses.english: Be careful not to turn toward wickedness, for you have begun to pursue this path after your affliction.

verses.latin: Ecce Deus excelsus in fortitudine sua, et neminem similis ei legis lator.
verses.english: Behold, God is exalted in His power, and there is no lawgiver like Him.

verses.latin: Quis potest illi investigare viam, aut quis potest ei dicere: Quia iniquitatem fecisti?
verses.english: Who can examine His ways, or who can say to Him, 'You have done wrong'?

verses.latin: Memento ut magnifices opus ejus, de quo cecinerunt viri.
verses.english: Remember to magnify His works, of which men have sung praises.

verses.latin: Omnes homines viderunt, procul intuetur homo.
verses.english: All mankind has seen them, yet man beholds them from afar.

verses.latin: Ecce Deus magnus, vincens scientiam nostram: numerus annorum ejus inæstimabilis.
verses.english: Behold, God is great, surpassing our knowledge; the number of His years is immeasurable.

verses.latin: Qui aufert stillas pluviæ, et effundit imbres ad instar fluentorum.
verses.english: He draws up the tiny drops of water, and pours out the rains like surging floods.

verses.latin: Quæ de nubibus stillant, pluunt super homines multos.
verses.english: which distill from the clouds, and fall as rain upon many people.

verses.latin: Si voluerit expandere nubes quasi tentorium suum, et illuminare cardines suos.
verses.english: If He chooses to spread out the clouds like His canopy, and to illuminate their farthest reaches.

verses.latin: Ecce extendit super illud lumen suum, et radices maris operit.
verses.english: Behold, He extends His light over them, and He covers the foundations of the sea.

verses.latin: Per hæc enim judicat populos, et dat escam plurimis.
verses.english: For by these —elements of nature— He judges nations, and provides food for many people.

verses.latin: In manibus abscondit lucem, et præcipit ei ut revertatur.
verses.english: He holds the lightning bolts in His hands, and commands them where to strike.

verses.latin: Narrat de ea amico suo, quod possessio ejus sit, et super ascensum ejus.
verses.english: His thunder announces its presence —referring to the lightning— proclaiming that it is His own possession, and speaks of its rising power.

verses.latin: Super hoc expavit cor meum, et emotum est de loco suo.
verses.english: At this, my heart trembles in awe, and it is shaken from its place.

verses.latin: Audite, audite, fragorem vocis ejus, et sonum de ore illius procedentem.
verses.english: Listen closely, listen to the rumbling roar of God’s voice, and the sound of it as it proceeds from His mouth.

verses.latin: Sub omni caelo ipse discurrit, et lumen illius ad terminos terrae.
verses.english: God causes His lightning to streak across the entire sky, and its light flashes to the very ends of the earth.

verses.latin: Post hunc rugiet sonitus, tonabit voce magnitudinis suae: et non prohibebit cum audita fuerit vox ejus.
verses.english: After this, the thunder will roar; God will make it thunder with the majestic sound of His voice. And no one can stop it once His voice is heard.

verses.latin: Tonabit Deus in voce sua mirabiliter, qui facit magna et inscrutabilia.
verses.english: God thunders with His voice in a wonderful way, for He does great and unfathomable things.

verses.latin: Qui praecipit nivi ut descendat in terram, et imbri hiemali, et imbri fortitudinis suae.
verses.english: He commands the snow to fall upon the earth, and the winter rain, and the downpour of His great power.

verses.latin: In cujus manu signat omnes homines, ut sciat unusquisque opera sua.
verses.english: By His hand, God stops all men from their work, so that each one may reflect on what he has done.

verses.latin: Ingredietur bestia latibulum suum, et in antris suis commorabitur.
verses.english: The wild beasts will enter their lairs, and will stay in their dens.

verses.latin: De interioribus egreditur tempestas, et a septentrione gelidus.
verses.english: From the deep clouds comes the tempest, and from the North comes the bitter cold.

verses.latin: Flante Deo, datur gelu, et rursum latissimae aquae strictae fiunt.
verses.english: At the breath of God, frost is given, and the vast expanses of water become hard ice.

verses.latin: Frumentum desiderat nubes, et nubes spargunt lumen suum.
verses.english: The grain yearns for the clouds to bring rain, yet the clouds also scatter forth their light—the lightning.

verses.latin: Quae discurrent per circuitum, quocumque eas voluntas illius duxerit, ad omne quod praeceperit illis super faciem orbis terrarum.
verses.english: The clouds move about in every direction, wherever His will leads them, to fulfill every command He gives them across the surface of the whole earth.

verses.latin: Sive in una tribu, sive in terra sua, sive in qualibet re alia, praeceperit illis.
verses.english: He causes them to appear either for a specific region or people, or for His own land, or for any other particular purpose He has given them.

verses.latin: Ausculata, Job, haec: sta, et considera mirabilia Dei.
verses.english: Listen to this, O Job; stand still and contemplate the wonderful works of God.

verses.latin: Numquid scis quando praeceperit Deus pluviis, ut ostenderent lumen nubis illius?
verses.english: Do you know when God commands the rains to come, so that they might reveal the light of His cloud—the lightning?

verses.latin: Numquid nosti semitas nubium magnas, et perfectas scientias?
verses.english: Do you understand the vast paths of the clouds, and the perfect knowledge of Him who directs them?

verses.latin: Quare vestimenta tua calida sunt, cum perflata fuerit terra austro?
verses.english: Why are your garments warm, when the earth is swept by the south wind?

verses.latin: Forsitan fabricatus es cum eo caelos, qui firmissimi sunt quasi aere fusi?
verses.english: Can you, then, create the skies with Him, which are as firm as a cast bronze mirror?

verses.latin: Ostende nobis quid dicamus illi: nos enim caligamus, nec quid loquamur scimus.
verses.english: Tell us what we should say to Him, for we are blinded by His glory and do not know what words to speak.

verses.latin: Numquid narrari ei potest quid loquar? aut si homo locutus fuerit, devorabitur?
verses.english: Can it be told to God what I would speak? Or if a man speaks, will he not be consumed?

verses.latin: At nunc non vident lucem: aer spissatus grandine in glaciem.
verses.english: Now, men cannot see the light, for the air is thickened with hailstones turned to ice.

verses.latin: Ab aquilone auri fulgor veniet: et circa Deum terribilis majestas.
verses.english: From the north comes a golden splendor, and around God is terrible majesty.

verses.latin: Omnipotentem attingere non possumus: magnus in fortitudine et judicio, et justitia, et ininarrabili bonitate non affliget.
verses.english: We cannot comprehend the Almighty; He is great in strength, and in judgment, and in justice, and with unspeakable goodness He does not afflict without cause.

verses.latin: Ideo timebunt Eum viri: et non contemplabuntur omnes qui sibi videntur sapientes.
verses.english: Therefore, men will fear Him, and all who consider themselves wise will not be able to comprehend Him.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Dominus Job de turbine, dixit:
verses.english: But the Lord responded to Job from a great whirlwind. He said to him:

verses.latin: Quis est iste involvens sententias sermonibus indoctis?
verses.english: Who is this person who clouds wise counsel with words that show no understanding?

verses.latin: Accinge sicut vir lumbos tuos: interrogabo te, et responde mihi.
verses.english: Prepare yourself like a strong man ready for battle. I will ask you questions, and you must answer Me.

verses.latin: Ubi eras quando ponebam fundamenta terræ? Indica mihi, si habes intelligentiam.
verses.english: Where were you when I laid the very foundations of the earth? Tell Me, if you truly possess understanding.

verses.latin: Quis posuit mensuras ejus, si nosti? vel quis tetendit super eam funiculum?
verses.english: Who was it that determined its dimensions—if you truly know? Or who stretched out a measuring line to mark its boundaries?

verses.latin: Super quo bases illius solidatæ sunt? aut quis demisit lapidem angularem ejus,
verses.english: Upon what were its supporting columns fixed and solidified? Or who was it that carefully laid its foundational cornerstone,

verses.latin: cum laudarent simul astra matutina, et jubilarent omnes filii Dei?
verses.english: while the morning stars sang together in praise, and all the spiritual beings — the sons of God — shouted aloud with joy?

verses.latin: Quis conclusit ostiis mare, quando erumpebat quasi de vulva procedens;
verses.english: Who was it that enclosed the vast sea with doors, as it burst forth from the earth as if from a womb?

verses.latin: cum ponerem nubem vestimentum ejus, et caligine illud quasi pannis involverem?
verses.english: When I used the clouds as its covering garment, and wrapped it in thick, dark mist like swaddling clothes?

verses.latin: Circumdedi illud terminis meis, et posui vectem et ostia;
verses.english: I established its precise boundaries with My decree, and placed strong bars and mighty doors to contain it;

verses.latin: et dixi: Hucusque venies, et non procedes amplius, et hic confringes tumentes fluctus tuos.
verses.english: and I declared: 'You may come this far, but you shall not advance any further. Here, your proud, swelling waves will be broken and subdued.'

verses.latin: Numquid post nativitatem tuam præcepisti diluculo, et ostendisti auroræ locum suum?
verses.english: Have you, since your birth as a human, ever commanded the morning to appear, or shown the dawn its proper place to rise?

verses.latin: et tenuisti concutiens extrema terræ, et excussisti impios ex ea?
verses.english: Have you ever taken hold of the very edges of the earth to shake them, or dislodged the wicked from its surface through such an action?

verses.latin: Revertetur sicut lutum sigillum, et stabit sicut vestimentum.
verses.english: The form of the earth is changed as clay is molded by a seal, and its features become distinct, like a well-formed garment.

verses.latin: Auferetur ab impiis lux sua, et brachium excelsum confringetur.
verses.english: From the wicked, their light and prosperity will be taken away, and their powerful arm — their strength and pride — will be utterly broken.

verses.latin: Numquid ingressus es profundum maris, et in novissimis abyssi deambulasti?
verses.english: Have you ever ventured into the deepest parts of the ocean, or walked in the farthest, hidden recesses of the primordial deep?

verses.latin: Numquid apertæ sunt tibi portæ mortis, et ostia tenebrosa detexerunt tibi?
verses.english: Have the gates of death ever been opened for you, revealing their secrets, or have the dark, shadowy doors of the underworld unveiled themselves to you?

verses.latin: Numquid considerasti latitudinem terræ? indica mihi, si nosti omnia:
verses.english: Have you truly comprehended the vast expanse of the earth? Tell Me, if you claim to know everything.

verses.latin: In qua via lux habitavit, et tenebrarum quis est locus ejus?
verses.english: Along what pathway does light truly dwell, and where is the specific dwelling place of darkness?

verses.latin: Ut ducas unumquodque ad terminos suos, et intelligas semitas domus ejus.
verses.english: Are you able to guide each—light and darkness—to its proper boundaries, and do you comprehend the pathways within its own domain?

verses.latin: Sciebas tunc, quia et natus eras, et numerus dierum tuorum magnus?
verses.english: Did you know all of this then, perhaps because you were already born and had lived for many days?

verses.latin: Numquid ingressus es thesauros nivis, aut thesauros grandinis aspexisti,
verses.english: Have you ever entered the vast storehouses of snow, or beheld the immense treasuries where hail is kept,

verses.latin: quæ præparavi in tempus angustiæ, in diem pugnæ et belli?
verses.english: which I have prepared and reserved for times of distress, for the day of battle and cosmic warfare?

verses.latin: Per quam viam spargitur lux, dividitur æstus super terram?
verses.english: By what unseen pathway is light distributed and scattered across the sky, and by what mechanism is heat diffused over the entire earth?

verses.latin: Quis dedit vehementissimo imbri cursum, et viam fulmini tonitrui?
verses.english: Who has determined the course for the most torrential rains, and who has forged a specific pathway for the lightning bolt that accompanies thunder?

verses.latin: Ut plueret super terram absque homine in deserto, ubi nullus mortalium commoratur;
verses.english: causing rain to fall even upon the earth where no man resides, in the desolate wilderness where no mortal human dwells;

verses.latin: Ut impleret inviam et desolatam, et produceret germen herbæ?
verses.english: so that He might fill the desolate, untraveled wasteland with water, and cause even the most basic green grass to sprout forth?

verses.latin: Quis est pluviæ pater? vel quis genuit stillas roris?
verses.english: Who is the true father of the rain, bringing it into existence? Or who gave birth to the countless tiny drops of dew?

verses.latin: De cujus utero egressus est glacies? et gelu de cœlo quis genuit?
verses.english: From whose mighty womb did the ice emerge? And who brought forth the frost from the very atmosphere?

verses.latin: In similitudinem lapidis aquæ durantur, et abyssus cursu suo congelascit.
verses.english: The waters harden like stone, becoming solid ice, and the great deep — even the primordial water bodies — becomes frozen in its usual flow.

verses.latin: Numquid junctas poteris facere stellas Pleiadas, aut gyrum Arcturi poteris dissipare?
verses.english: Are you able to bind together the beautiful cluster of stars known as the Pleiades, or can you loosen the tight bands that hold the constellation Arcturus in its course?

verses.latin: Numquid producis Luciferum in tempore suo, et vesperum super filios terræ consurgere facis?
verses.english: Do you bring forth the morning star, Lucifer, at its appointed time, and do you cause the evening star to rise over all the inhabitants of the earth?

verses.latin: Numquid nosti ordines cœli, et pones regulas ejus in terra?
verses.english: Do you understand the cosmic laws and ordinances that govern the universe, and can you establish their effects and rules here on earth?

verses.latin: Numquid elevabis in nebula vocem tuam, et impetus aquarum operiet te?
verses.english: Can you raise your voice into the clouds to command them, and would a torrent of water obediently cover you upon your word?

verses.latin: Numquid mittes fulgura, et ibunt, et revertentia dicent tibi: Adsumus?
verses.english: Can you dispatch lightning bolts, and will they obediently go forth, returning to you to report, 'Here we are, ready to do your bidding'?

verses.latin: Quis posuit in visceribus hominis sapientiam? vel quis dedit gallo intelligentiam?
verses.english: Who has endowed humanity with wisdom in their innermost being? Or who has granted the rooster its natural instinct and understanding?

verses.latin: Quis narrabit cœli rationem? et concentum cœli quis dormire faciet?
verses.english: Who possesses the wisdom to count the clouds and determine their celestial purpose? And who can silence the harmonious 'music' of the universe when it produces rain?

verses.latin: Quando funditur pulvis in siccitatem, et glebæ coarctantur.
verses.english: When the loose dust of the earth becomes so dry that it forms a solid mass, and the soil's clods cling tightly together due to extreme drought.

verses.latin: Numquid capies leænæ prædam, et animam catulorum ejus implebis,
verses.english: Are you able to hunt for the lioness to secure her prey, and can you fully satisfy the hungry appetite of her young cubs?

verses.latin: quando cubant in antris, et in specubus insidiantur?
verses.english: when they lie hidden in their lairs, and patiently lurk in their dens, waiting for their quarry?

verses.latin: Numquid scis tempus partus hinnulorum in petris, vel partum cervarum observasti?
verses.english: Do you know when the wild deer give birth to their fawns among the rocks? Or have you carefully observed the birth of the hinds, the female deer?

verses.latin: dinumerasti menses conceptus earum, et scisti tempus partus illarum?
verses.english: Have you precisely counted the months of their pregnancy? And do you truly know the exact moment they will give birth?

verses.latin: curvata sunt ad fetum, et pariunt, et rugitus solvunt.
verses.english: They curve themselves down to give birth. They labor and deliver their young, releasing their cries.

verses.latin: pingues facti sunt filii earum, et egressi ad pastum, proficiscuntur et non revertuntur ad eas.
verses.english: Their young grow strong and fat. They go out to graze, then they depart and do not return to their mothers.

verses.latin: Quis dimisit onagrum liberum, et vincula ejus solvit onagro?
verses.english: Who has set the wild ass free? Who has loosened the chains from the wild ass, allowing it to roam?

verses.latin: cui dedi in solitudine domum, et tabernacula ejus in terra salsuginis.
verses.english: I have given the wild ass its home in the wilderness, and its dwelling place in the barren, salty land.

verses.latin: contemnit multitudinem civitatis, nec clamorem exactoris audit.
verses.english: It despises the crowded city, and it does not hear the shouts of the driver forcing it to work.

verses.latin: campos montium pererrat; quærens omne quod viride est.
verses.english: It wanders over the mountain pastures, searching for every green plant it can find.

verses.latin: Numquid volet unicornis servire tibi, aut morabitur ad præsepe tuum?
verses.english: Will the wild ox choose to serve you? Or will it remain by your feeding trough?

verses.latin: numquid alligabis unicornem ad aratrum ut scindat sulcos post te?
verses.english: Can you bind the wild ox to a plow so that it will cut furrows behind you?

verses.latin: numquid habebis fiduciam super illius fortitudinem, et inlaboratum dimittes ei opus tuum?
verses.english: Will you place your trust in its immense strength? Will you leave your hard work entirely to it?

verses.latin: numquid credes illi quod reversurus sit, et aream tuam congregaturus sementem?
verses.english: Will you believe that it will return to you after leaving, and gather your grain into your threshing floor?

verses.latin: Penna struthionis similis est pennis herodii et accipitris.
verses.english: The wing of the ostrich is like the wings of the heron and the hawk.

verses.latin: quando derelinquit ova sua in terra, tu vero super pulverem calefacis ea.
verses.english: When it abandons its eggs on the ground, you, oh Job, would actually try to keep them warm on the dust.

verses.latin: obliviscitur quod pes conculcet, aut bestia agri conterat.
verses.english: It forgets that a foot might crush them, or that a wild animal of the field might break them.

verses.latin: duratur ad filios suos, quasi non sint sui: frustra laboravit, nullo timore.
verses.english: It is hardened toward its own children, as if they were not its own. It has labored in vain, without any fear for them.

verses.latin: privavit enim eam Deus sapientia, nec dedit illi intelligentiam.
verses.english: For God deprived the ostrich of wisdom, and did not give it understanding.

verses.latin: cum tempus fuerit, in altum alas erigit: deridet equum et ascensorem ejus.
verses.english: But when the moment comes for it to run, it raises its wings high; it mocks the horse and its rider.

verses.latin: Numquid præbebis equo fortitudinem, aut circumdabis collo ejus hinnitum?
verses.english: Do you bestow strength upon the horse? Or do you adorn its neck with a powerful mane and the sound of its neigh?

verses.latin: numquid suscitabis eum quasi cicadam? Gloria narium ejus terror.
verses.english: Do you make it leap like a locust? The majestic snorting from its nostrils is terrifying.

verses.latin: terram ungula fodit; exultat audacter: in occursum pergit armatis.
verses.english: With its hoof, it paws the ground, and it exults with boldness. It charges directly into armed men.

verses.latin: contemnit pavorem, nec cedit gladio.
verses.english: It despises fear and does not flinch from the sword.

verses.latin: super ipsum sonabit pharetra, vibrabit hasta et clypeus.
verses.english: Above it, the quiver rattles. The spear and shield flash.

verses.latin: fervens et fremens sorbet terram, nec credit quod tuba clangor sonuerit.
verses.english: Fierce and raging, it seems to devour the ground. It cannot believe that the trumpet has sounded the charge.

verses.latin: ubi audierit buccinam, dicit: Vah! procul odoratur bellum, exhortationem ducum, et ululatum exercitus.
verses.english: When it hears the war trumpet, it cries out, “Aha!” From afar, it scents the battle, the exhortations of the commanders, and the war cry of the army.

verses.latin: Numquid per sapientiam tuam attollitur accipiter, expandens alas suas ad austrum?
verses.english: Is it by your wisdom that the hawk soars upward, spreading its wings to the south wind?

verses.latin: numquid ad præceptum tuum elevatur aquila, et in arduis ponit nidum suum?
verses.english: Is it at your command that the eagle rises high and builds its nest in the lofty, inaccessible places?

verses.latin: in petris manet, et moratur in scopulis præruptis, atque inaccessis.
verses.english: It dwells among the crags and stays on the jagged, inaccessible cliffs.

verses.latin: inde contemplatur escam, et de longe oculi ejus prospiciunt.
verses.english: From there, it watches for its food, and its eyes spot prey from far away.

verses.latin: pulli ejus lambunt sanguinem: ubicumque cadaver fuerit, statim adest.
verses.english: Its young ones drink blood. Wherever a carcass is, there it is immediately present.

verses.latin: Et respondens Dominus Job de turbine, dixit:
verses.english: And the Lord answered Job from the midst of a whirlwind, saying:

verses.latin: Numquid contendere cum omnipotente? Et qui arguit Deum, respondeat ei.
verses.english: Will you contend with the Almighty? Let him who argues with God answer Him now.

verses.latin: Et respondens Job Domino, dixit:
verses.english: And Job answered the Lord, saying:

verses.latin: Quid possum respondere, qui ante te vilis sum? manum meam ponam super os meum.
verses.english: What can I answer, I who am so unworthy before you? I will place my hand over my mouth in silence.

verses.latin: Unum locutus sum, quod nunc retracto; et alterum, quibus ultra non addam.
verses.english: I have spoken once, but now I retract it. And if I were to speak a second time, I would add nothing further.

verses.latin: Et respondens Dominus Job de turbine, dixit:
verses.english: And the Lord answered Job again from the midst of the whirlwind, saying:

verses.latin: Accinge sicut vir lumbos tuos: interrogabo te, et responde mihi.
verses.english: Gird your loins like a man of strength! I will question you, and you must answer me.

verses.latin: Numquid irritum facies judicium meum? Et condemnabis me, ut justificeris?
verses.english: Will you really nullify my judgment? And will you condemn me in order to justify yourself?

verses.latin: Et si habes brachium sicut Deus, et si tonitruum simile illi potes ejaculari?
verses.english: Do you have an arm like God? Can you thunder with a voice like His?

verses.latin: Circumdare decore, et sublimitate, et induere fortitudine et gloria.
verses.english: Adorn yourself with splendor and majesty, and clothe yourself with strength and glory.

verses.latin: Et respondens Dominus Iob, dixit:
verses.english: And the Lord responded to Job, saying:

verses.latin: Numquid contendit nobiscum qui omnipotens est? et qui arguet Deum, ipse respondeat illi.
verses.english: Will the one who disputes with the Almighty now continue? Let the one who would argue against God answer Him now.

verses.latin: Et respondens Iob Dominum, ait:
verses.english: And Job responded to the Lord, saying:

verses.latin: Qui antea loquebar, loquar ultra? vel ponam manum meam super os meum?
verses.english: Shall I speak any further, I who have already spoken too much? Or should I place my hand over my mouth?

verses.latin: Unum locutus sum, et ultra non addam: et alterum, nec ultra astruam.
verses.english: I have said one thing, and I will not add to it; I have said another, and I will not repeat it.

verses.latin: Et respondens Dominus Iob de turbine, dixit:
verses.english: And the Lord responded to Job from out of the whirlwind, saying:

verses.latin: Accinge sicut vir lumbos tuos: interrogabo te, et responde mihi.
verses.english: Gird your loins like a man; I will question you, and you must answer Me.

verses.latin: An irritum facies iudicium meum? et condemnabis me, ut iustificeris tu?
verses.english: Will you then annul My judgment? Will you condemn Me, so that you may be justified?

verses.latin: Et si habes brachium sicut Deus, et si tonas voce simili illi,
verses.english: Do you have an arm like God? Can you thunder with a voice like His?

verses.latin: circumda tibi decorem, et praecelsam dignitatem: induere fortitudine, et gloria.
verses.english: Adorn yourself with splendor and supreme majesty; clothe yourself with strength and glory.

verses.latin: Effunde iram furoris tui: et respiciens omnem superbum, humilia illum.
verses.english: Unleash the full force of your furious anger; look upon everyone who is proud and humble him.

verses.latin: Respice universos superbos, et confunde eos: et contere impios in loco suo.
verses.english: Look upon all the proud and confound them; crush the wicked in their place.

verses.latin: Absconde eos in pulvere simul, et facies eorum demerge in foveam.
verses.english: Hide them all in the dust together, and plunge their faces into the pit of the grave.

verses.latin: Et ego confitebor quod salvet te dextera tua.
verses.english: Then I Myself will confess that your own right hand can save you.

verses.latin: Ecce behemoth quem feci tecum: fænum quasi bos comedet.
verses.english: Look now at Behemoth, whom I made just as I made you; he eats grass like an ox.

verses.latin: Fortitudo eius in lumbis eius: et potentia illius in umbilico ventris eius.
verses.english: His strength is in his loins, and his power is in the muscles of his belly.

verses.latin: Stringit caudam suam quasi cedrum: nervi testiculorum eius perplexi sunt.
verses.english: He makes his tail stiff like a cedar tree; the sinews of his thighs are intertwined.

verses.latin: Ossa eius velut fistulae aeris: cartilago illius quasi laminae ferreae.
verses.english: His bones are like tubes of bronze; his cartilage is like plates of iron.

verses.latin: Ipse est principium viarum Dei: qui fecit illum, applicabit ad eum gladium suum.
verses.english: He is the first among God's creations; only his Maker can bring His sword against him.

verses.latin: Huic montes fænum pariunt: omnes bestiae agri ludunt ibi.
verses.english: The mountains yield their grass for him; all the beasts of the field play near him.

verses.latin: Sub umbra dormit, in secreto calami, et in humidis.
verses.english: He sleeps under the shade, in the secret hiding place of the reeds, and in marshy places.

verses.latin: Umbra eius operiunt eum, salices torrentis circundant eum.
verses.english: The shade of trees covers him; the willows by the brook surround him.

verses.latin: Ecce absorbet fluvium, et non miratur: et habet fiduciam quod influat Iordanis in os eius.
verses.english: See, he drinks up a river without concern, and he is confident that even the Jordan can flow into his mouth.

verses.latin: In oculis eius quasi hamo capiet eum: et in sudibus perforabit nares eius.
verses.english: Can anyone take him by the eyes with a hook? Or pierce his nose with a snare?

verses.latin: An extrahere poteris leviathan hamo? et fune ligabis linguam eius?
verses.english: Can you pull out Leviathan with a fishhook? Or tie down his tongue with a rope?

verses.latin: Numquid pones circulum in naribus eius? aut confodebis maxillam eius stimulo?
verses.english: Can you put a ring in his nose? Or pierce his jaw with a hook?

verses.latin: Numquid multiplicabit ad te preces? an loquetur tibi mollia?
verses.english: Will he multiply supplications to you? Or will he speak soft words to you?

verses.latin: Numquid feriet tecum pactum? et accipies eum servum sempiternum?
verses.english: Will he make a covenant with you? Will you take him as your perpetual servant?

verses.latin: Numquid ludere poteris cum eo quasi cum ave? aut ligabis illum ancillis tuis?
verses.english: Can you play with him as with a bird? Or bind him for your servant girls?

verses.latin: Numquid scindent eum amici? component illum pastores?
verses.english: Will traders barter for him? Will merchants divide him up?

verses.latin: Numquid implebis sagenis pellem eius? et piscariorum gurgustio caput illius?
verses.english: Can you fill his skin with harpoons? Or his head with fishermen's spears?

verses.latin: Pone super eum manum tuam: memento belli, nec ultra addas.
verses.english: Lay your hand upon him; remember the battle, and do not try again.

verses.latin: An extrahere poteris Leviathan hamo, et fune ligare linguam ejus?
verses.english: Can you pull out Leviathan with a fishhook, or tie his tongue with a rope?

verses.latin: Numquid pones circulum in naribus ejus, aut confosseris maxillam ejus paxillo?
verses.english: Can you put a rope through his nose, or pierce his jaw with a spike?

verses.latin: Numquid multiplicabit ad te preces, aut loquetur tibi mollia?
verses.english: Will he often beg you for mercy, or speak gentle words to you?

verses.latin: Numquid feriet tecum pactum, et accipies eum servum sempiternum?
verses.english: Will he make a covenant with you, so you can take him as your slave for all time?

verses.latin: Numquid illudes ei quasi avi, aut ligabis illum ancillis tuis?
verses.english: Will you play with him as if he were a bird, or tie him up for your servant girls to keep?

verses.latin: Numquid partientur eum super eum amici? divident illum negotiatores?
verses.english: Will trading partners make a feast out of him? Will merchants divide him up for sale?

verses.latin: Numquid implebis sagenis pellem ejus, et scaphis piscium caput illius?
verses.english: Can you fill his skin with fishing darts, or his head with harpoons?

verses.latin: Pone super eum manum tuam: memento belli, nec ultra addas loqui.
verses.english: Try to lay your hand on him. You will remember the battle, and you will not try again.

verses.latin: Ecce spes ejus frustrabitur eum, et in conspectu suo praecipitabitur.
verses.english: Look, any hope of yours will be disappointed, and you will be overthrown by his mere presence.

verses.latin: Non est ita fortis ut suscitari possit: quis igitur resistere audebit vultui meo?
verses.english: No one is so fierce that he would dare to provoke him. Who then would dare to stand before my face? — This is God speaking, implying that if you cannot face Leviathan, you certainly cannot face God.

verses.latin: Quis ante dedit mihi ut reddam ei? sub omni caelo mea sunt omnia.
verses.english: Who has ever given Me anything first, that I should have to repay him? Everything under all of creation is mine.

verses.latin: Non parcam ei, et sermonibus ejus potentibus, et composite ad resistendum.
verses.english: I will not keep silent about him, or about his mighty strength, or his perfectly-formed ability to resist.

verses.latin: Quis revelabit faciem vestimenti ejus? et in circuitu duplici lorica ejus?
verses.english: Who can strip off his outer hide, or penetrate his double armor?

verses.latin: Portas oris ejus quis aperiet? dentes ejus per gyrum horribiles.
verses.english: Who can open the doors of his mouth? His terrifying teeth are all around it.

verses.latin: Corpus illius quasi scuta fusilia, compactum sigillis lapideis.
verses.english: His body is like cast metal shields, joined together with tight seals, like stones.

verses.latin: Unum et alterum jungitur, et per singulos spiraculum non pertransibit.
verses.english: One scale is joined tightly to another, so no breath can pass between them.

verses.latin: Singuli alterius adhaerens, et tenentes se ne separentur.
verses.english: Each scale clings to the next, holding so tightly they cannot be separated.

verses.latin: Sternutatio ejus fulgor ignis: et oculi ejus sicut palpebrae diluculi.
verses.english: His sneeze flashes like fire, and his eyes are like the bright rays of dawn.

verses.latin: De ore ejus lampades procedunt: sicut scintillae ignis egrediuntur.
verses.english: From his mouth burst forth torches, and sparks of fire shoot out.

verses.latin: De naribus ejus procedit fumus sicut a ferventis ollae et a caldariae.
verses.english: Smoke pours from his nostrils, like from a boiling pot or a burning cauldron.

verses.latin: Halitus ejus prunas commorit, et flamma de ore ejus egreditur.
verses.english: His breath sets coals ablaze, and flame comes forth from his mouth.

verses.latin: In collo ejus morabitur fortitudo, et ante faciem ejus saltabit egestas.
verses.english: Strength dwells in his neck, and terror dances before his face.

verses.latin: Membra carnis ejus cohaerentia sibimet: mittes super eum nihil, et non movebitur.
verses.english: The parts of his flesh cling together tightly; if you strike him, he will not be moved.

verses.latin: Cor ejus durum sicut lapis, et clausum quasi molae infernae.
verses.english: His heart is hard as stone, and as immovable as the lower millstone.

verses.latin: Cum surrexerit, timebunt angeli, et territi purgabuntur.
verses.english: When he rises up, the mighty will be afraid, and when terrified, they will be utterly dismayed.

verses.latin: Cum applicuerit ad eum gladius, non stabit, hastae, et contus, et lorica.
verses.english: If a sword strikes him, it will not hold. Spears, javelins, and armor are useless against him.

verses.latin: Reputabit quasi paleas ferrum, et velut lignum putridum aes.
verses.english: He regards iron as straw, and bronze as rotten wood.

verses.latin: Non fugabit eum virgo sagittis, in eum versus in stipulam convertuntur lapides fundae.
verses.english: An arrow will not make him flee; sling-stones turned against him become like stubble.

verses.latin: Aestimat malleum quasi stipulam, et deridet vibrantem hastam.
verses.english: He regards a club as straw, and he laughs at the shaking spear.

verses.latin: Sub ipso erunt radii solis, et omnis aurum sub eo quasi lutum.
verses.english: Beneath him are the rays of the sun (as he moves through the water), and all gold beneath him he treats as mud.

verses.latin: Fervescere facit quasi ollam profundum mare, et ponit quasi unguentum mare.
verses.english: He makes the deep sea boil like a pot, and makes the sea like a frothing ointment.

verses.latin: Post se lucet semita, aestimabit abyssum quasi senescentem.
verses.english: Behind him, a shining path appears, and he makes the deep seem to grow old with his passage.

verses.latin: Non est super terram potestas quae comparetur ei, qui factus est ut nihil timeat.
verses.english: There is no power on earth that can be compared to him, for he was made to fear nothing.

verses.latin: Omnes excelsos videt: ipse rex super universos filios superbiae.
verses.english: He looks down on all who are haughty, for he is king over all the children of pride.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Job Domino, dixit:
verses.english: Then Job answered the Lord and said:

verses.latin: Scio quia omnia potes, et nulla te latet cogitatio.
verses.english: I know that you can accomplish all things, and no plan of yours can be thwarted.

verses.latin: Quis est iste qui celat consilium absque scientia? Ideo insipienter locutus sum, et quae ultra modum excederent scientiam meam.
verses.english: —Who am I, that I should obscure your divine counsel without true knowledge?— Therefore, I have spoken unwisely, speaking of things that utterly exceeded my comprehension.

verses.latin: Audi, et ego loquar: interrogabo te, et responde mihi.
verses.english: —You said to me, "Listen, and I will speak; I will question you, and you respond to me."

verses.latin: Auditu auris audivi te: nunc autem oculus meus videt te.
verses.english: I had heard of you only by the hearing of my ear, but now my very own eyes see you.

verses.latin: Idcirco ipse me reprehendo, et ago pœnitentiam in pulvere et cinere.
verses.english: Therefore, I utterly condemn myself for my prior words, and I repent in dust and ashes.

verses.latin: Postquam autem locutus est Dominus verba hæc ad Job, dixit ad Eliphaz Themanitem: Iratus est furor meus in te, et in duos amicos tuos: quia non estis locuti coram me rectum, sicut servus meus Job.
verses.english: But after the Lord had spoken these words to Job, He said to Eliphaz the Temanite: "My wrath is kindled against you and against your two friends, because you have not spoken what is right before me, as my servant Job has."

verses.latin: Sumite ergo vobis septem tauros, et septem arietes, et ite ad servum meum Job, et offerte holocaustum pro vobis: Job autem servus meus orabit pro vobis. Faciem ejus suscipiam, ut non vobis imputetur stultitia: neque enim locuti estis ad me recta, sicut servus meus Job.
verses.english: Therefore, take for yourselves seven bullocks and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and offer a burnt offering for yourselves. My servant Job will pray for you, and I will accept his intercession so that your folly may not be counted against you. For you have not spoken what is right to me, as my servant Job has."

verses.latin: Abierunt ergo Eliphaz Themanites, et Baldad Suhites, et Sophar Naamathites, et fecerunt sicut locutus fuerat Dominus ad eos, et suscepit Dominus faciem Job.
verses.english: So Eliphaz the Temanite, Baldad the Shuhite, and Sophar the Naamathite went and did as the Lord had commanded them, and the Lord accepted Job's intercession.

verses.latin: Dominus quoque convertit ad pœnitentiam Job, cum oraret pro amicis suis: et addidit Dominus omnia quæ habuerat Job, duplicia.
verses.english: The Lord also turned Job's captivity to repentance—meaning He restored Job's fortunes and peace—when Job prayed for his friends. And the Lord doubled all that Job had possessed before.

verses.latin: Venerunt autem ad eum omnes fratres sui, et universæ sorores suæ, et cuncti qui noverant eum prius: et comederunt cum eo panem in domo ejus: et moverunt super eum, et consolati sunt eum super omni malo quod intulerat Dominus super eum. Et dederunt ei quasi annulum aureum unum, et inaures aureas singulas.
verses.english: Then all his brothers and all his sisters came to him, and all who had known him previously. They ate bread with him in his house, and they mourned with him and comforted him concerning all the evil that the Lord had brought upon him. Each of them also gave him a piece of money and a gold earring.

verses.latin: Dominus autem benedixit novissimis Job magis quam principio ejus. Et facta sunt ei quatuordecim millia ovium, et sex millia camelorum, et mille juga boum, et mille asinæ.
verses.english: Now the Lord blessed Job's latter end even more than his beginning. And Job had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, one thousand yoke of oxen, and one thousand female donkeys.

verses.latin: Et fuerunt ei septem filii, et tres filiæ.
verses.english: He also had seven sons and three daughters.

verses.latin: Et vocavit nomen unius Diem, et nomen secundæ Cassiæ, et nomen tertiæ Cornustibii.
verses.english: He named the first daughter Day, the second Cassia, and the third Cornustibii.

verses.latin: Non sunt autem inventæ mulieres speciosæ sicut filiæ Job in universa terra: deditque illis pater suus hæreditatem inter fratres suos.
verses.english: There were no women found throughout the entire land as beautiful as Job's daughters. And their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.

verses.latin: Vixit autem Job post hæc centum quadraginta annis, et vidit filios suos, et filios filiorum suorum usque ad quartam generationem:
verses.english: After these things, Job lived one hundred and forty years, and he saw his children and his children's children, even to the fourth generation.

verses.latin: Et mortuus est senex et plenus dierum.
verses.english: And so he died, an old man and full of days.
